questions.text: What is the biochemical basis behind exacerbation of symptoms in a patient with porphyria when there is consumption of barbiturates?
questions.solution:
The biochemical basis behind exacerbation of porphyria by barbiturates is the derepression of ALA synthase(ALAS- 1).

Drugs like barbiturates and griseofulvin are metabolized by microsomal CYP450, a heme-protein oxidase system found in the liver. They increase the synthesis of CYP450, which in turn increases the consumption of heme. This decrease in heme concentration in the liver leads to the de-repression or induction of the enzyme ALA synthase, which is the rate-limiting enzyme for heme synthesis. This leads to increased synthesis of heme precursors which exacerbates the attacks of porphyria.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: A patient with a history of a renal transplant presented with a painless pink papule which is slowly growing on his right forearm. The donor was found to have been infected with polyoma virus. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given vignette with a history of a renal transplant and infection with a polyoma virus in the donor raises concerns for Merkel cell carcinoma(MCC).

The polyoma virus is an oncogenic virus associated with the development of MCC, an aggressive form of skin cancer. It is transmitted via solid organ transplants (usually renal transplants), and the immunosuppression given after a transplant allows it to replicate in the host body and diminishes the prognosis. The virus inactivates p53 and the retinoblastoma genes.

Other Options:

Basal cell carcinoma is associated with cumulative sun exposure and presents as a pink, pearly papule.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents with a sudden pain in his right arm after attempting to lift a 30 Kg dumbbell. When asked to flex his right elbow, an abnormal bulge is seen. On further evaluation, you notice an injury to the muscle attached to the structure marked below. Which of the following signs did the patient present with?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the presence of an abnormal bulge on flexing the elbow following injury to the arm is suggestive of Popeye's sign which occurs due to the rupture of the tendon of the long head of the biceps brachii muscle.

The image above shows the radius, identified by the radial head at the elbow joint. The arrow points to a raised area, which is the radial tuberosity to which the biceps brachii is inserted.

Popeye sign appears due to the bulging of the muscle belly caused by contraction of the unrestrained muscles on flexing the elbow. The sign is named due to the resemblance of the deformity with the famous cartoon character 'Popeye'.

Biceps brachii is one of the muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm. It has two heads - a long head and the short head. The long head originates from the supraglenoid tubercle of the scapula whereas the short head originates from the apex of the coracoid process. Both heads get inserted into the radial tuberosity. 

The biceps brachii muscle is innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve (C5, C6). It causes powerful flexion of the forearm at the elbow joint and supination of the forearm. It also is an accessory flexor of the arm at the glenohumeral joint. 

Other options:

Option A: Hill-Sachs sign refers to a defect in the postero-lateral surface of the humeral head due to repeated impact against the anterior glenoid rim. It is a common complication of anterior shoulder dislocation.

Option B: Griesinger sign refers to oedema of the postauricular soft tissues overlying the mastoid process as a result of thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. It is a complication of acute mastoiditis.

Option D: Tinel's sign is used to assess nerve regeneration following injury. The nerve is percussed along its course to elicit a tingling sensation. The point of tingling marks the site of newly sprouting axons.

Related Pearl: Dermatome and root value of the upper limb

Key Sensory Areas:

  • C5 - Upper lateral part of arm
  • C6 - Palmar pad of thumb
  • C7 - Pad of index finger
  • C8 - Pad of little finger
  • T1 - Skin on medial aspect of elbow

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presented to the casualty with severe, sudden-onset chest pain radiating to the left arm. ECG showed ST-segment elevation in precordial leads. The person succumbed after 3 hours. On autopsy, the patient's heart was immersed in triphenyl tetrazolium chloride solution. Which of the following statement is true?

choices.text: Infarct myocardium appears brick red due to loss of LDH activity
Viable myocardium appears brick red due to preserved LDH activity
Infarct myocardium appears unstained due to preserved LDH activity
Viable myocardium appears unstained due to the loss of LDH activity

questions.solution:
Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride solution imparts a brick-red color to the viable non-infarcted myocardium due to preserved LDH activity.

Myocardial infarcts < 12 hours old are usually not apparent on gross examination. However, if the infarct preceded death by 2 to 3 hours, it is possible to identify the area of necrosis. This is done by immersing the tissue slices in triphenyl tetrazolium chloride solution.

The histochemical stain imparts a brick-red color to intact, noninfarcted myocardium. Here, lactate dehydrogenase, LDH, activity is preserved. LDH leaks out through the damaged membranes of dead cells, so an infarct appears as an unstained pale zone.

The image given below shows an ischemic brain after immersion in triphenyl tetrazolium chloride solution. The pale unstained region is the infarcted zone.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the OPD with a swelling in her vagina and pain during sexual intercourse. On examination, a tense shiny swelling with well-defined margins is observed on the lateral vaginal wall. It does not have any rugosities. Cough impulse is absent. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of a tender shiny swelling in the lateral vaginal wall with the absence of cough impulse points towards the diagnosis of a Gartner's cyst.

Gartner's cyst is a retention cyst in remnants of the Wolffian duct. It is typically an asymptomatic cyst that is found on the lateral wall of the vagina. Symptoms, if present include dyspareunia, vaginal pain, and difficulty inserting tampons. Examination findings include a tense shiny swelling with well-defined margins that is palpable or seen to bulge from beneath the vaginal wall.

Management involves excision or marsupialization of cyst in symptomatic cases

Other options

Option A - Epidermoid cysts (or epidermal inclusions) are skin-colored round-oval cysts commonly found on the vulva. It is caused by the traumatic implantation of epidermal cells into deep tissues or due to plugged pilosebaceous units.  Usually, they are located beneath the epidermis in the anterior half of the labia majora.

Option B - Cystocele is the prolapse of the urinary bladder into the vagina. It appears as a reducible swelling with ill-defined margins, rugosities, and a cough impulse. It is often associated with urinary symptoms.

Option C - Bartholin glands produce mucus for the lubrication of the vulva and vagina. Obstruction of this gland leads to Bartholin cyst. It is identified by its anatomic location, i.e. inferior part of labia majora or lower vestibular area. It is usually asymptomatic but becomes painful when infected.

questions.text:
In a road traffic accident, a pedestrian was hit and he suffered the following injuries. Which of these sustained injuries are most likely to be secondary injuries?
  1. Fractures of tibia and fibula
  2. Tire marks on the body
  3. Head injury
  4. Lacerations by particles of the broken windshield
  5. Patterned injuries of the radiator grill
questions.solution:
The correct option is 2 and 3 only.

  • Fractures of tibia and fibula- (Bumper injury: primary impact injury)
  • Tire marks on the body- (secondary injuries)
  • Head injury- (most common secondary injury)
  • Lacerations by particles of the broken windshield- (secondary impact injury)
  • Patterned injuries of the radiator grill- (primary impact injury)

Injuries to pedestrians:

  • Primary impact injuries are caused by the first impact of the vehicle on the victim. Eg: injuries produced are patterned injuries, and are due to the bumper, radiator grill, headlights, etc.
  • Secondary impact injuries are further injuries caused by the vehicle. Eg: Particles of the broken windshield, parts of the bonnet, etc. can produce contusions, lacerations, etc
  • Tertiary impact injuries (synonyms: Secondary injuries) are caused when the victim strikes other objects or falls on the ground after being hit by the vehicle. Eg: Head injuries are the most common injuries of this group, crush injuries, Tire marks seen on the body.

A note to clear the confusion: The question is asking for Secondary injuries, which is also called Tertiary impact injuries, which happens when the victim strikes the ground. Secondary impact injuries are the impact injuries caused by the vehicle apart from primary impact injuries. For example, lacerations produced by particles of the broken windshield, in this case.

questions.text: Transmitting coil, receiver-stimulator and electrode array are associated with which of the following devices?
questions.solution:
Transmitting coil, receiver-stimulator and electrode array are components of cochlear implant which can be used in a patient with bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss.

A cochlear implant is a medical device that uses electricity to stimulate the spiral ganglion cells of the auditory nerve to restore sensorineural hearing loss. It converts sound to an electrical signal (transduction) and delivers this to the hearing nerve, which bypasses the damaged hearing apparatus.

The principle of the surgery is to place the electrode array within the scala tympani of the cochlea via the facial recess (posterior tympanotomy) approach. An intact 8th nerve and the higher auditory pathway are prerequisites for surgery. 

The microphone, speech processor and transmitter are part of the external component of the cochlear implant which remain outside the body. The receiver-stimulator implanted during surgery (under the skin) and the electrode array (implanted in the scala tympani of the cochlea) are part of the internal component of the cochlear implant.

Device 1 is a picture of a Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA), which can be used in a patient with bilateral external auditory canal atresia and conductive deafness not amenable to other treatment procedures. 

It is comprised of a sound processor,  with a small titanium fixture implanted behind the ear, which allows the bone to transfer sound to a functioning cochlea rather than via the middle ear. This process is known as direct bone conduction. 

Device 3 is a picture of a stapedectomy piston, used in patients with otosclerosis. The treatment of choice for otosclerosis is  surgical management which includes stapedotomy/stapedectomy with the placement of a prosthesis (stapedectomy piston). The Teflon piston is a frequently used prosthesis in stapes surgery.

Device 4 is a picture of a partial ossicular replacement prosthesis (PORP) that is designed for situations when the incus and/or malleus are eroded but the stapes are structurally intact and mobile. PORP is placed between the tympanic membrane and the stapes head.

Related Pearl: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:

Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC).

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

  • Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)
  • Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text: After an antigen is presented to a Naive T-cell, what other receptor interaction is required to activate the T Cell?
questions.solution:
CD80 (B7-1) and CD86 (B7-2) are the costimulatory molecules present on antigen-presenting cells (APCs). They bind to CD28 protein present on T cells. This promotes the expansion of antigen-stimulated T cells and their differentiation into effector and memory cells.

T-cell activation requires two signals that are delivered by APCs. They include:

  1. Antigens displayed by APCs in the form of peptides bound to MHC molecules, that are recognised by T-cell receptors
  2. Costimulatory signal (as it stimulates T cells in conjunction with antigen) provided by molecules on APCs that engage particular costimulatory receptors on T cells

In the absence of costimulation, T cells that recognize antigen either fail to respond and die or enter a state of unresponsiveness known as anergy. Thus, costimulation is a key determinant of the outcome of a T-cell encounter with an antigen.

questions.text: Which of the following ethmoidal air cells are in close proximity to the sphenoid sinus?
questions.solution:
Onodi cell also called the sphenoethmoid cell is the most important cell in the posterior group of ethmoidal cells, which grows posteriorly by the side of the sphenoid sinus or superior to it for as much distance as 1.5 cm from the anterior surface of the sphenoid. 

The sphenoid sinus is in close relation to the optic nerve and sometimes the carotid artery. Therefore, while removing posterior ethmoidal cells during endoscopic surgery, the presence of Onodi cells increases the risk to the optic nerve.

The image shown below shows the location of the Onodi cell.

Ethmoidal sinuses are air-containing cavities that are present in the lateral mass of the ethmoid bone. They are bound medially by the lateral nasal wall, laterally by a thin plate of bone called the lamina papyracea, and superiorly by an extension of the orbital plate of the frontal bone. 

The ethmoid sinusoidal air cells range from 3 to 18 in number and are divided into anterior and posterior groups by a basal lamina.

Anterior cells- They open into the middle meatus. They contain-

    • Agger nasi cells - Present in the agger nasi ridge.
    • Ethmoid bulla - Forms the posterior boundary of hiatus semilunaris.
    • Supraorbital cells
    • Frontoethmoid cells- In the area of the frontal recess.
    • Haller cells - In the floor of the orbit. Lies in the roof of the maxillary sinus, and enlargement may prevent drainage of the maxillary sinus.

The image shown below shows the Haller cells.

  • Posterior cells - They open into the superior or the supreme meatus. Occasionally, they may also open directly into the sphenoid sinus. They contain about 1-7 cells, the most important one being the Onodi cells.

questions.text: Which of the following are the two intermediate hosts of Diphyllobothrium latum?
questions.solution:
Cyclops and Freshwater fish are the two intermediate hosts for diphyllobothrium latum.

Definitive host: Man, dog, and cat. Man is the optimal host.

  • First intermediate host: freshwater crustacean: Cyclops
  • Second intermediate host: Freshwater fish
  • The infective stage of humans: Plerocercoid larvae

questions.text:
Match the following Vitamins to their respective deficiency manifestations.
  Vitamin   Deficiency State
 1. Pantothenic acid  A. Hemolytic anemia, ataxia, and muscle weakness
 2. Vitamin E  B. Elevated prothrombin time and bleeding
 3. Pyridoxine  C. Anemia, convulsions, depression, tumorigenesis
 4. Vitamin K  D. Burning foot syndrome
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

  Vitamin   Deficiency State
 1. Pantothenic acid D. Burning foot syndrome
 2. Vitamin E A. Hemolytic anemia, ataxia, and muscle weakness 
 3. Pyridoxine C. Anemia, convulsions, depression, tumorigenesis
 4. Vitamin K B. Elevated prothrombin time and bleeding  

Vitamin B5/ Pantothenic acid deficiency causes burning feet syndrome. Other features of pantothenic acid deficiency include GI disturbances, paraesthesia, muscle cramps, and ataxia. Burning feet syndrome or nutritional melalgia was first seen in prisoners during the Second World War.

Vitamin B6/ Pyridoxine deficiency may present with seizures, depression, microcytic anemia, a nonspecific pruritic rash, cheilitis, and glossitis. In infants, diarrhea, seizures, and anemia can be seen.

Vitamin E is a chain-breaking antioxidant. In vitamin E deficiency, there is no prevention of lipid peroxidation caused due to free radicals. As a result of this, the erythrocyte membranes are rendered abnormally fragile leading to hemolytic anemia. It can also lead to ataxia, difficulty with upward gaze, hyporeflexia, and profuse muscle weakness.

Vitamin K  is a cofactor for gamma-carboxylation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X. Vitamin K deficiency can lead to elongation of prothrombin time and bleeding.

questions.text: A 14-year-old child presents to the OPD with complaints of absence of menstruation and decreased sense of smell. On examination, there is a lack of breast and pubic hair development. The child has normal height. Investigations reveal low FSH and LH levels. MRI was performed and was normal. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a history of amenorrhoea with a decreased sense of smell and lack of breast and pubic hair development with normal height and low FSH and LH point towards the diagnosis of Kallman syndrome.

Kallman syndrome can be inherited as an X-linked autosomal dominant, or autosomal recessive disorder. There is a mutation in the KAL-1 gene on the short arm of the X chromosome. This gene encodes an adhesion protein called anosmin-1.  Anosmin-1 is required for the migration of GnRH and olfactory neurons. Hence in patients with Kallman syndrome, the GnRH neurons fail to migrate and instead remain near the nasal epithelium which is unable to stimulate the pituitary gland to release LH and FSH.

Clinical features include a lack of testicular development in males. Micropenis can be present in some cases. In females, there is a failure to start menstruation (amenorrhea) with a lack of pubic hair and breast development. There may be associated cleft lip and cleft palate.

Investigations reveal low FSH and LH levels. Management includes combined estrogen and progestin therapy to induce menstruation. Exogenous gonadotropins are used to induce ovulation.

Other options

Option A: Idiopathic hypogonadotropic hypogonadism presents with similar clinical features as Kallman syndrome. However, there are no olfactory abnormalities in idiopathic hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

Option B: Craniopharyngioma also presents with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. However normal MRI rules out craniopharyngioma.

Option D: Resistant ovarian syndrome presents with hypergonadotropic hypogonadism with elevated FSH and LH levels.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient came to the OPD with a history of recurrent neck pain and stiffness over the last year.  He also has asymmetric bilateral loss of sensation in the lateral three digits. What is the likely etiology of the findings of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features suggestive of bilateral paresthesias and chronic neck pain are suggestive of cervical spondylosis.

Cervical spondylosis is a disorder arising due to chronic intervertebral disc degeneration in the cervical region. Changes are most common in lower cervical segments such as C5/6 and C6/7. The most common clinical feature is pain and stiffness of the neck. Involvement of different segments of the cervical spine can present with different sensory and motor symptoms. In this case, the presence of asymmetric bilateral loss of sensation in the lateral three digits indicates a compression at the C5/6 nerve root. In most cases, it is unilateral but can occur bilaterally.

The X-ray may show osteophytes and degenerative changes on Lateral view.

Treatment:

  • Conservative treatment with analgesics, physiotherapy, and the cervical collar is the mainstay
  • Operative treatments performed include:
    • Anterior discectomy and fusion
    • Foraminotomy 
    • Intervertebral disc replacement
    • Laminoplasty

Other options:

Option A: Nerve entrapments can also present with pain and paresthesias but symptoms are worse at night and follow a particular peripheral nerve rather than a nerve root distribution. Also, bilateral loss of sensations is less likely in a nerve entrapment

Option B: A syrinx is a long cavity filled with CSF usually in the cervical spine. It is usually associated with trauma or tumors in the spine. It is less likely in this patient who is middle-aged. Age-related cervical degeneration should be ruled out first.

Option D: Cervical spine stenosis presents with upper motor neuron symptoms in the areas below the level of the stenosis. This patient has no such complaints making cervical spondylosis the likely mechanism of this patient's symptoms.

Related Pearl: Dermatome and root value of the upper limb

Key Sensory Areas:

  • C5 - Upper lateral part of arm
  • C6 - Palmar pad of thumb
  • C7 - Pad of index finger
  • C8 - Pad of little finger
  • T1 - Skin on medial aspect of elbow

questions.text: An actress wants to undergo a permanent method of sterilization. However, she is concerned about the resulting scars on her abdomen. Which of the following methods of sterilization would best suit her case?
questions.solution:
Essure would best suit the actress as it is done through the hysteroscopic method, thus, avoiding abdominal scar.

The Essure permanent device is the latest method of hysteroscopic sterilization. It is a dynamically expanding micro-inserter consisting of a flexible inner coil made of stainless steel and a dynamic outer coil made of nickel-titanium alloy (nitinol). In the inner coil, there is a layer of polyethylene terephthalate fibers that occludes the fallopian tube by initiating a benign local fibrous tissue growth. This is an irreversible and permanent technique. Tubal blockage can be confirmed 3 months later by hysterosalpingography. Its advantages are that there is no abdominal scar and that it can be done under local anesthesia.

However, disadvantages include:

  • Hysteroscopy is required to insert the Essure device
  • Cost and expertise required
  • Permanent method
  • HSG to confirm blockage after 3 months
  • Bilateral insertion is difficult due to spasms in 15% of cases
  • Tuboplasty for reversal is not possible
  • Perforation of the tube 
  • The failure rate is 3.5%

Other options

Option A: Irving procedure involves ligating and excising the mid-portion of the tube after which the proximal stump is buried into the myometrium and the distal stump is buried in the broad ligament. It is an irreversible technique and may require a laparotomy incision.

The procedure described in the image below is the Irving procedure.

Option B:  In Madlener's procedure a loop of the tube is crushed and ligated with a non-absorbable suture.

Option D: In the Pomeroy procedure the fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision, and the middle portion is formed into a loop which is tied at the base with catgut and excised as shown in the image below.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male from West Bengal, presents with complaints of recurrent fever with chills for the past 3 months with progressive weakness and abdominal discomfort. On examination he has hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow aspiration finding is given in the image. Which of the following can be given for the treatment?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of recurrent fever with chills, progressive weakness, and hepatosplenomegaly along with the presence of intracellular organisms within the macrophages is suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis. It can be treated with sodium stibogluconate. 

Drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis are sodium stibogluconate, miltefosine, and amphotericin. Liposomal amphotericin single dose 10 mg/Kg IV is the first line of treatment in India. For most regions of the endemic regions of the world, pentavalent antimony compounds like sodium stibogluconate are the drug of choice. In India, antimony resistance has been noted and thus Amphotericin B is the drug of choice. Miltefosine is an oral drug that is also approved for treatment of this condition

Kala-azar or visceral leishmaniasis is a protozoal infection mainly affecting the reticuloendothelial system. It is caused by the Leishmania donovani complex which includes L. donovani and L. infantum. These organisms are transmitted by sandflies. When the infected sandfly bites a person, infectious promastigotes are released into the host dermis along with the sandfly's saliva, which potentiates parasite infectivity.

L. donovani exists in 2 forms:

  • Amastigote form- in humans and other mammals
  • Promastigote form- in the sandfly and artificial culture

The amastigote form (as shown in the image below) is also known as the Leishman-Donovan (LD) body. It is an intracellular form found inside macrophages, monocytes, and reticuloendothelial cells. It contains a kinetoplast which consists of a parabasal body and a blepharoplast. Flagellum is absent.

Promastigote form (as shown in the below image) is present in the midgut of the female sandfly. The kinetoplast lies transversely near the anterior end. A single flagellum is seen. It is the infective form of Leishmania donovani for humans.

In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh. Patients present with high fever, hepatosplenomegaly, weight loss, and emaciation. The skin becomes dry, rough, and darkly pigmented. There is anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia.

Diagnosis:

  • Rapid diagnostic test: rK39 Rapid diagnostic test and Kala azar dipstick test strip.
  • Parasitological diagnosis: Demonstration of LD bodies in buffy coat smear - confirmatory.
  • Aldehyde test of Napier: Widely used for surveillance.
  • Serological tests for diagnosis: Rapid dipstick test, Direct agglutination test, ELISA, Indirect Fluorescent Antibody Test.
  • Leishmania (Montenegro) test: Induration of 5 mm or more is considered positive, usually positive 4-6 weeks after onset in cutaneous leishmaniasis, valuable for distinguishing immune from non-immune subjects and endemicity.

Drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis are sodium stibogluconate, miltefosine, and amphotericin. Liposomal amphotericin single dose 10 mg/Kg IV is the first line of treatment in India.  

Other options:  

Option A: Benznidazole is used in the treatment of Chagas disease caused by protozoa Trypanosoma cruzi. 

Option C: Suramin is used in the treatment of African sleeping sickness caused by Trypanosoma brucei. 

Option D: Atovaquone can be used in the treatment of babesiosis and Pneumocystis jiroveci infection.

questions.text: You visit a health centre in a tribal area, that serves a population of 20,000 people. There are a total of 12 essential manpower working in this centre, as per the IPHS 2022 guidelines. Which health centre is being referred to in the above scenario?
questions.solution:

They include 1 Medical Officer (MBBS), 2 staff nurses, 1 pharmacist, 1 health worker female/ANM, 1 health worker/health assistant (male), 1 health assistant (female)/lady health visitor, 1 laboratory technician, 1 data entry operator, 1 dresser, 1 accountant, and 1 sanitation staff.

questions.text: Identify the condition in which the given type of hypersensitivity reaction is implicated.
questions.solution:
The given image illustrates a type 3 hypersensitivity reaction that is implicated in systemic lupus erythematosus.

  • Reactive arthritis.

  • Polyarteritis nodosa.
  • Serum sickness.
  • Arthus reaction.

Other options:

questions.text: A 6-year-old with HIV is brought with complaints of the rash shown below. Where does DNA replication occur in the viruses falling in the same family as the microbe causing this rash?
questions.solution:
The image shows pink, fleshy umbilicated papules suggesting molluscum contagiosum. It is caused by the Molluscum contagiosum virus belonging to Poxviridae. DNA replication in these viruses occurs in the host cytoplasm.

Replication of DNA in DNA viruses typically occurs in the host nucleus. However, poxviruses are the exception - replication of DNA occurs in the host cytoplasm. Replication of RNA in RNA viruses typically occurs in the host cytoplasm. However, orthomyxoviruses and retroviruses are the exception - replication of RNA occurs in the host nucleus.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with a complaint of pain in the wrist. He was diagnosed to have carpal tunnel syndrome. He is a patient with chronic kidney disease who is on hemodialysis. This is caused due to deposition of which of the following ?
questions.solution:
Carpal tunnel syndrome secondary to hemodialysis in a patient with chronic kidney disease is due to the deposition of Aβ2 microglobulin

Aβ2 microglobulin is present in high concentrations in the serum of patients with renal disease. It is retained in circulation as it is not filtered through dialysis membranes. It gets deposited in the synovium, joints, and tendon sheaths. When this deposition takes place in the carpal ligament of the wrist it leads to the development of ‘carpal tunnel syndrome’.

questions.text: A preterm newborn delivered at 30 weeks of gestation does not cry at birth, despite stimulation. On further evaluation, the heart rate is 104 beats/min but laboured breathing is observed. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The next step in the management of a preterm neonate with a heart rate >100 beats/minute and laboured breathing, is oxygen supplementation via continuous positive airway pressure(CPAP). 
In preterms, due to deficiency of lung surfactants, there is a higher chance of alveolar collapse. CPAP increases pressure in the airway and keeps the alveoli open.
In term neonates, oxygen supplementation via nasal prongs or oxygen hood is recommended. Oxygen saturation should be regularly monitored and supplemental oxygen should be titrated to achieve the targeted saturations.
 
The response to neonatal resuscitation at various steps is assessed based on the heart rate.
  • If the baby is apneic, has gasping breathing or heart rate <100 beats/min, positive pressure ventilation (PPV) is provided with a bag and mask. SPO2 monitoring is done and adequate ventilation is ensured.
  • If the heart rate is <60 beats/min, then chest compressions are initiated over the lower third of the sternum at a rate of 90 compressions/min. The ratio of compressions to ventilation is 3:1.
  • IV epinephrine is given via the umbilical vein, if the heart rate still remains < 60 beats/min, despite effective compressions and ventilation.

questions.text:
The urine of the patient taking indapamide will have:
      Cl-    Urea    Mg2+     K+
    1.      ↑      ↓      ↓      ↑
    2.      ↓      ↑      ↓      ↑
    3.      ↑      ↓      ↑      ↑
    4.      ↑      ↓      ↑      ↓
questions.solution:
The correct option is option C i.e. the urine will have increased levels of chloride, magnesium, and potassium and decreased levels of urea. 

Indapamide is a thiazide diuretic that can cause increased loss of chloride, potassium, and magnesium and decreased excretion of urea in urine. Thus resulting in hypokalemia, hyperuricemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypercalcemia as adverse effects.

Thiazides act on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). They block the Na+/Cl- co-transporter in the DCT. This results in the loss of sodium, chloride, and water contributing to the diuretic effect.

The diuretic effect of thiazide leads to decreased osmotic pressure due to the loss of Na+, Cl-, and water leading to compensatory reabsorption of uric acid thus resulting in hyperuricemia.

The intracytoplasmic Na+ concentration also decreases due to the blockade of the co-transporter. To compensate, the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger pumps sodium from the systemic circulation into the epithelial cells in exchange for calcium. The declining calcium levels inside the cell will draw more calcium from the lumen into the systemic circulation. This results in hypercalcemia. There is also increased loss of Mg2+, K+, and H+.

Thiazides are the diuretic of choice for uncomplicated hypertension.

The advantages of thiazide as an antihypertensive are:

  • It can be given as once a day dose and has a flat dose-response curve
  • Decreased incidence of postural hypotension and relative freedom from CNS side effects
  • No tolerance
  • No fluid retention
  • Decreased risk of osteoporotic fractures due to its hypocalciuric action
  • Low cost
  • Effectiveness in isolated systolic hypertension

Thiazides are ineffective both as antihypertensive and diuretic in patients with chronic renal failure.

Osmotic diuretics ↑↑ ↑ ↑

Thiazides ↑ ↑↑ ↓

Acute effects of thiazides on Ca2+ excretion are variable but when administered chronically, it decreases Ca2+ excretion.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was found dead at home, who had a chronic history of swelling of both limbs and breathlessness. The gross pathological image of his liver is given below. What is the most likely cause of the appearance of the liver?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the nutmeg appearance of the liver, seen in heart failure.

Congestive hepatopathy, also known as chronic passive congestion of the liver, is liver dysfunction due to venous congestion; it usually occurs due to congestive heart failure. It can also occur due to isolated venous obstruction.

Left-sided cardiac failure leads to hypoperfusion and hypoxia of hepatocytes around central veins. The combination of hypoperfusion and retrograde congestion causes centrilobular hemorrhagic necrosis, leading to this mottled appearance of the liver, known as a nutmeg liver. Right-sided cardiac failure leads to passive congestion of the liver.

Nutmeg liver refers to the mottled appearance of the liver, resembling the cut section of nutmeg. This appearance occurs due to hepatic venous congestion following right heart failure. The dark centrilobular zones reflect sinusoidal congestion. Congestion is seen around the central veins, usually from right-sided heart failure. The pale periportal zones reflect normal or fatty liver tissue.

questions.text: A 2-week-old neonate presented with abdominal distension and hematochezia. On further evaluation, you diagnose this case as Necrotizing Enterocolitis and plan to take up this child for surgery. Which of the following features is an absolute indication for surgery in this child?
questions.solution:
In the given case of Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), the presence of pneumoperitoneum, as given in stage IIIB of Modified Bell Staging Criteria, is an absolute indication for surgery.

Modified Bell's Staging Criteria:

Stage   Intestinal signs Systemic signs Radiological signs Treatment
IA Suspected NEC Mild abdominal distention, emesis, guaiac-positive stool Temperature instability, apnea, bradycardia, lethargy Normal or intestinal dilatation, mild ileus NPO, Antibiotic for 3 days 
IB   IA + Bright red blood from the rectum Same as IA Same as IA Same as IA
IIA Mildly ill Absent bowel sounds Same as IA  Pneumatosis intestinalis, ileus NPO, Antibiotics for 7-10 days 
IIB Moderately ill  IIA + definite abdominal tenderness

IA+ Metabolic acidosis+ thrombocytopenia+hyponatremia 

  IIA + Pneumatosis portalis (portal venous gas), with or without ascites NPO, Antibiotics for 14 days 
IIIA Severely ill, bowel intact  IIB + peritonitis with marked tenderness, and definite ascites. IIB+ hypotension, bradycardia, acidosis, DIC, neutropenia  IIB + definite ascitis  NPO, Antibiotics for 14 days, fluid resuscitation +/- inotropes, ventilator, paracentesis
IIIB Severely ill, bowel
perforated		  Same as III A Same as IIIA   IIB +pneumoperitoneum Same as III A, surgery 

Necrotizing enterocolitis is the most common life-threatening emergency of the gastrointestinal tract in the newborn period. The disease is characterized by various degrees of mucosal or transmural necrosis of the intestine, mainly affecting the distal part of the ileum and the proximal segment of the colon.

The major risk factors involved are prematurity, bacterial colonization of the gut, and formula feeding. It usually presents within the 2nd or 3rd week of life with abdominal distension and tenderness, feed intolerance, and occult/gross blood in the stool.

The given x-ray shows pneumatosis intestinalis (black arrows) seen in stage IIA. It shows a characteristic train-track lucency appearance within the bowel wall due to the gas produced by bacteria.

Management of NEC includes supportive measures, nil per oral, nasogastric decompression, IV fluids, and broad-spectrum antibiotics. The only absolute indication for surgery is evidence of perforation on an abdominal radiograph (pneumoperitoneum). The options for surgical treatment include primary peritoneal drainage (PPD) or exploratory laparotomy with resection of the necrotic intestine.

The most effective preventive strategy is the use of human milk. Enterally fed probiotics are also found helpful.

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes a multilayered epithelium which can contract and expand in response to the degree of distension, without losing its integrity
questions.solution:
The multilayered epithelium which can contract and expand in response to the degree of distension, without losing its integrity is transitional epithelium.

It is also called urothelium as it is a specialized epithelium lining most of the urinary tract.

The epithelium appears to be 4–6 cells thick and lines organs that undergo considerable distension and contraction. It can therefore stretch greatly without losing its integrity. 

It extends from the collecting duct of the kidney to the ejaculatory duct in males and to the urogenital membrane in females. It is named transitional epithelium as it can apparently change from stratified cuboidal epithelium to stratified squamous epithelium. It has 3 distinctive layers as follows:

  • Basal layer is made of cuboidal cells which can regenerate.
  • Intermediate layer is made of polygonal cells responsible for the stretch of the organ by flattening of cells.
  • Superficial layer is made of umbrella-shaped multinucleated cells which are protective and impermeable.

Other options:

Option A: Stratified squamous epithelium is a multilayered epithelium, where the deepest layer is usually columnar, above which there are layers of cuboidal cells, and as it proceeds towards the surface of the epithelium the cells become increasingly flattened (or squamous).

It is further classified into keratinized and non-keratinized epithelium.

The given histological images show keratinized stratified squamous epithelium of the oral mucosa and the non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium of the esophagus.

Option B: Stratified columnar epithelium consists of two or more layers of columnar cells. The given histological image shows stratified cuboidal epithelium of salivary glands.

Option C: Pseudostratified columnar epithelium - comprises only a single layer of columnar cells but has its cell nuclei positioned at various levels in a manner falsely suggestive of stratified epithelia.

Given below is a histological image showing the pseudostratified columnar epithelium of the trachea.

Related Pearl: Various Types of Epithelium, Their Location and Functions

questions.text: The blood report of a patient shows increased uric acid levels. All of the following could be a possible underlying pathology except?
questions.solution:
Deficiency of xanthine oxidase causes hereditary xanthinuria. Xanthine oxidase catalyzes the conversion of hypoxanthine to xanthine and xanthine to uric acid. It is associated with hypouricemia and xanthine lithiasis.

Other options:

Option A: Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency, known as von Gierke's disease or glycogen storage disease type I, is characterized by severe fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hepatomegaly. In this case, glycogen is present in the liver but cannot be broken down efficiently into glucose.

Option B: Hereditary fructose intolerance occurs due to deficiency of the enzyme aldolase B. It is characterized by profound hypoglycemia and vomiting after consumption of fructose. Fructose-induced hypoglycemia occurs despite the presence of high glycogen reserves because fructose-1-phosphate allosterically inhibits liver glycogen phosphorylase. The sequestration of inorganic phosphate leads to depletion of ATP and hyperuricemia.

Option C: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder due to a complete deficiency of the HGPRT enzyme. This deficiency results in an inability to salvage hypoxanthine or guanine resulting in increased levels of phospho-ribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP) and decreased levels of inosine monophosphate (IMP) and guanosine monophosphate (GMP). This causes increased de novo purine synthesis and excessive amounts of uric acid. Patients present with self-mutilating behavior, delayed developmental milestones, positive family history, and hyperuricemia

questions.text: A 70-year-old female presents with fever and severe left-sided headache. She also gives a history of bilateral shoulder and neck pain over the past few months. On examination, there is left scalp tenderness. What is the ideal screening test and diagnosis?

choices.text: Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) - Giant cell arteritis

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a 70-year-old female (post-menopausal) with fever, severe unilateral headache, bilateral shoulder and neck pain (polymyalgia rheumatica) and scalp tenderness, is highly suggestive of giant cell arteritis which shows elevated ESR levels and hence used as an ideal screening test.

Giant cell arteritis (GCA), also known as temporal arteritis, is an inflammation of medium and large-sized vessels. It is more common in women and people aged >50 years.

The clinical features include headache, scalp pain and jaw claudication, fever and weight loss. Gentle pressure on the scalp may elicit focal or generalized tenderness. It is associated with polymyalgia rheumatica characterized by morning stiffness and pain around the shoulders and hip.

Lab reports reveal an elevated ESR level, hypo-/normo-chromic anaemia, elevated alkaline phosphatase levels, and increased levels of IgG and complement. The diagnosis can be confirmed by a temporal artery biopsy.

The mainstay of treatment in GCA is steroids. Prednisolone 40-60 mg is given for one month followed by tapering doses. The duration of treatment is approximately 2 years or more.

Other options:

Option B: Polymyositis presents with symmetric and proximal muscle weakness that worsens over several weeks to months. Creatine kinase levels are always elevated

Option C: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disorder that results in damage to multiple organs and organ systems in the body most commonly seen in women of reproductive age. It is associated with the presence of elevated antinuclear antibodies.

Option D: Migraine is the second most common cause of headaches and is seen more commonly in women and presents as an episodic headache associated with nausea and photosensitivity. It is not associated with polymyalgia rheumatica.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man complains of an irresistible urge to move his legs, and it interferes with his sleep. He drinks 2 glasses of wine a day and does not smoke. He takes propranolol for social anxiety disorder. What will be the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Alcohol cessation is the most appropriate management for this patient.

The given clinical condition is restless leg syndrome(RLS). Patients with this condition should be advised to make lifestyle modifications first, like alcohol and caffeine cessation, moderate exercise, and sleep hygiene. 

Restless leg syndrome(RLS) is a typical sensory-motor disorder that generally affects the legs during periods of rest and especially sleep. There is an irresistible urge to shake the legs associated with a burning sensation, itching, and cramps of legs. In idiopathic cases, dopaminergic hypofunction is postulated. 

Iron deficiency is closely associated with RLS, so serum ferritin should be checked for all patients who present with this condition. Uremia, folic acid deficiency, and neuropathies can also lead to RLS.

Management:

  • Lifestyle modifications should be advised first to patients, this includes:
    • alcohol cessation
    • caffeine cessation
    • Massaging the affected limbs
    • Hot baths
  • Medications are given to patients with intractable symptoms
    • Gabapentin
    • Dopaminergic agonists like ropinirole and pramipexole
    • Benzodiazepines 

Other options:

Option A: Ropinirole is useful in the management of RLS but should be started only if conservative management fails 

Option C: Riluzole is a benzothiazole derivative that is used in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. They inhibit glutaminergic transmission.

Option D: Propranolol is not associated with precipitating or relieving the symptoms of restless leg syndrome.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with features of hyperthyroidism. Her pregnancy test was positive and gestation age was 5 weeks. Which of the following is the most appropriate for the management of hyperthyroidism in this patient?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for the treatment of thyrotoxicosis during the first trimester of pregnancy is propylthiouracil (PTU). It is because it has lower teratogenic effects than carbimazole or methimazole.

Methimazole is associated with teratogenic effects collectively called methimazole embryopathy which include upward-slanted palpebral fissures, arched flared eyebrows, and a small nose with a broad bridge. Choanal atresia, esophageal atresia, and aplasia cutis can be seen. However, propylthiouracil use is limited to the first trimester due to the risk of liver failure. It is replaced with carbimazole or methimazole in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters of the pregnancy.

Propylthiouracil is an anti-thyroid drug that inhibits the coupling and iodination of thyroid hormones decreasing the production of the hormones. It also has the additional property of inhibiting the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.

The most serious adverse effect of propylthiouracil is agranulocytosis. Agranulocytosis usually occurs in the initial weeks or months of therapy. It occurs rapidly and hence periodic monitoring of granulocyte levels is generally ineffective. However, it is reversible on discontinuation of the drug. Therefore, patients who are on these drugs should be instructed to report immediately if they develop a fever or sore throat. They can be treated with recombinant human granulocyte colony-stimulating factors. Other side effects include mild urticarial papular rash, joint pain, headache, nausea, skin pigmentation, and loss of hair. 

Note: Radioiodine therapy is contraindicated during pregnancy and lactation.

questions.text: The manufacturer of a drug company labels a drug as ondansetron. However, on analysis it actually contained paracetamol. What is the terminology used to describe this scenario?
questions.solution:
The term spurious is used to describe the drug that has been substituted wholly or in part by another drug or substance.

A drug is considered spurious if it fulfills the following conditions:

  • If the drug is imported under a name that belongs to another drug (or)
  • If the drug is an imitation of another drug with the intent to deceive (or)
  • If the label depicts a manufacturer that is either fictitious or a real company with no ties to the product (or)
  • If it has been substituted wholly or in part by another drug or substance.

Other options:

Option A: An adulterated drug is a drug that contains filthy or decomposed substances, substances that are injurious to health, or if the drug contains harmful substances to reduce the quality or strength of the drug. It also includes drugs that are prepared in unsanitary conditions.

Option B: The term unethical drug is not standard terminology in pharmacology. However, the term ethical drug is sometimes used to describe those drugs that are available only by prescription of a medical practitioner.

Option C: A drug shall be deemed to be misbranded if - 

  • It is made to appear of better or greater therapeutic value than it really is
  • It is not labeled in the prescribed manner
  • Its label or container or anything accompanying the drug bears any false claim for the drug

questions.text: A physiologist is studying the action potential of the sinoatrial node plotted in the graph given below. Which of the following ion channels do not contribute to phase 4 in the graph given below?
questions.solution:
L-type calcium channels do not contribute to phase 4 of the action potential of the SA node.

The graph in the given image represents the action potential of the SA (sinoatrial) node (i.e., the pacemaker potential). In the figure, phase 4 corresponds to the prepotential. During prepotential the ongoing K+ efflux results in hyperpolarization(Option D). This makes the channel more permeable to Na+ ions and since these Na+ channels are activated during hyperpolarization they are referred to as funny currents (Ih/ If)(Option A). They form the first half of the pre-potential. The second half of the prepotential is completed by the opening of the voltage-gated T-(transient) type Ca2+ channel (Option C). The slope of Phase 4 in the SA node determines the heart rate.

The resting membrane potential (RMP) of the SA node is -55 to -60 millivolts. Phases of this potential are: 

  • Phase 0 - Upstroke wave. It is due to the influx of Ca2+ ions by the opening of voltage-gated L-type channels.
  • Phase 3 - Downstroke wave. It is due to the efflux of K+ leading to repolarization.
  • Phase 4- Prepotential. Because of ongoing K+ efflux, hyperpolarization sets in. This makes the channel more permeable to Na+ ions and since these Na+ channels are activated during hyperpolarization they are referred to as funny currents (Ih/ If). They form the first half of the pre-potential. The second half of the prepotential is completed by the opening of the voltage-gated T-(transient) type Ca2+ channel. The slope of Phase 4 in the SA node determines the heart rate.

Clinical aspect:

i) Vagal stimulation activates the cholinergic fibres to the SAN and leads to a decreased slope of phase 4. This occurs by depolarizing effect of funny Na+ (If) channel on M2 receptor stimulation. There is also decreased cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) causing the decreased firing of the T-type Ca2+ channel. Similar action is seen upon administering digitalis. 

ii) The frequency of SA node discharge is increased when the temperature rises. Thus, fever is usually associated with tachycardia.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl was brought to the OPD by her mother, who was concerned that her daughter was shorter than her classmates. On examination, you notice that the girl has a webbed neck, shield-shaped chest and low posterior hairline. Suspecting a genetic disorder, you get a chest X-ray done. Which of the following signs will be seen on the X-ray?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the symptoms of short stature, webbed neck, shield-shaped chest and low posterior hairline in the 10-year-old girl are highly suggestive of Turner's syndrome. The cardiovascular lesion associated with Turner's syndrome is coarctation of the aorta which shows the figure 3 sign on X-ray.

Figure 3 sign is pathognomonic of coarctation of the aorta and occurs due to indentation of the aorta at the site of coarctation and pre and post-stenotic dilatation along the left paramediastinum. 

Coarctation of aorta is a congenital heart defect characterized by the narrowing of the thoracic aorta near the insertion of the ductus arteriosus. It is associated with the bicuspid aortic valve, atrial septal defect, ventricular septal defect, mitral regurgitation and Turner syndrome. It is more common in males.

On barium swallow, the reverse figure 3 sign (also known as the E sign) is seen as the medial equivalent of the figure 3 sign seen on chest X-ray. It is formed by prestenotic dilatation of the ascending aorta, indentation of the coarctation site and post-stenotic dilatation of the descending aorta.

Notching of ribs (Roesler's sign) due to inferior rib erosion by dilated intercostal collateral vessels, is also seen in coarctation of aorta.

Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder that occurs due to complete or partial monosomy of X-chromosomes (45 XO)- O for the absent X chromosome. Clinical features include short stature, short webbed neck, shield chest with widely spaced nipples, congenital heart defects, and renal anomalies.

Two X chromosomes are required for the development of ovaries and the loss of one X chromosome results in streak ovaries with inadequate estrogen production. The loss of negative feedback from reduced estrogen raises the FSH and LH levels causing hypergonadotropic hypogonadism. 

Other options:

Option A: Egg-on-string sign is a characteristic X-ray finding seen in transposition of great arteries (TGA). It refers to a globular-shaped heart due to an abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement, and therefore appears like an egg.

Option C: Snowman's heart is seen in total anomalous pulmonary venous return. It refers to the configuration of the heart and the superior mediastinal borders resembling a snowman. It is also referred to as the figure of 8 sign.

Option D: Gooseneck sign is seen on left lateral angiograms in endocardial cushion defect. It is the most common cardiovascular lesion in Down’s syndrome.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male diagnosed with parkinsonism and on treatment presented with the finding as seen in the image below.  Which of the following drugs is most likely implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows livedo reticularis and it is a side effect of amantadine.

Amantadine:

Amantadine inhibits the NMDA receptors(glutaminergic receptors) thereby mediating an anti-dyskinetic effect. It also blocks presynaptic dopamine reuptake, facilitates dopamine release, postsynaptic dopamine agonism, and/or dopamine receptor modulation. It also has an anti-viral effect by interfering with the function of the M2 protein and inhibiting viral replication.

 It is used in the treatment of influenza. Amantadine can be used in milder cases of parkinsonism or as a supplement to levodopa for advanced cases. It is also used in the management of levodopa-induced dyskinesia.

Adverse effects include restlessness, depression, irritability, insomnia, agitation, excitement, hallucinations, confusion, headache, heart failure, postural hypotension, urinary retention, and gastrointestinal disturbances like anorexia, nausea, constipation, and dry mouth. Livedo reticularis and peripheral edema can be seen in some cases.

Other options:

Option A: Apomorphine is a dopamine receptor agonist used in 'off' episodes of levodopa therapy.

Option B: Entacapone is a catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) inhibitor that decreases levodopa metabolism and prolongs its action.

Option D: Selegiline is an irreversible monoamine oxidase-B (MAO) inhibitor.

questions.text: The following image shows a type of cell signaling pathway. Which of the following hormones act through this pathway?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the JAK-STAT signaling pathway, which is associated with tyrosine kinase receptors. Insulin acts through this signaling pathway.

Hormones that use receptor tyrosine kinase/ JAK-STAT signaling include

  • Growth hormone
  • Fibroblast growth factor
  • Hepatocyte growth factor
  • Insulin
  • Insulin-like growth factor-1
  • Leptin
  • Prolactin
  • Vascular endothelial growth factor

Other options

Option B: Thyroxine acts through nuclear receptors.

Option C: Cortisol (Glucocorticoids) acts through cytoplasmic receptors.

Option D: Glucagon acts through Gs type of G-protein coupled receptor.

questions.text: A middle-aged man who previously presented with foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge and crusting was diagnosed with atrophic rhinitis. He now presents with a woody hard nasal swelling and multiple granulomatous nodules in the nasal mucosa. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is suggestive of rhinoscleroma, as the patient had a history of foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge and crusting before the development of a woody hard nasal swelling and multiple granulomatous nodules in the nasal mucosa, which corresponds to the atrophic stage of rhinoscleroma.

The diagnosis can be confirmed by biopsy showing two characteristic findings- Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies. 

Mikulicz cells (small arrow) are large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing causative bacilli. Russell bodies are homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies found in the plasma cells. They occur due to the accumulation of immunoglobulins secreted by the plasma cells.

Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus).

It has 3 stages:

  • Atrophic stage– Crusting and foul-smelling nasal discharge similar to atrophic rhinitis.
  • Granulomatous stage– Painless, non-ulcerative granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving the feel of woody/hebra nose.
  • Cicatricial stage– Fibrosis leading to stenosis of vestibule, pharynx, larynx. The deformity is called tapir nose.

Other options:

Option A: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass. The biopsy shows several oval or round-shaped sporangia filled with spores bursting through the chitinous walls.

Option B: Wegener's granulomatosis is a chronic granulomatous disorder presenting with crusting, granulation and saddle nose deformity. Biopsy shows necrosis and ulceration of mucosa, epithelioid granuloma and necrotizing vasculitis of the vessels.

Option C: Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis involving the skin and mucosa. It presents with ulcerated nodules or plaques and a characteristic apple-jelly appearance on diascopy, not woody nasal swelling or granulomas.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient is found on rectal examination to have a hard, irregular nodule within his prostate. A biopsy of this lesion reveals the presence of crowded small glands lined by a single layer of cells with enlarged, prominent nucleoli. Immunohistochemistry shows the absence of the outer basal cell layer. From what portion of the prostate did this lesion most likely originate?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, palpation of hard, irregular nodules within the prostate with immunohistochemistry revealing the absence of an outer basal layer is suggestive of carcinoma prostate and most prostatic carcinomas arise from the peripheral zone.

Carcinoma of the prostate is the most common form of cancer affecting men. It arises in the peripheral zone of the gland, classically in a posterior location. 

The growth and survival of prostate cancer cells depend on androgens, which bind to the androgen receptor (AR) and induce the expression of pro-growth and pro-survival genes. Germline mutations of the tumor suppressor BRCA2 increase the risk of prostate cancer. Other acquired mutations include TPRSS2-ETS fusion genes. Prostatic Intraepithelial Neoplasia(PIN) has been described as the precursor lesion of carcinoma prostate.

On palpation, it is gritty, and firm in consistency. Histologically, most lesions are adenocarcinomas that shows small crowded glands lined by a single layer of neoplastic cells with mild to moderate degree of pleomorphism. The outer basal cell layer is absent. Immunohistochemically, basal cell markers are absent and α-methyl acyl-coenzyme A-racemase (AMACR) positive.

Grading of prostate cancer by the modified Gleason system correlates with pathologic stage and prognosis.

Grade Group 1 (≤6)

 Only individual discrete well-formed glands

Grade Group 2 (3 + 4)

Predominantly well-formed glands with a lesser component of poorly formed, fused, or cribriform glands

Grade Group 3 (4 + 3)

 Predominantly poorly formed/fused/cribriform glands with a lesser component of well-formed glands

Grade Group 4 (4+4/3+5/5+3)

Only poorly formed/fused/cribriform glands or predominantly mix of well-formed glands and lack of glands

Grade Group 5 (4+5/5+4/5+5)

 Lack of gland formation (or with necrosis) with or without poorly formed/fused/cribriform glands
