questions.text: A 45-year-old man with colorectal carcinoma was diagnosed to be a case of Lynch syndrome. He wants to know about screening for his 15-year-old daughter. Which of the following is not a part of the screening guidelines?

choices.text: Upper endoscopy every 2 years starting at age 20
Colonoscopy is repeated every 1-2 years until the age of 35 years
Annual urine analysis starting at 25-30 years
Colonoscopy is repeated annually after the age of 35 years

questions.solution:
The management of patients with Lynch syndrome needs close surveillance of patients known to carry the mutation. Out of the recommendations given above, endoscopy starting at age 20 is incorrect. Endoscopy should be started at the age of 40 every 3-5 years.

Hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)/ (Lynch syndrome) is characterized by an increased risk of colorectal cancer and also cancers of the endometrium, ovary, stomach and small intestine. It is an autosomal dominant condition caused by a mutation in one of the DNA mismatch repair genes. The most commonly affected genes are MLH1 and MSH2.

Screening

  • It is usually recommended that a program of surveillance colonoscopy begin at the age of 20 years.
  • Colonoscopy is repeated every 2 years until the age of 35 years and then annually thereafter.
  • In women, periodic vacuum curettage is begun at age 25 years, as are pelvic ultrasound and determination of CA-125 levels.
  • Annual tests for occult blood in the urine should also be carried out because of the risk for ureteral and renal pelvic cancer.
  • Upper endoscopy at time of colonoscopy with visualization of duodenum every 3-5 years starting at the age of 40. 

Management

  • When colon cancer is detected in a patient with Lynch syndrome, an abdominal colectomy–ileorectal anastomosis is the procedure of choice.
  • If the patient is a woman with no further plans for childbearing, a prophylactic total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy are recommended.
  • The rectum remains at risk for the development of cancer, and annual proctoscopic examinations are mandatory after abdominal colectomy.

Related Pearl: Amsterdam Criteria II - Revised Criteria for HNPCC

The diagnostic criteria for HNPCC are referred to as the Amsterdam criteria or the 3-2-1-0 rule.

It includes the following:

  • Three or more relatives with HNPCC-associated cancer (colorectal cancer, endometrial cancer, cancer of the small bowel, ureter, or renal pelvis), one of whom is a first-degree relative of the other two
  • At least two successive generations affected
  • At least one case diagnosed before the age of 50 years
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis excluded.
  • Tumors verified by pathologic examination.

All of the above must be applicable for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC to be made in a family.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male, who is a known case of alcoholic liver disease, presents with reduced urine output. On ultrasonography, both kidneys appear normal and you suspect hepatorenal syndrome in this patient. A progressive rise in which of the following blood parameters is considered most appropriate while making this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hepatorenal syndrome is characterized by a progressive rise in serum creatinine in a patient who has established acute or chronic liver disease.
 
Hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) is a form of functional renal failure without any renal pathology that occurs in some patients with advanced cirrhosis or acute liver failure. The pathophysiological hallmark is severe renal vasoconstriction.
 
Clinical presentation includes:
  • A progressive rise in serum creatinine
  • Nonoliguria or oliguria depending upon the severity and duration
  • No or minimal proteinuria (less than 500 mg per day)
  • A very low rate of sodium excretion.

The diagnosis of HRS is one of exclusion and depends mainly on the serum creatinine level, as no specific tests establish the diagnosis of HRS. 

There are two types of HRS:
  • Type 1 HRS: There is progressive impairment in renal function and a marked decline in creatinine clearance within 1–2 weeks of presentation.
  • Type 2 HRS: There is a drop in glomerular filtration rate with elevated creatinine levels. It has a better prognosis than type 1 HRS.

Ultrasound of the kidney shows normal study and hyaline casts may be observed, indicating prerenal failure.

Management:

  • Stop diuretics
  • Albumin infusion at 1g/kg/day
  • Medical management:
    • Vasopressin analogs- terlipressin
    • Somatostatin analogs- octreotide
    • Alpha-adrenergic agonists- midodrine, noradrenaline
  • Definitive treatment: Liver transplantation 

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: All of the following are true about macula densa except:

choices.text: It causes afferent arteriolar constriction in response to increases Na+ concentration
It functions as a chemoreceptor for K+
It is located at the end of the thick ascending limb of Henle and at the beginning of the distal tubule

questions.solution:
Macula densa serves as a chemoreceptor for Na+, not K+

At the end of the thick ascending limb of Henle, and at the beginning of the distal tubule, the tubular epithelial cells are specialized to form the macula densa. They detect the sodium concentration of the fluid in the tubule (chemoreceptor). Though changes in K+ also seems to have an effect on renin levels, even that seems to be mediated via Na+.  

In response to elevated sodium, the macula densa cells trigger the contraction of the afferent arteriole, reducing the flow of blood to the glomerulus and the glomerular filtration rate. This happens as follows: When there is increased sodium, there is increased sodium-potassium ATPase activity which leads to increased ATP hydrolysis causing more adenosine formation. The adenosine receptors on the macula densa cells stimulate it to release more calcium, so that there is vasoconstriction of the afferent arteriole, thereby decreasing the GFR.

Macula densa secretes PGE2 along with RMICs(Renal Medullary Interstitial Cells) and cells in the collecting ducts.

Apart from macula densa, the juxtaglomerular apparatus contains

  • Lacis cells: Extraglomerular mesangial cells situated between afferent and efferent arteriole.
  • Granular cells/JG cells: Modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole, they secrete renin. Fall in pressure in afferent arteriole stimulates renin release (mechanoreceptor), which, in turn, increases blood pressure.

Related Pearl: Factors that affect renin secretion

Stimulatory

  • Increased sympathetic activity via renal nerves
  • Increased circulating catecholamines
  • Prostaglandins
  • Na+ depletion
  • Diuretics
  • Upright posture
  • Hemorrhage
  • Hypotension
  • Dehydration
  • Cardiac failure
  • Cirrhosis
  • Constriction of the renal artery or aorta
  • Various psychological stimuli

Inhibitory

  • Increased Na+ and Cl- reabsorption across macula densa
  • Increased afferent arteriolar pressure
  • Angiotensin II
  • ADH (vasopressin)

questions.text: A 68-year-old man visits your outpatient clinic for a routine follow-up. Which of the following protocols would you use to assess his health literacy?
questions.solution:
The SPEAK protocol is used to assess health literacy in the geriatric population in a clinical setting.

Health literacy is defined as the degree to which individuals have the capacity to obtain, process, and understand basic health information needed to make appropriate health decisions. The SPEAK protocol provides a simple framework that healthcare providers can use to assess literacy. SPEAK stands for:

  • S - Speech
  • P - Perception
  • E - Education
  • A - Access
  • K - Knowledge

Option A: The GATHER approach is mainly used for counseling (usually, family planning and reproductive counseling) to help people make decisions about health. It stands for:

  • G – Greet
  • A – Ask
  • T – Tell 
  • H – Help 
  • E – Explain 
  • R – Return 

Option C: The SPIKES protocol is used to convey distressing information and break bad news in an organized manner to patients and families. It stands for:

  • S - Setting
  • P - Perception
  • I - Invitation or information
  • K - Knowledge
  • E - Empathy
  • S - Summarizing or strategizing.

Option D: The S-BAR technique is used for prompt and appropriate communication among health care workers in hospital settings. It stands for:

  • S - Situation
  • B - Background
  • A - Assessment
  • R - Recommendation

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida with a history of gestational diabetes was admitted to the labor room at her 38th week of gestation. Just prior to the crowning of the head, a mediolateral episiotomy was performed after administering local anesthesia. Which among the following methods is ineffective in providing analgesia for episiotomy?

choices.text: Local infiltration of the fourchette, perineum and vagina

questions.solution:
The paracervical block is ineffective in providing analgesia for episiotomy.  

Analgesia can be provided by bilateral pudendal nerve block or local infiltration of 1% lidocaine into the fourchette, perineum, and vagina. 2.5% lidocaine-prilocaine cream (EMLA cream) can also be used if applied 1 hour before expected delivery. Pain with vaginal delivery arises from stimuli from the lower genital tract which are transmitted mainly through the pudendal nerve.

Episiotomy refers to a surgically planned incision on the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labor, at the time of crowning. In mediolateral episiotomy, the incision is made downwards and outwards from the midpoint of the fourchette either to the right or to the left.

The other types of episiotomy include median (midline), lateral, and J-shaped episiotomy.

Structures cut : 

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles
  • Bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering these muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

 

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: Which of the following can be estimated using Horrock’s apparatus?

choices.text: Both free and combined chlorine levels

questions.solution:
The Horrock’s apparatus is used to determine the chlorine demand of water.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who underwent renal transplantation a year ago presents to the outpatient department with complaints of fever with chills, headache, confusion, and vomiting. On cerebrospinal fluid microscopy, gram-positive rods with tumbling motility at 25°C are observed. Which is the most likely mode of transmission of this pathogen?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an immunosuppressed adult with symptoms suggestive of meningitis, and an organism showing tumbling motility at 25°C points to a diagnosis of Listeria monocytogenes. The most likely mode of transmission of Listeria monocytogenes is through the ingestion of contaminated food such as cheese, fruits, or vegetables.

Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive bacillus that shows characteristic tumbling motility at 25°C and becomes non-motile at 37°C. The image below shows the tumbling motility of Listeria.

Listeria can overcome the food preservation process since it grows at 4°C, with low pH, and high salt concentration. 

It has cell wall surface proteins called internalin A and B that interact with E-cadherin, a receptor on epithelial cells, promoting phagocytosis into the epithelial cells. The virulence factor produced by Listeria is called listeriolysin O. This helps the bacteria to escape and cause septicemia. They are catalase-positive and show beta hemolysis. This helps to differentiate Listeria from other gram-positive bacilli.

Listeriosis can present as gastroenteritis in healthy adults. It usually develops within 48 hours of ingestion of a large inoculum in contaminated food. It can also lead to the formation of an abscess, pharyngitis, pneumonia, and endocarditis. It leads to neonatal meningitis and sepsis, and meningoencephalitis in the elderly and immunocompromised people. Listeriosis in pregnancy can lead to abortion and stillbirth.

Most laboratories do not routinely culture Listeria from stool samples. The diagnosis of systemic listeriosis rests on the isolation of the organism in cultures of blood and spinal fluid.

Ampicillin plus gentamicin is often recommended for therapy. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is the drug of choice for central nervous system infections in patients who are allergic to penicillin. 

Other options:

Option A- Respiratory droplets are the mode of transmission for pathogens including Neisseria meningitides, respiratory syncytial virus, etc.

Option B- Needlestick injury is the mode of transmission for pathogens including Hepatitis B, HIV, etc.

Option D- Arthropod bite is the mode of transmission of various pathogens including dengue virus, yellow fever virus, etc.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presented with swelling in the upper eyelid, which had gradually increased in size over the last 6 months. On palpation, the swelling is hard and non-tender. After further evaluation, you prepare the patient for a minor procedure and assemble the following instruments on the tray. What type of incision will be given during this procedure?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, symptoms of gradually increasing, painless swelling in the upper eyelid and a hard, non-tender mass on palpation point towards the diagnosis of chalazion. This can be confirmed by the presence of a chalazion clamp(8) and chalazion scoop(2-5) in the given image which are used as part of a procedure called incision and curettage, where a vertical incision is given.

lncision and curettage is the conventional and effective treatment for chalazion. The incision is made with a sharp blade, which should be vertical on the conjunctiva side to avoid injury to other meibomian ducts. Contents are curetted out with the help of a chalazion scoop.

A chalazion clamp is used to fix the chalazion and achieve haemostasis during the procedure.

A chalazion is a sterile chronic lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland due to retained sebaceous secretion. It is also called a tarsal or meibomian cyst. They are seen more commonly in the upper eyelid than the lower eyelid because the upper eyelid has more meibomian glands. Histopathology shows a lipogranulomatous picture with extracellular fat deposits surrounded by lipid-laden epithelioid cells.

A recurrent chalazion should be biopsied to exclude malignant transformation. In elderly patients, malignant transformation to meibomian gland adenocarcinoma can occur occasionally. 

Conservative treatment includes hot fomentation, topical antibiotic eye drops and oral anti-inflammatory drugs. Intralestional injection of long-acting steroid (triamcinolone) is reported to cause resolution in about 50% of cases.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with miosis, ptosis, and anhydrosis on the left side along with dysphagia, and dysarthria, and frequently falls towards the left side on walking. On examination, he was found to have a loss of pain and temperature sensation on the right side of the body and the left side of the face. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient having left-sided Horner's syndrome, dysphagia, dysarthria, ataxia towards left and right-sided loss of pain and temperature is left-sided Wallenberg’s syndrome.

Wallenberg’s syndrome, otherwise known as the lateral medullary syndrome, is a type of ischemic stroke of the brainstem. The symptoms and the corresponding tracts affected are shown below: 

Tract affected Symptoms
Descending tract and nucleus of CN V  Ipsilateral impaired sensation over half of the face
IX and X CN Ipsilateral paralysis of palate, vocal cord(dysarthria), diminished gag reflex causing dysphagia
The nucleus of tractus solitarius Ipsilateral loss of taste
Vestibular nucleus   Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
Spinocerebellar tract Ipsilateral ataxia
Descending sympathetic tract Ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (characterized by miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis (decreased sweating)
Lateral spinothalamic tract  Impaired pain and temperature sensation over the contralateral half of the body

It can be caused by occlusion of vessels like the vertebral artery, posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), Superior, middle, or inferior lateral medullary arteries. The most commonly involved are the vertebral artery and PICA.

Other options:

Dejerine syndrome is otherwise known as medial medullary syndrome. It occurs due to occlusion of the vertebral artery or its branch. There is paralysis of the ipsilateral tongue (face is spared) and contralateral limbs, as well as impaired tactile and proprioceptive sense of the contralateral half of the body.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with dull pelvic pain and burning micturition for 1 year. On per rectal exam, he has mild pain on palpating the prostate. Which is best suited to obtain a culture sample for his condition?

choices.text: Sample obtained after a prostate massage

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of chronic pelvic pain with burning micturition lasting more than a year makes chronic prostatitis the likely diagnosis. In order to obtain an adequate sample for this, a prostate massage is done to elicit prostatic secretions (or threads)which are sent for culture to clinch the diagnosis.

Chronic bacterial prostatitis occurs when either acute infections were not treated adequately or if the patient has had repeated episodes of acute prostatitis.

Clinically, patients present with prostatodynia and dysuria. They can also have sexual dysfunction.

Diagnosis of chronic bacterial prostatitis is done via the 3-tube test. 

  • First voided(10ml) is taken in a test tube. This comes from the urethra.
  • Then midstream sample is taken from the bladder and in the test tube. 
  • Then a prostatic massage is done which gives rise to prostate secretions or threads in the first voided sample post-massage. 
  • These threads are sent for culture.

Treatment:

Antibiotics like ciprofloxacin for 4-6 weeks. 

If the causative organism is chlamydia use doxycycline, if it is trichomonas, use metronidazole.

questions.text: A patient presented to dermatology OPD with hyperpigmentation on the back as shown below. No other significant history is present. What is the management of the given condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows blue-grayish hyperpigmentation in the acromioclavicular region which is highly suggestive of Nevus of Ito and the treatment of choice is a pigment-targeting Q‐switched laser. 

Nevus of Ito is unilateral blue-grayish hyperpigmentation in the acromioclavicular region and upper chest. It is usually present in the area innervated by the posterior supraclavicular and lateral cutaneous brachial nerves. It is a benign lesion and is also known as nevus fuscoceruleus acromiodeltoideus.

Histopathology shows a large number of elongated dendritic melanocytes scattered among collagen bundles in the superficial dermis with extension into the dermis or subcutaneous tissue at times.

Pigment targeting Q‐switched laser systems is the treatment of choice.

Other options

Option A: CO2 laser is used in various conditions like moles, viral warts, rhinophyma, acne scarring, keloid, hypertrophic scar, etc.

Option B: KTP laser is used in vascular malformations like telangiectasia and angioma, melasma, lentigos, freckles, etc.

Option D: Argon laser is used in actinic keratosis and basal cell carcinoma (BCC).

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts by causing irreversible inhibition of the initiation complex through binding of the 30S ribosomal subunit?
questions.solution:
Aminoglycosides like gentamicin act by causing irreversible inhibition of the initiation complex through binding of the 30S ribosomal subunit. They cause misreading and premature termination of mRNA translation. 

Aminoglycosides include streptomycin, gentamicin, tobramycin, amikacin, and kanamycin. They are bactericidal and the killing is concentration-dependent.

They are used in the treatment of aerobic gram-negative bacterial infections such as urinary tract infections, mycobacterial infections, tularemia, respiratory infections in cystic fibrosis, and other pseudomonal infections. Anaerobic bacteria are intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides because the transport of aminoglycosides across the cytoplasmic membrane requires oxygen.  

The adverse effects of aminoglycosides include-

  • Ototoxicity is characterized by irreversible high-frequency hearing loss and vestibular dysfunction. Streptomycin and gentamicin are the most vestibulotoxic. Amikacin, kanamycin, and neomycin mainly affect auditory functions. 
  • Nephrotoxicity due to damage to proximal tubular cells. Neomycin is the most nephrotoxic. Streptomycin is the least nephrotoxic.
  • Acute neuromuscular blockade and apnea. Neuromuscular blockade may be reversed by intravenous administration of a Ca2+ salt. 

Other options

Options A and B- Chloramphenicol and clindamycin act by binding to the 50S subunit of the ribosome.

Option D- Vancomycin is a glycopeptide that inhibits cell wall synthesis. It binds to terminal dipeptide D-Ala-D-Ala of peptidoglycan to inhibit cell wall synthesis.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman came with complaints of headache and nasal discharge since 1 week. She describes the headache to be present as soon as she wakes up, gradually increasing until midday, and then starting to subside. What is the site of drainage of the structure affected in the above case?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the duration of symptoms and the characteristic pattern of headache described are highly suggestive of acute frontal sinusitis, caused by inflammation in frontal sinus cavities, which drain into the middle meatus of the nose.

It is most often associated with an antecedent viral upper respiratory tract infection followed later by bacterial invasion. 

Patients present with frontal headache with characteristic periodicity i.e. present on waking up, gradually increases and reaches its peak by about midday and then starts subsiding. It is also called “office headache” because of its presence only during office hours.

Treatment: Medical - Antimicrobials, decongestion of the sinus ostium and a combination of antihistaminic with oral nasal decongestant (phenylephrine hydrochloride).  Surgical- Trephination of the frontal sinus.

Paranasal sinuses are air-containing cavities that are present in the skull bones. These paranasal sinuses have been divided into two groups:

Anterior group: Their ostia drain into the middle meatus through a common drainage pathway known as osteomeatal unit. This group includes:

  • Maxillary sinus (antrum of Highmore)
  • Frontal sinus
  • Anterior ethmoidal sinus

Posterior group: 

  • Posterior ethmoidal sinuses: Opens in the superior meatus (option A)
  • Sphenoid sinus: Opens in sphenoethmoidal recess (option B)

The inferior meatus (option C) has the nasolacrimal duct draining into it with its terminal end being guarded by the Hasner's valve.

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with history of scorpion bite. On examination, there was hypertension, tachypnea, and tachycardia. He was administered prazosin. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Prazosin is a selective α1 blocker.

Prazosin is a selective alpha-1 antagonist. It acts by blocking the alpha-1 receptors in the arterioles and veins, thereby decreasing peripheral vascular resistance and venous return to the heart. It has little or no alpha-2 blocking effect.

It is highly bound to plasma proteins, metabolized in the liver, and excreted primarily in bile. Its duration of action lasts about 6-7 hours in the treatment of hypertension. It is used in the treatment of Raynaud's disease, hypertension, congestive heart failure, and benign prostatic hyperplasia.

Adverse effects include first-dose phenomenon: Within 30-90 minutes of the initial dose of prazosin or when the dosage is increased, there is marked orthostatic hypotension or syncope. This is known as the first-dose phenomenon. After a few initial doses, tolerance develops to this side effect. Initiating low doses at bedtime is recommended to minimize this phenomenon. Orthostatic hypotension can be a problem with long-term therapy. Other side effects are headache, dizziness, and asthenia.

Related Pearl: Drugs acting on the receptors of autonomic nervous system

questions.text: A researcher is studying the calculation for total body water and its distribution into intracellular compartments. Which combination of dyes can she use to measure this?
questions.solution:
Intracellular fluid(ICF) volume can be measured using a combination of inulin and tritium.

Total body fluid (TBW) is distributed between extracellular fluid (ECF) and intracellular fluid (ICF). Extracellular fluid (ECF) can be divided into interstitial fluid and blood plasma. ICF is measured indirectly. 

Intracellular fluid (ICF) = Total body water (TBW) - extracellular fluid (ECF)

Radioactive sodium, radioactive chloride, radioactive iothalamate, thiosulfate ion, and inulin can be used to measure ECF volume. Tritium and deuterium can be used to measure TBW.

  • In ECF, a third specialized compartment, called the transcellular compartment (not shown in flow chart), is quantitatively small and includes the cerebrospinal, pleural, peritoneal, pericardial, synovial, intraocular and digestive fluids. Altogether it constitutes about 1-2 L.
  • The ECF volume/intracellular fluid volume ratio is larger in infants and children than it is in adults, but the absolute volume of ECF in children is, of course, smaller than in adults. Therefore, dehydration develops more rapidly and is frequently more severe in children.
  • All solutes and water that enter or leave the body do so via the ECF.
  • The ICF and ECF are in osmotic equilibrium. Water moves between these compartments only when an osmotic pressure gradient exists.
  • Equilibration of ICF and ECF osmolality occurs primarily by shifts in water and not shifts in solutes.

questions.text: A patient underwent a surgical resection of a part of his brain to treat seizures. Following the surgery, he suffered from anterograde amnesia and was unable to form new long-term memories but could learn new puzzles. He has normal procedural memory. Which portion of his brain was surgically removed?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient had anterograde amnesia and was unable to form new long-term memories post-surgery. The hippocampus is most likely removed in this patient as it converts short-term memories to long-term memories.

Other options

The neocortex, the amygdala, and the striatum are associated with implicit (procedural) memory, which is intact in this patient.

Related Pearl: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

questions.text: A 24-year-old lady, with a past history of pulmonary tuberculosis, presents to the OPD with complaints of infertility. After further evaluation, you diagnose her with genital tuberculosis. The most common structure involved in this condition is derived from which of the following?
questions.solution:
The most common structure involved in genital tuberculosis are the fallopian tubes which develop from the Mullerian ducts (paramesonephric ducts).

Three parts can be recognized in each paramesonephric duct: (1) a cranial vertical portion that opens into the abdominal cavity, (2) a horizontal part that crosses the mesonephric duct, and (3) a caudal vertical part that fuses with its partner from the opposite side.

With the descent of the ovary, the first two parts develop into the fallopian tube, and the caudal parts fuse to form the uterine canal.

The upper vaginal wall, uterus and cervix also develop from the Mullerian ducts.

Derivatives of the urogenital sinus:

  • Lower vagina
  • Skene’s tubercles
  • Bartholin’s gland
  • Urinary bladder 
  • Urethra

questions.text: You are declaring a patient brain dead by using Harvard criteria. All of the following parameters are checked for, except:
questions.solution:
Isoelectric EEG is included in Harvard criteria for brain death and not ECG.

Harvard criteria for brain death include:

  • Unreceptivity and unresponsiveness
  • No movements
  • Apnoea
  • Absence of elicitable reflexes
  • Isoelectric EEG (confirmatory)

All these tests should be recorded. If there is no change after 24 hours, then the patient is declared brain dead.

Philadelphia protocol, Minnesota criteria are other criteria used to diagnose brain death.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl was brought to the OPD with complaints of development of pubic and axillary hair and a sudden growth spurt. On examination, she has Tanner stage 2 breast development. USG revealed a right-sided adnexal mass. The patient underwent laparotomy to remove the tumor and the biopsy from the tumor showed characteristic Call-Exner bodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario history of a sudden growth spurt with the development of pubic and axillary hair with histopathological examination revealing Call-Exner bodies is suggestive of Granulosa cell tumor.

Granulosa cell tumors cell are ovarian sex-cord stromal tumors made up of cells closely resembling the granulosa cells of the Graafian follicle. 

  • In prepubertal girls, estrogen secreted from the granulosa cell tumor results in precocious puberty.
  • In women of reproductive age, increased estrogen from granulosa cell tumors leads to abnormal uterine bleeding
  • In post-menopausal women, post-menopausal bleeding is the most characteristic symptom.

The cut section is solid/cystic and yellow/orange due to its high lipid content. On microscopy, Call-Exner bodies are seen where the granulosa cells are arranged in small clusters around a central cavity.

Other options:

Option B: Endodermal sinus tumor/Yolk sac tumor is a type of ovarian germ cell tumor that is seen between 15-20 years of age. There is no excess estrogen secretion and hence no development of secondary sexual characteristics. Schiller-Duval bodies are pathognomonic in histopathology. It is characterized by cystic spaces with a tuft of vascular tissue lined by flattened epithelium.

Option C: Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors are a type of sex-cord stromal ovarian tumors. It is most commonly seen in women of reproductive age group. These produce excess androgens and are hence known as virilizing tumors. Menstrual irregularities and signs of virilization like hirsutism and deepening of the voice are common presenting complaints. Microscopy reveals Sertoli cells and Leydig cells.

Option D: Theca cell tumors are also estrogen-secreting sex-cord stromal ovarian tumors. However, they are most commonly seen in post-menopausal women. Microscopy reveals cortical stroma with areas of granulosa cells.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought with complaints of erratic behaviour in school and at home. He is unable to sit still in class for more than a few minutes at a time, pushes other children, and never waits for his turn. The parents don't want him to be started on any addictive medication. Which of the following drugs can be used to manage his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described above of a child with inattention and hyperactivity points towards a diagnosis of attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). In a child with parental preferences not to start an addictive medication, atomoxetine can be used.   

Pharmacotherapy is the first line of treatment for ADHD. CNS stimulants are the first-choice agents as they have shown the greatest efficacy with mild, tolerable side effects. The CNS stimulants used are dopamine agonists like methylphenidate (Option A), amphetamine salts, and dextroamphetamine (Option C). These medications have a risk of dependence and addiction. Non-stimulant medications used in the treatment of ADHD include atomoxetine (norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor), clonidine, and guanfacine (Alpha agonists). They are preferred in patients with a family history of addiction or patient preference. 

Psychosocial interventions such as academic organization skills remediation, parent training, behaviour modification in the classroom and at home, cognitive-behavioural therapy (CBT), and social skills training are also used as adjuncts to pharmacotherapy.

Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a neuropsychiatric condition characterized by a pattern of diminished attention span and increased impulsivity or hyperactivity. The prefrontal cortex of the brain has been implicated in its aetiology, and dopamine is the main neurotransmitter. 

ADHD can begin during infancy but is usually recognised between 1-3 years of age. ADHD was known as minimal brain dysfunction earlier. The characteristics of children with ADHD, in order of frequency, are

  • Hyperactivity
  • Attention deficit (short attention span, distractibility)
  • Impulsivity (action before thought, abrupt shifts in activity, lack of organisation)
  • Memory and thinking deficits
  • Specific learning disabilities
  • Speech and hearing deficits.

Under DSM-5 criteria, for diagnosis of ADHD, it is necessary for symptoms to be present prior to age 12, persist for at least 6 months, have a negative impact on social, academic, or occupational activities, and be present in two or more settings.

The course of ADHD is variable. The majority of the cases persist into adult life. The hyperactivity may disappear in some cases, but the decreased attention span and impulse-control problems usually persist. Patients with ADHD are vulnerable to developing antisocial behaviour, conduct disorder, substance use disorders, and mood disorders.

Other Options: 

Option D: Benzodiazepines have no role in the management of ADHD.

questions.text: A 24-year-old lady presented with vomiting, abdominal distention, and postprandial epigastric pain. She recently joined a gym and has lost 20kgs. A barium meal follow-through of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the likely etiology of the disease?

choices.text: Decreased gastric motility due to malnutrition
Loss of the mesenteric fat pad between the aorta and a branch

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of vomiting, abdominal distension, a history of significant weight loss and the barium follow-through demonstrating dilation of the duodenum with an abrupt cut-off at its third part, coinciding with the line of the superior mesenteric artery is suggestive of superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome/Wilkie syndrome. This condition occurs due to the loss of the mesenteric fat pad between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery which provides a cushioning effect and prevents duodenal compression. 

Wilkie syndrome is usually seen in young women who are physically weak. It is a rare condition in which the SMA compresses the third portion of the duodenum. The normal aortomesenteric angle is between 38-65 degrees. This is reduced to 20 degrees (according to some texts it is 15.2 degrees and in some, it is 18 degrees) in SMA syndrome. The SMA obstructs the third part of the duodenum by compressing it against fixed retroperitoneal structures. 

Symptoms include epigastric pain which is episodic and postprandial in nature, nausea, vomiting, abdominal distention, and weight loss.

SMA syndrome is associated with:

  • Rapid childhood growth
  • Profound weight loss
  • Abdominal surgery
  • Inflammatory diseases of the abdomen
  • Immobilization in a cast that increases lordosis and accentuates the angle of the SMA with the aorta (cast syndrome)

Upper gastrointestinal barium studies are used for diagnosis. CT is also useful in some cases.

Treatment includes:

  • Medical therapy- frequent small feedings, lying on prone or left side postprandially, weight gain, or removal of a body cast improves symptoms.
  • Laparoscopic lysis of the ligament of Treitz is beneficial in a few cases.
  • The following surgical procedures can be done- duodenojejunostomy, gastrojejunostomy, and duodenal derotation (Strong procedure).

The given image shows compressed angle between SMA and the abdominal aorta in CT angiography.

Other Options: 

Option 1 decreased gastric motility does not cause these findings on the X-ray. Malnutrition has no known association with reduced gastric motility. 

Option 3 hypertrophy of the gastric outlet leads to pyloric stenosis. However, this is seen in newborns rather than in adults. 

Option 4 Pancreatic divisum can form a ring-shaped pancreas that can present similarly, however, the history of profound weight loss makes SMA syndrome more likely.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman came with complaints of massive painless vaginal bleeding. She also reported amenorrhea for 2 months. The histopathological examination of the endometrium showed a characteristic Swiss cheese pattern. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of painless vaginal bleeding preceded by amenorrhea with histopathological examination of the endometrium revealing a characteristic Swiss cheese pattern is suggestive of metropathia hemorrhagica.

Metropathia hemorrhagica is a specialized form of anovulatory DUB, seen in women aged 40 to 45 years. The typical symptoms are continuous painless vaginal bleeding at the onset of menses or preceded by a 6-8 week period of amenorrhoea. Occasionally the woman gives a history of menorrhagia prior to this.

On examination, the uterus is bulky and uniformly enlarged. Histopathological findings are:

  • Myohyperplasia of the uterine wall - up to 2.5cm
  • Thick endometrium with cystic glandular hyperplasia appearing as Swiss cheese pattern
  • Absence of secretory endometrium i.e. absence of corkscrew glands 
  • Thin, slender endometrial polyps project into the uterine cavity
  • Corpus luteum is absent
  • One or both ovaries may contain a cyst

Other options

Option A: Endometriosis usually presents in the reproductive age group, with symptoms of dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, menorrhagia, and infertility.

Option C: Halban's disease is irregular shedding and is due to persistent corpus luteum. Regular cycles with prolonged bleeding and normal flow are present. 

Option D: Endometrial carcinoma usually presents as postmenopausal bleeding. There may be a history of PCOS or HRT indicating chronic estrogen exposure. There will be no Swiss cheese appearance on histopathological examination.

questions.text: A patient is being evaluated 3 weeks after a fracture. Below is a picture of her cast. She had no previous surgeries. What was the likely fracture she developed and the name of the cast?
questions.solution:
The image shows a spica cast used for fractures of the shaft of the femur.

The negative history for previous surgeries suggests a shaft fracture. A hip spica is used for fracture neck of the femur only after surgical fixation of the fracture.

Once adequate traction is obtained, a hip spica cast is applied with the hip joint in 95 degrees of flexion and 40 to 45 degrees of abduction. There must be sufficient space left to allow for toileting and to prevent soiling of the cast. 

Other Options: 

Option A, C, D: A Minerva cast is used for cervical and upper thoracic disease. Fractures of the neck of the femur are almost always managed surgically due to a high risk of avascular necrosis of the neck of the femur due to injury to the blood supply to the head of the femur. Methods used include multiple screw fixation and hip arthroplasty.

questions.text: As an ENT intern, you notice the following test being performed on a parotidectomy patient. The test involves painting the parotid area with dry corn starch and asking the patient to chew a piece of gum. You observe the parotid area turning blue in colour. This test confirms the diagnosis of which of the following syndromes?
questions.solution:
The test described above is Minor's starch-iodine test used to diagnose Frey's syndrome.

Frey's syndrome or gustatory sweating occurs as a result of aberrant innervation of the dermal sweat glands by the regenerating fibers of the auriculotemporal nerve following parotid surgery. Patients with Frey's syndrome present with sweating, warmth, and redness of the face as a result of salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of food.

The diagnosis can be confirmed with Minor's starch-iodine test. This test involves applying iodine and dry starch over the suspected area, and giving a stimulus that can cause salivation is given to the patient. In the presence of iodine and sweat, the starch over the affected area will turn blue.

Management of Frey's syndrome:

  • Initially conservative and reassurance. Most often they recover without any active treatment in 6 months.
  • Antiperspirants like aluminium chloride
  • Tympanic/Jacobson neurectomy
  • Botulinum toxin injection into the affected skin
  • Auriculotemporal nerve avulsion
Other options:

Option A: Bogard syndrome (gustatory lacrimation) is due to residual facial paralysis or faulty regeneration of the nervus intermedius of the facial nerve. It presents as unilateral lacrimation during eating and drinking.

It occurs due to facial nerve damage, proximal to the geniculate ganglion. During regeneration, the fibres supplying the salivary gland aberrantly supply the lacrimal gland. 

Option C: DiGeorge syndrome is a clinical syndrome that occurs due to a deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22. It results from the failure of the development of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches. The features associated are:

  • Cleft palate
  • Abnormal facies
  • Thymic aplasia leading to T-cell deficiency
  • Cardiac defects
  • Hypocalcemia 2° to parathyroid aplasia. (Mnemonic: CATCH-22)

Option D: Brown sequard syndrome occurs due to transection of the spinal cord only on one side. This results in blocking of all motor functions on the side of the transection in all segments below the transection level.

Features include:  

  • Ipsilateral weakness - due to corticospinal tract
  • Ipsilateral loss of joint position and vibration sensation - due to posterior column 
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation - due to the spinothalamic tract

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady presents with generalised weakness and recurrent epistaxis. On examination, the spleen is not palpable. Blood investigations reveal Hb of 5 g/dL, platelet count of 15,000/μL, and WBC count of 3000/μL. What findings are expected to be seen in a bone marrow biopsy of this patient?

choices.text: Macrophages with characteristic crumbled tissue paper appearance.
Numerous needle-like azurophilic granules in the cytoplasm of the promyelocytes.
Erythroid hyperplasia with pathognomonic ring sideroblasts

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of generalised weakness, recurrent epistaxis, impalpable spleen and blood investigations showing pancytopenia, are suggestive of Aplastic anemia. Bone marrow biopsy reveals hypocellularity with fatty infiltration.

Aplastic anemia is a syndrome of chronic primary hematopoietic failure. This results in pancytopenia (anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia). The patient will have

  • Decreased red blood cells leading to anemia
  • Decreased white blood cells leading to recurrent infections
  • Decreased platelets leading to petechiae and ecchymoses.

Many other leukemias and lymphomas may have a similar presentation. However, splenomegaly is characteristically absent in these patients. 

The bone marrow is markedly hypocellular. It is largely devoid of hematopoietic cells. Marrow aspirates yield a dry tap having only fat cells, fibrous stroma, lymphocytes, and plasma cells. Aplasia is best appreciated in marrow biopsies. 

The images given below show the normal and hypocellular bone marrow.

Treatment includes:

  • Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation - best method of management in young patients.
  • Antithymocyte globulin with cyclosporine - elderly patients and patients without HLA-matched donors.
  • Eltrombopag - a thrombopoietin analog used as an add-on therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Bone marrow examination showing macrophages with characteristic crumbled tissue paper appearance is seen in Gaucher disease, due to glucocerebrosidase deficiency. The patients present with haematological abnormalities, organomegaly, and pathological fractures. 

Option B: Acute myeloid leukaemia is most commonly seen in elderly people. Histopathology from bone marrow aspirate reveals Auer rods (needle-like azurophilic granules) in the cytoplasm of the promyelocytes (black arrow) along with a large, uniform population of cells (myeloblasts) with prominent nucleoli (yellow arrow).

Option D: Bone marrow examination showing erythroid hyperplasia with pathognomonic ring sideroblasts is seen in sideroblastic anemia. Sideroblastic anemia are a group of disorders characterized by the presence of nucleated red cells (normoblasts) containing non-heme siderotic granules and stain prussian blue positive (sideroblasts). They can be also seen in myelodysplastic syndrome and lead poisoning.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes with complaints of low-grade fever, wheezing, and urticaria. He has eosinophilia on CBC and there are charcot leyden crystals and larvae on sputum microscopy. Which of the following is the likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above constellation of symptoms in addition to the presence of larvae in the sputum raises suspicion for Loeffler's syndrome caused secondary to Ascaris lumbricoides infection of the lung. 

Ascaris lumbricoides is an intestinal nematode that causes ascariasis. Infection occurs through food or water contaminated with human feces having eggs of Ascaris. These eggs contain the infective rhabditiform larva. After the worm penetrates the intestinal mucosa it ascends to the lungs via the portal circulation where it gets coughed up and swallowed leading to a cycle of reinfection.

When the Ascaris worms are in the lungs, they can precipitate a local hypersensitivity reaction that presents as cough, wheezing, and urticaria. There can be eosinophilia. Sputum can be blood-tinged and may contain Charcot Leyden crystals.  These are formed by the eosinophil protein galectin-10.

The syndrome can last for 1-2 weeks and generally resolves on its own but sometimes it can be fatal. 

Other options:

Options B: Lofgren's syndrome is characterized by erythema nodosum and hilar adenopathy. Periarticular arthritis may also be seen. It is a subtype of sarcoidosis and is not associated with larvae in the sputum sample. 

Option C: Asthma can present similarly. However, the presence of larvae in the sputum makes Loeffler's syndrome more likely.

Option D: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis arises due to inhalation of antigenic triggers which result in an inflammatory response. Symptoms include fever, chills, malaise, and dyspnea. Cough, weight loss, and fatigue can be seen in chronic cases.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient presents to the OPD for evaluation of lower extremity weakness after lifting heavy boxes. On examination there is decreased sensation in the ankle region and the ankle jerk reflex is diminished. He also reports difficulty in passing urine. Which of the following is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of this patient are suggestive of an intervertebral disc prolapse likely involving the L5-S1 nerve root. The next step in management for this patient would be to perform an MRI of the spine to assess the severity of the prolapse and guide further management.

Intervertebral disc prolapse occurs when the nucleus pulposus of the disc bulges through a tear in the outer ring. This can apply pressure on the spinal cord and lead to clinical symptoms based on the spinal segment involved. These include:

  • Pain that radiates down the back(Sciatica)
  • Urinary incontinence if the S2 segment is involved. 
  • Muted ankle(L5-S1) and knee reflexes (L3-L4)

Most cases of low back pain can be managed conservatively with NSAIDs and physical therapy and imaging is usually not required. However there are certain indications that require urgent imaging and surgical management. 

Indications for surgical management: 

Absolute indications:

  • Failed conservative management.
  • Marked progressive weakness of muscles.
  • Progressive neurological deficit.
  • Cauda equina paralysis.

Relative Indications:

  • Recurrent episodes of incapacitating sciatica
  • Pain unrelieved by complete rest from activity.

Intervertebral disc prolapse

Features of IVDP pain:

  • Pain is increased by flexion episodes, sneezing, coughing, straining, and sitting. 
  • Pain is decreased by rest and in the semi-Fowler position. Semi-Fowler position is lying in a bed supine with the head of the bed raised at approximately 30 to 45 degrees.
  • Leg pain equal to or more than the back pain in IVDP cases is evidence of involvement of the nerve root due to the herniated disc.

Important tests for diagnosis:

1. Straight Leg Raising Test (SLRT) or Lasegue sign

This is done to assess nerve root irritation in the lumbosacral area.  The patient is made to lie on the back with the head extended, with hips and legs in the neutral position. The affected leg is then passively and slowly raised by the ankle with the knee fully extended. The examiner stops further leg elevation when pain is elicited. Normally it should be possible to raise the limb to 80–90 degrees. The SLRT test is positive if the patient develops pain when the leg is between 30 and 60/70 degrees from horizontal. The pain should be radicular type and radiating to the back of the thigh or to the calf.

 

2. Bragard test (or Sciatic stretch test or Flip test)

Perform SLRT. At the point where the patient experiences discomfort, the leg is lowered a little. The stretching and pain become less. At this angle, the ankle is passively dorsiflexed. If the pain at the back of the thigh or in the calf is felt again, the test is positive. This is also called reinforcement positive or Bragard’s sign positive

 

3. Crossed SLRT (or well-leg raising test or Fajersztajn sign)

When SLRT is performed on the unaffected side, the patient may feel pain on the affected side. This is termed a contralateral positive SLRT or crossed SLRT positive. It is a very specific sign of root compression. It becomes positive usually when there is severe compression due to a centrally located prolapse.

4. Bowstring sign (or popliteal compression test)

The ‘bowstring sign’ is even more specific for disc prolapse than SLRT. Perform SLRT until the patient experiences sciatic pain. Without reducing the amount of lift, bend the knee so as to relax the sciatic nerve (Buckling sign). Buttock pain is immediately relieved. The examiner then presses the popliteal fossa to stretch the lateral popliteal nerve behind the lateral tibial condyle. This will tighten the nerve like a bowstring and re-induce the pain.

 

5. Femoral stretch (reverse Lasegue test or Mackiewicz sign)

The patient lies prone. The examiner flexes the knee to the thigh and the hip is passively extended. The test is positive if the patient experiences anterior thigh pain. This test is usually positive for L2-L3 and L3-L4 (high lumbar) protrusions

 

Treatment:

Conservative:

  • Continuous bed rest and traction for 2 weeks will reduce the herniation in over 90% of cases.
  • Back exercises and posture correction are also a part of conservative management
  • Epidural steroids

Surgical: Surgical procedures include laminectomy, hemilaminectomy, fenestration surgery, and microscopic & endoscopic lumbar discectomy.

questions.text: As a PSM resident, you explain the actions of four different types of vaccinations to a group of interns, as given below. Which of the following is contraindicated in pregnancy?

choices.text: Vaccine prepared by growing the organism in culture media and inactivating them with chemicals.
Vaccine prepared by detoxifying the toxins produced by organisms
Vaccine prepared by recombinant DNA technology by expressing protective protein antigens in yeast cells.
Vaccine prepared from organisms that have lost their capacity to induce full-blown disease but retain their immunogenicity.

questions.solution:
Live attenuated vaccines are prepared from organisms that have lost their capacity to induce full-blown disease but retain their immunogenicity and are contraindicated in pregnancy unless the risk of infection exceeds the risk of harm to the fetus.

Varicella, Mumps, BCG, Measles and Rubella vaccines are examples of live attenuated vaccines.

Other options: 

Option A:  Inactivated or killed vaccines are prepared by growing the organism in culture media and inactivating them with heat and chemicals (usually formalin). They are usually safe in pregnancy. Examples include cholera, rabies and polio (IPV) vaccines.

Option B: Toxoid vaccines are a type of subunit vaccines prepared by detoxifying the toxins produced by organisms like tetanus bacilli. In general, they are highly efficacious and safe immunizing agents.

Tetanus toxoid is routinely administered in pregnant women. The first dose is given at 16-20 weeks while the second dose is at 20-24 weeks ideally maintaining a one-month interval between the two doses.

Option C: Recombinant protein vaccines are prepared by recombinant DNA technology by expressing protective protein antigens in yeast cells like the hepatitis B vaccine. They are generally better purified from cultured microorganisms resulting in cleaner vaccine preparations with a better safety profile.

questions.text: A 45-year-old painter presented with chronic right shoulder pain. On examination, the patient can only initiate abduction up to 15° and not beyond. The muscle injured in this case belongs to which of the following categories?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the deltoid muscle (multipennate) is injured as abduction beyond 15° is carried out by this muscle. 

Muscles with oblique fibers are subclassified as follows:

  • Triangular: They are triangular in shape. E.g., temporalis, adductor longus, trapezius
  • Pennate: They are feather-shaped. Based on their complexity, they can have the following subtypes:
    • Unipennate: Fascicles on one side of the tendon. E.g., flexor pollicis longus, extensor digitorum longus, peroneus tertius, and, palmar interossei
    • Bipennate: Fascicles on two sides of the tendon. E.g., rectus femoris, peroneus longus, flexor hallucis longus, and dorsal interossei
    • Multipennate: Central tendon branches into two or more branches within the muscle. E.g., deltoid, subscapularis
    • Circumpennate (radial): Muscle fibers converge to a central tendon in a radial fashion. E.g., tibialis anterior
 

Muscles involved in the abduction of the shoulder:

  • The first 15° of abduction is initiated by the supraspinatus muscle (Both deltoid and supraspinatus help in initiation).
  • The next 15° to 90° of abduction is carried out mainly by the middle fibres of the deltoid muscle.
  • Abduction of the arm beyond 90° is carried out by the movement of the shoulder girdle caused by the action of the trapezius and serratus anterior,

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with pain in the right leg accompanied by symptoms of fever and fatigue. His X-ray shows onion peel appearance with extension into the bone marrow. Which of the following is associated with this condition?

choices.text: There is poor response to radio therapy

questions.solution:
This patient has pain in the limb with fever and fatigue with onion peel appearance on X-Ray with extension into the bone marrow. This is most likely Ewing's sarcoma. It is associated with an elevated serum LDH.

Ewing sarcoma is the 2nd most common bone sarcoma in children. The majority of the patients affected are usually <20 years of age. It has a slight male predominance. The majority of Ewing sarcomas have a balanced translocation between the EWSR1 gene on chromosome 22 and the FLI1 gene on chromosome 11. 

It commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, humerus, and flat bones of the pelvis. Patients present with painful enlarging mass, fever, and anemia. The affected area is usually tender, swollen, and warm.

Laboratory findings may show an elevated WBC count, LDH levels (lactate dehydrogenase) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). The common diagnostic test used for Ewing’s sarcoma is the detection of translocation t(11;22) (q24;q12). 

A histopathological examination of Ewing sarcoma shows sheets of uniform, round blue cells arranged in Homer-Wright rosettes. Immunohistochemistry is usually positive for synaptophysin and mic-2. The tumor cells contain glycogen and are hence PAS positive and they are reticulin negative.

Preoperative chemotherapy with vincristine, ifosfamide, doxorubicin and etoposide results in extensive tumor necrosis and shrinkage. Wide excision may be combined with adjuvant radiotherapy if surgical margins are poor. Definitive radiotherapy rather than surgical excision may be advocated if it is non-resectable or metastasis has occurred. It is a radio-sensitive tumor.

Indicators of poor prognosis in patients with Ewing's sarcoma:

  • Presence of distant metastasis - worst prognostic factor
  • Size and location of the primary lesion
  • Presence of fever, anemia
  • Leukocytosis, raised ESR. 

Other Options:

Ewing's sarcoma is radio sensitive(Option A), reticulin negative(Option B) and associated with a t(11:22) (Option D) translocation.

Related Pearl: Important radiosenstive and radioresistant bone tumours

Radiosensitive tumors:

  1. Metastasis (except metastasis from renal cell carcinoma which is radioresistant)
  2. Ewing's sarcoma
  3. Multiple myeloma
  4. Lymphoma

Radioresistant tumors:

  1. Osteosarcoma
  2. Chondrosarcoma
  3. Fibrosarcoma
  4. Malignant fibrous histiocytoma
