questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with headache, dizziness and unsteady gait. You confirm the diagnosis with the help of a brain MRI which shows a midline mass arising from the cerebellar vermis in the posterior fossa. What characteristic feature can be seen on MRI of the spine?
questions.solution:
The 5-year-old boy presenting with headache, unsteady gait and the brain MRI showing a midline mass arising from the cerebellar vermis in the posterior fossa is highly suggestive of Medulloblastoma. Spine MRI shows drop metastases which refers to the dissemination of the tumor through the CSF to anatomically lower sites like the spinal cord.

The image below is a T1-weighted MRI of the spine showing localised enhancing nodules (drop metastases) in the cervical region.

Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant brain tumour of childhood, accounting for 90% of embryonal CNS tumours. It predominantly occurs in the cerebellar vermis which causes ataxia and unsteady gait. CT and MRI demonstrate a solid, homogeneous, contrast medium–enhancing mass in the posterior fossa causing 4th ventricular obstruction and hydrocephalus.

Medulloblastoma predominantly occurs in males, presenting at a median age between 5-7 years of age and correspond histologically to WHO grade IV tumours. Clinical features include increased intracranial pressure manifesting as headache, nausea, vomiting, mental status changes, and hypertension. There is also cerebellar dysfunction which manifests as ataxia, poor balance, and dysmetria. 

On microscopic examination, the tumour is very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells. Individual tumour cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei and are characterized by Homer–Wright rosettes.

Treatment comprises a multimodal strategy that includes surgical resection with adjuvant craniospinal radiotherapy for those over 3 years of age and chemotherapy. 

Other options:

Option A: Rugger jersey spine is seen in osteopetrosis. X-ray shows alternating bands of sclerosis and lucency throughout, resembling a rugger jersey.

Option C: Squaring and bridging of the vertebral body, leading to a bamboo spine appearance in ankylosing spondylitis

Option D: A diffuse and homogenous increase in the vertebral body opacity is referred to as the ivory vertebra is seen in Paget's disease.

questions.text: A 23 year old man presents with back pain for 2 months. MRI of the spine reveals a bony cystic mass at the L1 vertebra. MRI shows intralesional septations and angiography demonstrates persistence of contrast and blush of flow within the lesion. There is no cartilage or necrosis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a lesion on the L1 vertebra with persistence of contrast and blush of flow in the lesion is suggestive of an aneurysmal bone cyst.

It affects all age groups, but generally occurs during the first 2 decades of life and has no sex predilection. It usually occurs in the metaphysis of long bones and the posterior elements of vertebral bodies.

This is a tumor characterized by multiloculated blood-filled cystic spaces separated by septae, composed of multinucleated osteoclast-like giant cells and reactive woven bone. Radiographically, an aneurysmal bone cyst is seen as an eccentric, expansile, lesion with well-defined margins. Most lesions are completely lytic and often contain a thin shell of reactive bone at the periphery.

 

The spindle cells of aneurysmal bone cyst frequently demonstrate rearrangements of chromosome 17p13, leading to USP6 overexpression.

The majority of secondary aneurysmal bone cysts arise in association with:

  • Benign neoplasms
    • Giant-cell tumor of the bone (most common)
    • Chondroblastoma
    • Osteoblastoma
    • Fibrous dysplasia
  • Osteosarcoma

questions.text: A post-knee transplant patient has an infection of his prosthesis. The organism is novobiocin-sensitive and coagulase-negative. Which of the following is not a virulence factor of this organism?
questions.solution:
The most likely organism implicated here is Staphylococcus epidermidis as it is coagulase-negative and novobiocin-sensitive. Gamma hemolysin is not a virulence factor seen in this bacteria.

Staphylococcus epidermidis is a novobiocin-sensitive, coagulase-negative, non-pigmented, non hemolytic cocci. It also doesn't ferment mannitol. 

It is present on normal skin flora and mucous membranes and has the following virulence factors:

  • Biofilms
  • Adhesive proteins
  • Teichoic acids
  • Lipases and DNAses

Among the Coagulase negative staph species, Staph epidermidis is the most common cause of:

  • Healthcare-associated bloodstream infections
  • Early prosthetic valve endocarditis
  • Peritonitis in dialysis patients
  • Infections of orthopedic prosthesis
  • CSF shunt infections

S. epidermidis is more resistant than Staph aureus to methicillin and the treatment of choice is Vancomycin.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman comes to your clinic due to recurrent episodes of cough productive of large amounts of sputum for 2 years. She is a non-smoker. Lung examination reveals wheezes with crackles bilaterally. A transverse section of the CT lung is given in the image below. Which of the following statements is false regarding the diagnosis?

choices.text: CT of chest shows tram-track appearance
Surgical resection of the affected organ forms the mainstay of management
It can be caused by aspiration of foreign body
Poor mucociliary clearance is one of the mechanisms of pathogenesis

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette along with the CT scan showing the signet ring sign is diagnostic of bronchiectasis. Surgical management of this condition is considered in only select cases and does not form the mainstay of treatment.

Bronchiectasis refers to the irreversible dilatation of bronchi due to recurrent cycles of infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. Development of the disease requires an infectious insult in combination with impaired mucociliary clearance (e.g. impaired immune defenses, structural airway defect).

Bronchiectasis is commonly associated with Kartagener syndrome, cystic fibrosis, and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis. Focal bronchiectasis can be caused due to the pressure effects of a foreign body or tumor or neighboring lymphadenopathy on the airway.

Clinically, patients present with persistent productive cough and production of thick tenacious sputum. On examination, there will be clubbing, wheezing, and crackles.

A chest X-ray shows a tram track appearance due to the dilated airways. Chest CT is the imaging modality of choice for the diagnosis of bronchiectasis. 

CT findings include

  • Tram-track appearance
  • Signet-ring sign
  • Lack of bronchial tapering
  • Tree-in-bud pattern - It occurs due to the thickening of the dilated airways along with the inspissated secretions.
  • Cysts originating from the bronchial wall (pronounced in cystic bronchiectasis)

The image given below shows the signet ring sign (arrows) seen in bronchiectasis:

Management includes antibiotic therapy, improved secretion clearance, bronchial hygiene, and anti-inflammatory therapy.

Surgery is only indicated in select cases where the bronchiectasis is confined to a single lobe or segment. Lung transplantation is considered in severe bronchiectasis cases, predominantly when associated with cystic fibrosis. In a case of bronchiectasis presenting with massive hemoptysis, intubation is done to stabilize the patient, the source of bleeding is identified, and the nonbleeding lung is protected. Bronchial artery embolization is often needed to control the bleeding.

Related Pearl: Investigation of Choice in Respiratory Diseases

Disease Investigation of choice
Interstitial lung disease HRCT
Bronchiectasis HRCT
Pulmonary embolism CT Pulmonary Angiography > Ventilation-Perfusion Scan
Calcification CT
Solitary pulmonary nodule CT > PET
Lung Malignancy CT scan
Superior sulcus tumor MRI scan > CT scan

Related Pearl: Types of Bronchiectasis

Cylindrical/Tubular Saccular/Varicose Cystic
  • Mildest form of bronchiectasis
  • Loss of normal airway tapering
  • Bronchi have a uniform calibre, have parallel walls tram track sign and signet ring sign
  • Further distortion of the airway wall along with more mucous and sputum production
  • Beaded bronchi with interspersed sites of relative narrowing
  • Most severe form of bronchiectasis and least common
  • This form has large air spaces and a honeycombed appearance
  • Air fluid levels present

Related Pearl: Tram Track Appearance in Various Conditions

Tram tracks or tram track signs are medical signs that bear some resemblance to tramway tracks (Railway Track).

1. Pulmonology

  • When found in the lungs, tram tracks are radiologic signs that are usually accompanied by pulmonary edema in cases of congestive heart failure and bronchiectasis.
  • Tram tracks are caused by bronchial wall thickening, and can be detected on a lateral chest X-ray.

2. Nephrology

  • The term "tram tracks" is also used to describe the basement membrane duplication found on light microscopy that is characteristic of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type I.
  • It is less commonly associated with types II and III.

3. Neurology

  • The term has also been used to describe findings associated with optic nerve sheath meningioma.
  • Tram track-shaped calcifications in the cerebral cortex indicate Sturge-Weber syndrome.

4. Mammary glands:

  • Tram track appearance in mammography/USG indicates Duct Ectasia.

questions.text:
Which of the following values are negative in the declining stage of the demographic cycle?
  1. Demographic gap
  2. Population
  3. Death rate
  4. Population growth
  5. Birth rate
questions.solution:
The demographic gap and population growth are negative in stage 5 ( declining stage) of the demographic cycle.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: A patient was given 200 mg of a drug that follows first-order kinetics. If 75 mg is excreted in 90 minutes, how much drug will remain at the end of 6 hours?
questions.solution:
30.5 mg of the drug will remain after 6 hours.

In first order kinetics, a constant fraction of the drug is excreted in a given time. 

75 mg of 200 mg is excreted in 90 minutes

75/200 = 37.5/100 = 0.375 is eliminated 

After 90 minutes; 200 mg-75 mg = 125 mg remains 

The next 90 minutes (after 180 minutes) = 125 x 0.375 = 46.875 mg is eliminated, and 125-46.875 = 78.125 mg remains 

The next 90 minutes (after 270 minutes) = 78.125 x 0.375 = 29.297 mg is eliminated, and 78.125-29.297 = 48.828 remains 

The next 90 minutes (after 360 minutes) = 48.828 x 0.375 = 18.310 mg is eliminated, 48.828-18.310 = 30.518 mg remains after 6 hours. 

A simpler way to calculate 

3/8 fraction is excreted in 90 minutes → 5/8 remains after 90 minutes.

6 hours (360 min) is 4 times of 90 minutes.

So 200 x (5/8)(5/8)(5/8)(5/8) = 30.518 mg remains after 360 minutes

questions.text: A 22-year-old female patient is posted for surgery under general anesthesia.  She has a previous history of postoperative emesis and motion sickness. Which of the following anaesthetic agent is most suitable for this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario indicates that the patient has significant risk factors for postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV). Propofol is the most suitable anesthetic agent due to its anti-emetic properties.

Risk factors for PONV:

  • Patient factors 
    • Young age, female gender, non-smoker
    • History of prior postoperative emesis
    • History of motion sickness
  • Anesthetic techniques
    • General anesthesia
    • Drugs: Opioids, Volatile agents, Nitrous oxide(Options B and D)
  • Surgical procedures
    • Strabismus surgery
    • Gynecological surgeries
    • Laparoscopy
    • Cholecystectomy

Risk reduction strategies include:

  • Avoidance of general anesthesia by the use of regional anesthesia
  • Use of propofol for the induction and maintenance of anesthesia
  • Avoid nitrous oxide in surgeries lasting over 1 hour
  • Avoid volatile anesthetics
  • Minimization of intraoperative and postoperative opioids
  • Maintain adequate hydration
  • Use of sugammadex instead of neostigmine for the reversal of neuromuscular blockade

Drugs used in the prevention and treatment of PONV:

  • 5-HT 3 antagonists - ondansetron, palonosetron
  • Butyrophenones- droperidol
  • Dexamethasone
  • Transdermal scopolamine

Note: Post-operative nausea and vomiting is more common with Etomidate.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with recurrent swellings in the natal cleft with occasional purulent discharge from it. He also complains of pain and discomfort on sitting. On examination, a single point of discharge is seen. There is hair at the opening. Antibiotics have not provided relief and he has no relevant surgical or medical history. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of a military personnel with swelling in the natal cleft associated with pain and discharge is suggestive of pilonidal sinus disease/jeep disease. The management of recurrent disease is with simple excision and primary closure.

Pilonidal sinus disease is commonly seen in the natal cleft, more in men, usually after puberty. Drivers and hairdressers are more commonly affected.

The pilonidal sinus opening is seen usually in the midline between the level of the sacrococcygeal joint and the tip of the coccyx. The other sites that they can be affected include the interdigital cleft and axilla.

Pathophysiology:

Buttock friction and shearing forces in this area allow broken hairs to enter the skin and create a subcutaneous, chronically infected midline track. An infected hair follicle can also form such a track. Secondary tracks can also form and are lined with granulation tissue and discharge. 

Clinical features:

  • Patients complain of intermittent pain, swelling, and discharge at the base of the spine.
  • A foreign-body-type reaction may then lead to the formation of an abscess.
  • Recurrence is common even after adequate excision of the tract.

Treatment

  • Conservative treatment: Strict hygiene and regular shaving of hair in the area.
  • Abscess:
    • Rest, baths, local antiseptic dressings, and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
    • If refractory to the above treatment- drainage with thorough curettage of granulation tissue and hair.
  • Surgical techniques: 
    • With no prior surgical procedures: Primary excision and closure or marsupialization
    • In patients with recurrent disease with multiple local surgeries: flap procedures like Bascom repair, Z flap, Rhomboid flap

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male patient recently diagnosed with renal vein thrombosis is being evaluated. He had past history of weight gain, generalized edema, and hypertension. Urinary examination shows gross proteinuria and the presence of multiple RBCs with normal morphology and no casts. Anti-PLA2R antibodies are present. Which of the following is likely to be seen on renal biopsy in this patient?

GBM - Glomerular basement membrane

choices.text: Diffuse thickening of the GBM with spike and dome pattern

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of nephrotic syndrome. Anti PLA2R antibodies are seen in membranous nephropathy which is seen as diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) on light microscopy examination. On electron microscopy, there are irregular spikes protruding from the GBM.

Membranous nephropathy is characterized by nephrotic syndrome and proteinuria. It occurs due to the accumulation of deposits containing immunoglobulins along the subepithelial portion of the glomerular basement membrane. Most of the cases (75%) are primary and are linked to an autoimmune phenomenon. The remaining are associated with the following: 

  • Drugs - Penicillamine, captopril, gold, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
  • Underlying malignancies like carcinoma of the lung, colon, melanoma
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Infections such as chronic hepatitis B and C, syphilis
  • Autoimmune conditions like thyroiditis

M-type phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) antibodies are seen in the majority of these cases. 

Membranous nephropathy can present with insidious onset of nephrotic syndrome or a hypercoagulable state such as pulmonary embolism, renal vein thrombosis, deep venous thrombosis, and symptoms of heart failure. The hypercoagulable state occurs due to the loss of antithrombin 3 from the urine.

On light microscopy, the glomeruli may be normal or have a uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall. Electron microscopy will reveal spike and dome patterns. Immunofluorescence microscopy demonstrates that the granular deposits contain both immunoglobulins and complement.

The image below shows the light microscopic findings in membranous nephropathy.

Other options:

Options B and D- Tram-track appearance of the glomerular basement membrane and large and hypercellular glomeruli are seen in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis. It presents as nephrotic syndrome and along with features of nephritic component manifested by hematuria or as mild proteinuria.

Option C- Mesangial deposition of IgA is seen in IgA nephropathy (Berger disease).

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

The principal site of glomerular injury

 Visceral epithelial cell (Podocyte) Endothelial cells, glomerular basement membrane (GBM), Mesangial cells, Parietal epithelial cells (>Crescents)

Clinical features

Hallmark:

Heavy Proteinuria: 3.5 g/24 h or Urine protein:creatinine ratio >3) 

Hypoalbuminemia, 

Edema

Lipiduria, Hyperlipidemia

Microscopic hematuria

Hypertension

Hypercoagulability                                                    

Hallmark:

Hematuria (RBC casts/dysmorphic RBCs)

Varying degrees of proteinuria and pyuria

Renal dysfunction

Hypertension

Associated Glomerular pathology

Minimal change disease (Primary and secondary)

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Primary and secondary)

Membranous-nephropathy (Primary and secondary)

Diabetic nephropathy

Amyloidosis

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (crescentic)

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

Alport syndrome

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythematosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: Hypoxia-induced vasoconstriction in pulmonary circulation results due to inhibition of which of the following channels?
questions.solution:
Hypoxia-induced vasoconstriction in pulmonary circulation results due to the inhibition of the potassium channel.

Hypoxia induces vasoconstriction by inhibition of oxygen-sensitive potassium channels in pulmonary vascular smooth muscle cell membranes. This leads to depolarization of the cell membrane and activation of calcium channels causing the influx of calcium ions. The rise of calcium concentration then causes constriction of small arteries and arterioles.

When the concentration of O2 in the alveoli decreases below normal the adjacent blood vessels constrict. This effect is opposite to the effect observed in systemic vessels, which dilate rather than constrict in response to low O2 levels.

This is because the low oxygen concentrations can

  • Stimulate the release of or increase sensitivity to vasoconstrictor substances such as endothelin or reactive oxygen species.
  • Decrease the release of vasodilators such as nitric oxide from the lung.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy has been brought with complaints of thumb sucking for the last 2 months. He has a 3-month-old brother who was born preterm and is in the NICU. His parents spend a lot of time with him in the hospital. Which of the following defense mechanisms is he exhibiting?
questions.solution:
This patient's behaviour of thumb sucking is a behaviour exhibited by neonates and disappears by 5 years of age. Reverting back to behaviours from a previous developmental stage age is regression.

Regression occurs as a method to deal with the anxieties associated with conflict. In this case, it is the likely lack of attention paid by the parents to the patient due to them spending time with his sick sibling. The condition is managed by offering psychotherapy to the child and encouraging the parents to spend more time with him.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: An extract of the flowers derived from the plant given below is used as a mosquito control measure. Which of the following best describes the action of this insecticide?
questions.solution:
The given plant is pyrethrum(Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium). The extract from the flowers contains pyrethrin (nerve poison) which is used as an excellent space spray against adult mosquitos. 

Space sprays are those where the insecticidal formulation is sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog to kill insects.

Pyrethrum sprays are effective in reducing the number of mosquitoes but the reduction is only temporary since it has no residual action like DDT or other synthetic insecticides. So, most space sprays contain pyrethrum and DDT for synergistic action.

Related Pearl: Insecticides

Contact poisons

  • Natural: Pyrethrum, rotenone, derris, nicotine, mineral oils
  • Synthetic:
    • Organo-chlorine compounds: DDT, methoxychlor, HCH, lindane, chlordane, heptachlor, dieldrin, aldrin, toxaphene, kepone, mirex.
    • Repellants: Benzyl benzoate, indalone, meta-diethyltoluamide, dimethyl phthalate, ethyl hexanediol.
    • Organo-phosphorus compounds: Chlorthion (aryl), diazinon (aryl), demethoate, malathion (alkyl), fenthion, parathion (aryl), trichlorfon (alkyl), runnel, abale, naled, chlorpyrifos, fenitrothion, dicapthon.
    • Carbamates: Carbaryl, dimetilan, propoxur, pyrolan.
    • Synthetic pyrethroids: Prothrin, resmethrin, bioresmethrin, permethrin, proparthin, tetramethrin
  • Stomach poisons: Paris green, sodium fluoride.
  • Fumigants: Hydrogen cyanide, methyl bromide, sulphur dioxide, carbon disulphide.
Specific Insecticides Comments
DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-thrichloroethane) Insecticidal properties were discovered by Swiss scientist, Paul Muller. Most widely used insecticide. Attacks nerves of insects but doesn’t cause immediate death. White amorphous powder. Contains 70 – 80% of para-para isomers, which is the most active fraction of DDT. Has residual action up to 18 months. Used as a residual spray.Least toxic organo-chlorine compound.
HCH (hexachlorocyclo-hexane) Synthesized by Michael Faraday. Normal HCH contains 13 – 16% of gamma isomer. Gamma-HCH or lindane has 99% gamma isomer.Short residual action – 3 months.
Malathion Least toxicity of all organophosphorus compounds. Used as an ultra-low volume spray.
Fenthion Also called baytex. Used as a residual spray.
Pyrethrum Vegetable origin – Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium. Nerve poison and is excellent as a space spray.No residual action.Synergistic action with DDT as space spray.

Related Pearl: Mosquito Control Measures

  • Anti-larval measures
    • Environmental control
      • This is done by source reduction by eliminating breeding places through appropriate methods for the different species.
      • Intermittent irrigation is also a method of environmental control
    • Chemical control
      • Mineral oils: Oldest known larvicidal method. Oils that are used are diesel oil, kerosene, crude oil fractions. Disadvantage is that it kills fish.
      • Paris green: Copper acetoarsenite is an emerald green, micro-crystalline powder and is insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison to larvae. It is not harmful to man or animals. Very effective against Anopheles as they are surface feeders.
      • Synthetic insecticides: Organo-phosphorous compounds like fenthion, chlorpyrifos and abate are larvicidal. Abate is least toxic.
    • Biological control
      • The fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (Barbados millions) feed on mosquito larvae.
      • These are used in conjunction with other methods.
  • Anti-adult measures
    • Residual sprays
      • Adult mosquitoes can be controlled by spraying with residual insecticides like DDT, Malathion, propoxur and gamma-HCH (lindane)
      • Resistance to DDT has been shown by mosquitoes
    • Space sprays
      • Space sprays are those in which insecticides are sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog.
      • Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison and is the most common insecticide used as a space spray. Its active principle is pyrethrin.
      • Ultra-low volume space spraying (ULV) is done with Malathion and fenitrothion.
    • Genetic control by sterile male technique, cytoplasmic incompatibility, sex distortion, etc.
  • Protection against bites
    • Usage of mosquito nets, building screens and repellants like diethyltoluamide (deet), indalone, dimethylphthalate, dimethyl carbate, etc.

questions.text: An elderly woman presents with a unilateral throbbing headache associated with nausea and vomiting. She has had similar episodes in the past where the headache usually lasts for 1-2 days and she prefers sitting in a dark room during the attacks. She also gives a history of myocardial infarction 2 years back. Which of the following drugs can be prescribed to this patient to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of an acute attack of migraine. Lasmiditan which is a 5-HT1F receptor agonist, can be used in this condition as it has no vascular effects, unlike triptans (rizatriptan, sumatriptan).

Stimulation of 5-HT1B/1D receptors can stop an acute migraine attack. Ergotamine and dihydroergotamine are nonselective receptor agonists, whereas triptans are selective 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonists. They act by arresting the nociceptive nerve signaling in the trigeminovascular system. They also act by vasoconstricting, not only the intracranial vessels but other vessels too. Hence it is contraindicated in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD), cerebral vascular accident (CVA) and other vascular problems.

Migraine is the second most common cause of headaches and is seen more commonly in women. It presents as an episodic headache associated with nausea, vomiting, photosensitivity, and sensitivity to sound (phonophobia). Common triggers include bright lights, sounds, and hunger. The release of vasoactive peptides such as calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) by the trigeminal nucleus cells is the theory used to explain the pathogenesis of the condition. The neurotransmitters serotonin and dopamine also play a part.

A migraine attack has four phases: premonitory (prodrome), aura, headache and postdrome; each has distinct and sometimes disabling symptoms, which may overlap.

Migraine can broadly be classified into:

  • Migraine without aura (70-80%): Common migraine.
  • Migraine with aura (20-30%): Classic migraine.

The migraine disability assessment score (MIDAS) can be used to assess the severity of the condition. Avoidance of recognized triggers is helpful to avoid symptoms. The various drugs used to treat an acute attack of migraine are non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), triptans, CGRP Receptor Antagonists (rimegepant), 5-HT1/F receptor agonists (lasmiditan), and dopamine receptor antagonists (domperidone). 

The various FDA-approved drugs used in prophylaxis include propranolol, valproate, topiramate and flunarizine.

Related Pearl: Simplified diagnostic criteria for migraine

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination with no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

At least 2 of the following features:

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at least 1 of the following features:

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

Related Pearl: Trigeminal Autonomic Cephalalgia

Types of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia:

  • Cluster headache
  • Paroxysmal hemicranias
  • Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT)
  • Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks with cranial autonomic features (SUNA)
  • Hemicrania continua

Gender  Males>females Female=Males Female=Males
Character of pain  Stabbing /boring Throbbing pain /stabbing /boring Burning /stabbing/sharp
Severity of pain  Excruciating  Excruciating Severe to excruciating
Site of pain  Orbit, temple Orbit, temple Periorbital
Attack frequency  1-8 /day 1-20/day 3-200/day
Duration 15min-3 hours 2-30 min 5-240seconds
Migraneous feature  Yes  Yes  Yes
Alcohol trigger  Yes No No
Cutaneous trigger No No Yes
Response to indomethacin No Yes No
Abortive treatment

100% oxygen

Prophylaxis

Chronic cluster

  • Lithium
  • Verapamil
  • Methysergide

  • Verapamil

  • Cutaneous trigger is also seen in trigeminal neuralgia, however, trigeminal neuralgia is a separate entity and not a part of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia

questions.text: A researcher wants to survey the general population of a country. For this, he draws the sample in a systematic way so that each portion of the sample represents a corresponding strata of the population. Identify the sampling method used.
questions.solution:
In this study, stratified random sampling method is used where the population is separated into homogenous sub-groups where each group represents a corresponding strata of the population.

Related Pearl: Sampling

1. Simple random sampling

  • In simple random sampling, samples are drawn in such a way that every element in a population has equal chances of being included.
  • Randomness refers to the method of picking the sample and not the outcome.

2. Stratified random sampling

  • In stratified random sampling, the population is first divided into homogeneous groups, or strata. From these strata, random samples are drawn.
  • For example, dividing a population into the strata of men, women, and children and then picking samples randomly from these strata.

3. Cluster sampling

  • In cluster sampling, the population is divided into internally heterogeneous groups. Then a simple random sampling is done of these clusters and taken as the samples.
  • In other words, the clusters are the sampling unit.
  • This is usually done when large-scale simple random sampling or stratified sampling is laborious or expensive.
  • This is the method used in assessing the immunization status of children.
  • Cluster sampling involves a design effect, which is an adjustment to allow for design structure. It aids in the correlation between clusters.
  • Multistage sampling is a form of cluster sampling, where sampling clusters are chosen from the already divided clusters.

4. Systematic random sampling

  • In systematic sampling, there is a systematic pattern to selecting the elements of a sample.
  • For example, every 3rd baby to be born can be selected.

questions.text:
As an epidemiologist, you are assigned to calculate the maternal mortality ratio in your area. Which of the following parameters will you take into account while calculating this ratio?
  1. Total live births
  2. Women in reproductive age group
  3. Deaths due to peripartum infection
  4. Maternal deaths due to road traffic accidents
  5. Deaths due to postpartum haemorrhage
questions.solution:
Total live births and deaths due peripartum infections and postpartum haemorrhage will be taken into account while calculating the maternal mortality ratio (MMR).

MMR = (Number of maternal deaths in a given year / Number of live births in the same area and year) x 1,00,000 (or 1000).

Maternal mortality refers to deaths during pregnancy or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, from causes related to pregnancy. 

Related Pearl: Maternal Mortality Ratio

Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

The main global causes of maternal deaths are severe bleeding, indirect causes (anemia, malaria, heart diseases), infections, unsafe abortions, eclampsia, obstructed labor, and other direct causes like ectopic pregnancy, anesthesia-related complications, etc.

In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

questions.text: A 7-month-old baby was brought with irritability, vomiting, and seizures. The mother reports that he was breastfed for 6 months and cereals and fruit juices were recently introduced into the diet. Upon investigation, which of the following tests will not be positive in this child?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with symptoms occurring after ingesting fruit juices (containing fructose) points to the diagnosis of hereditary fructose intolerance. Here Fructose is excreted in the urine, which gives Benedict's test positive (reducing sugar test), rapid furfural test positive (tests for monosaccharides ), and specifically Seliwanoff's test (distinguish glucose and fructose) positive. The Sakaguchi test is used for detecting the amino acid arginine (containing guanidium group), not carbohydrates like fructose.

Hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI) is due to a deficiency of the enzyme aldolase B. It is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism. This occurs when sucrose (fructose+glucose) is introduced into the diet of infants, usually around 6 months of age.

Defective aldolase B causes the accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate. This will inhibit glycogen phosphorylase and cause glycogen accumulation in the liver and associated hypoglycemia. Patients will present with vomiting, loss of appetite, and failure to thrive. Hepatomegaly and jaundice may occur. If liver damage progresses, death will occur. Withdrawal of fructose from the diet will immediately relieve the symptoms

Seliwanoff's test will distinguish glucose and fructose. The reagent is resorcinol in HCl. 3 ml of the reagent and 0.5 ml of urine are heated for 30 seconds up to a boiling point. A red color indicates the presence of fructose.

Benedict's test detects the excretion of reducing substances in the urine. It is semi-quantitative and the color of the precipitate roughly indicates the concentration of reducing sugar. Urine is boiled with 5 ml of Benedict's reagent for 2 minutes, a blue color indicates the absence of sugar in the urine. The green precipitate means 0.5%, yellow (1%), orange (1.5%), and red indicates 2% or more sugar.

Rapid furfural test: Monosaccharides when treated with concentrated sulphuric acid undergo dehydration. Hexoses like fructose give hydroxymethylfurfural and these furfural derivatives can condense with phenolic compounds to give colored products. This also forms the basis of the Molisch test. 

The image summarizes the metabolic pathways involved in the metabolism of fructose.

The other tests are color reactions used to identify specific amino acid groups. They are summarized in the pearl attached below.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented with cyclical fever and chills for the last 7 days. A peripheral blood smear is shown below which shows Schuffner's dots. What is the likely etiology of this patients disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of fever and chills with the image showing Schuffner's dots in the erythrocyte suggest that P. ovale is the causative agent.

Schuffner's dots are red granules seen on the surface of the trophozoites of P. vivax and P. ovale. It is more evident in P. ovale, it is not always seen in late trophozoites of P. vivax. The infected erythrocytes are enlarged and oval-shaped with fimbriated margins. The schizonts resemble those of P. malariae, except that the erythrocyte is usually oval, with prominent Schuffner's dots and the pigment is darker. 

Other options:

Option A:  Babesia trophozoites appear as intraerythrocytic round or pyriform or ring form. Other distinguishing features are the absence of schizonts and gametocytes and the presence of tetrads/ maltese crosses, which are pathognomic of B. microti or B. duncani.

Option C: Anaplasma causes human granulocytic anaplasmosis. It is transmitted by ticks. Clinical features are fever, headache, and myalgia. Inclusions in granulocytes are seen.

Option D: Erythrocytes in P. falciparum initially will show a marginal ring form known as accole. Binucleate rings (double chromatin) resembling stereo headphones are commonly seen. The infected erythrocyte is normal in size and shows a few brick-red dots known as Maurer's cleft. Basophilic stippling also can be noted. 

The blood smear in P. falciparum will show multiple ring forms in the erythrocytes as shown below.

Note: Maltese crosses are also seen in the urine of a nephrotic syndrome patient too.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is undergoing an insertion of a central venous catheter. During the course of the insertion, he suddenly developed breathlessness and low blood pressure. In what position should this patient be placed in to manage this condition immediately?
questions.solution:
In this given scenario of venous air embolism (VAE), the patient should be placed in the left lateral decubitus position. This prevents the embolised air from entering the left circulation. it can then be aspirated out with a catheter.

 The goal of treatment in VAE is to prevent further air entry, treat the intravascular air and hemodynamic support.

  • The first immediate step is to notify the surgeon to cover the surgical field with a saline-soaked dressing and tilt the table to prevent further air entry. In surgeries done in a sitting position, the jugular venous compression can restrict air entry into chest circulation.
  • Improve patient oxygenation by administration of 100% oxygen. It also reduces embolus volume by eliminating nitrogen. Nitrous oxide should be discontinued even after minor embolic events to prevent the air from reaching left-sided circulation.
  • Air entry to the right side of the heart may be relieved by a partial left lateral decubitus position. Aspiration of air from the right atrium can be tried by the use of a Bunegin-Albin multi-orifice catheter.
  • Maintain optimum fluid status and stabilize the patient with inotropes or pressors if needed.
  • In case of massive VAE with cardiac decompensation, initiate rapid cardiopulmonary resuscitation with chest compression.
  • To decrease the severity of the disease, initiate anticoagulation therapy with heparin. The usage of steroids is controversial as steroids do not have any effect on cytotoxic brain edema resulting from air embolism.

VAE refers to the entrapment of exogenously delivered gas or air into the venous vasculature resulting in systemic effects. It may occur during surgeries like sitting neurological procedures (posterior cranial fossa surgeries), obstetrics, and orthopedic surgeries. Other causes include mechanical insufflation during laparoscopic surgeries, iatrogenic air entry during venous catheterization and dysbarism. 

VAE should be considered when unexplained hypotension or a sudden fall in end-tidal CO2 level occurs intraoperatively in high-risk cases. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the most sensitive device for detecting intracardiac air embolus.

questions.text: A capnograph of a patient is given below. What is the most likely cause of this capnograph?
questions.solution:
The given capnograph shows cardiac oscillations. It can be a normal variant in the pediatric population.

Cardiogenic oscillations are a common feature of capnograms particularly when respiratory rates are low. They cause a ripple or spiked effect at the end of the alveolar plateau and during the downstroke of the capnogram. Mechanism: The beating heart causes the emptying and filling of various parts of the lung with exhaled and fresh air. 

The normal capnograph displays the exhaled CO2 in both the inspiratory and expiratory phases. The expiratory phase is divided into three distinct components:

  • Phase I: exhalation of dead space gas (i.e., partial pressure of CO2, pCO2 ∼0).
  • Phase II: A sharp rise in pCO2 to a plateau indicates the sampling of transitional gas between the airways and alveoli. 
  • Phase III: The plateau region of the capnograph, corresponds to the pCO2 in the alveolar compartment. 
  • Following phase III, a sharp inspiratory downstroke occurs, which is referred to as the beginning of phase 0 or phase IV.

questions.text: Doppler sonography of the umbilical cord is given below. What does this signify?
questions.solution:
Doppler sonography shows two umbilical arteries and one umbilical vein, indicating it is a normal umbilical cord.

A single umbilical artery is the most common aberration of vessel number in the umbilical cord. It indicates an increased risk of congenital malformations in the fetus.

A single umbilical artery is seen in the following conditions: 

  • Twin pregnancy
  • Gestational diabetes/Overt diabetes
  • Epilepsy
  • Oligohydramnios
  • Polyhydramnios
  • Preeclampsia
  • Antepartum hemorrhage 

It is associated with other conditions such as:

  • Congenital malformation of the fetus
  • Renal and genital anomalies
  • Trisomy 18

Risks:

  • Increased chance of abortion
  • Fetal aneuploidy
  • Prematurity
  • IUGR
  • Increased perinatal mortality

The following doppler image shows a single umbilical artery

In the velamentous placenta, the cord is attached to the membranes. The cord vessels traverse between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta. If the leash of blood vessels traverses through the membranes overlying the internal os, in front of the presenting part, the condition is called vasa previa. The rupture of the membranes involving the overlying vessels leads to vaginal bleeding and fetal exsanguination.

questions.text: In which of the following cases will you advise the mother to hold her baby in the method shown below, immediately after delivery?

choices.text: Baby born at 34 weeks of gestation with birth weight of 1.2kg
Hemodynamically stable term baby with birth weight of 2.8 kg
Hemodynamically unstable preterm with birth weight of 2 kg
Baby born at 33 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 2 kg

questions.solution:
The image shows Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) can be done in a baby born at 33 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 2 kg.

KMC was introduced for the prevention of neonatal hypothermia in low birth weight/ premature newborns.

Eligibility criteria for KMC:

It is indicated for all hemodynamically stable low birth weight babies (option C). Short sessions of KMC can be initiated in babies on medical treatment like IV fluids or oxygen therapy. Initiation of KMC can vary with the birth weight of the baby.

  • Birth weight <1200 g - It may take days to weeks for initiation of KMC (Option A)
  • Birth weight =1200-1800 g - Only a few days may be taken before KMC initiation
  • Birth weight >1800 g - KMC can be initiated immediately after birth

It has 4 components—

  • Skin-to-skin positioning of the newborn on the mother’s chest.
  • Adequate nutrition through breastfeeding.
  • Early discharge and ambulatory care.
  • Support for mother and family for child care.

Evidence shows that-

  • It is at least equivalent to incubators, in terms of safety and thermal protection (measured by mortality)
  • Reduces severe morbidity by way of facilitating breastfeeding
  • Humanization of neonatal care
  • Promoted bonding between mother and child

All mothers without any serious illness can provide KMC.

Positioning for KMC: The baby is placed between the mother's breasts in an upright position. The hips are abducted and flexed in the frog position and the arms are also flexed. The abdomen of the baby should be at the level of the mother's epigastrium. In this position, the mother's breathing would stimulate the baby and prevent the development of apnea.

The duration of KMC should be gradually increased from short sessions of more than one hour to 24 hours a day.

KMC is not necessary once the baby attains 2500 g of weight or 37 weeks of gestation (Option B).

Note: 

Incubatory care, feeding via nasal catheter, and prevention of infection are part of intensive care for low birthweight babies.

questions.text: A forensic pathologist is examining a venous specimen to look for the presence of antemortem clots. Microscopy reveals laminations with alternating light and dark bands. What are these laminations called?
questions.solution:
The laminations in the thrombus are called lines of Zahn.

Lines of Zahn are characteristic of thrombi that appear in blood vessels, very commonly in veins. These laminations or striae can be seen either macroscopically, in large vessels, or microscopically in smaller ones, as they form alternating light and dark bands. The light bands are composed of platelets and fibrin while the darker bands are referred to as red-cell-rich because they are composed of erythrocytes.

The presence of lines of Zahn helps to distinguish between antemortem and postmortem clots. They are present in antemortem clots as they are formed in the flowing blood.

Postmortem clots are usually bland and nonlaminated clots. They are gelatinous and have a lower dark red portion which is erythrocyte rich, formed as a result of gravitation of these erythrocytes and a yellow "chicken fat"  upper portion, that is not attached to the vessel wall.

The following image shows the lines of Zahn.

Other options:

Option A: Psammoma bodies are foci of dystrophic calcification. Necrotic cells form the focus for surrounding calcific deposition. They have a lamellated concentric calcified structure. Psammoma bodies are found in various tumors such as papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, meningioma, and serous cystadenoma of the ovary.

Option B: Hemosiderin is a hemoglobin-derived, yellowish-brown granular or crystalline pigment. In the body, iron is stored along with apoferritin to form ferritin micelles. However, when there is excessive iron present, ferritin forms hemosiderin granules, which may be observed in the mononuclear phagocytes of bone marrow, spleen, and liver.

The image below shows hemosiderin pigment within the alveolar macrophages in the lung.

Option D: Lipofuscin granules are insoluble brownish-yellow granular intracellular materials that are representative of complexes of lipid and protein, produced by polyunsaturated lipids which undergo free radical–catalyzed peroxidation. They accumulate in many tissues like the heart, liver, and brain, and are seen with aging or atrophy. It is indicative of past free radical injury. If the brown pigment is present in large amounts, it gives an appearance to the tissue called "brown atrophy".

The image below shows cardiac myocytes with lipofuscin granules in the perinuclear region.

questions.text: One year ago, a 60-year-old man was diagnosed with pancreatic adenocarcinoma and treated for it. At present, on further evaluation of this patient, you suspect him to have Trousseau’s syndrome. Which of the following features helped you come to this diagnosis?

choices.text: Recurrent episodes of localised thrombosis of the superficial veins of limbs
Enlargement of the left supraclavicular lymph node
Contraction facial muscles on tapping over facial nerve in front of the tragus of the ear.
Painful carpopedal spasm on applying inflated sphygmomanometer cuff above the systolic blood pressure.

questions.solution:
The coexistence of recurrent episodes of localised thrombosis of the superficial veins of limbs(migratory thrombophlebitis) with visceral carcinoma, particularly pancreatic cancer, is called Trousseau’s syndrome.

It is a paraneoplastic syndrome, also known as Trousseau's sign of malignancy, and is attributed to the production of platelet-aggregating factors and procoagulants from the tumour or its necrotic products. Both venous and arterial thrombi can occur.

Migratory thrombophlebitis is seen in: 

  • Pancreatic cancer (most common)
  • Lung cancer
  • Gastrointestinal cancer
  • Ovarian cancer
  • Prostate cancer
  • Lymphoma

Other options:

Option B: Troisier sign is the clinical finding of a hard and enlarged left supraclavicular node (Virchow node), and is considered a sign of metastatic abdominal malignancy.

Option C: Chvostek sign is contraction of facial muscles on tapping over the facial nerve in front of the tragus of the ear.

Option D: Trousseau sign is accoucheur’s hand position which is a painful carpopedal spasm on applying a sphygmomanometer cuff to the arm and keeping the pressure above systolic blood pressure for 5 minutes.

Both Chvostek and Trousseau signs are seen in hypocalcemic tetany. Image showing Trousseau sign:

questions.text: A patient with Crohn's disease who underwent multiple sequential ileal resections and removal of his terminal ileum and proximal cecum presents with bloating, flatulence, and watery diarrhea. The lactulose breath test shows a higher-than-normal reading after 1 hour.  Which of the following is the cause of his symptoms?

choices.text: Resection of the ileo cecal valve

questions.solution:
Multiple sequential ileal resections, typical of patients with Crohn’s disease can cause short bowel syndrome (<150 cm of the residual small bowel). Flatulence, diarrhea, and a higher than normal concentration of Hydrogen on lactulose breath test make small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO) the most likely diagnosis. Resection of the ileocecal valve is the probable cause of his symptoms as it removes the barrier between the small and large bowel allowing for the colonic bacteria to colonise the small intestine. 

Massive intestinal resection (<150 cm of the residual small bowel) results in metabolic and nutritional consequences, is known as short bowel syndrome.

Complications of short bowel syndrome include:

  • Diarrhea (due to hypergastrinemia and gastric hypersecretion, SIBO or unabsorbed bile salts in the colon)
  • Steatorrhea (due to the depletion of the bile salt pool)
  • Gallstones (due to interruption of the enterohepatic cycle of bile salts)
  • Renal stones (due to increased absorption of oxalate in the colon).

SIBO is a condition characterized by overgrowth of bacteria in the small bowel. this can lead to bloating, flatulence, and secretory diarrhea.

Risk factors for SIBO:

  • Surgically created blind loops
  • Short bowel syndrome
  • Decreased intestinal motility
  • Resection of ileocecal valve
  • Type 2 diabetes mellitus
  • Decreased gastric acid secretion

Diagnosis is by small bowel cultures or Lactulose hydrogen breath test which shows more than 20ppm of hydrogen. Treatment is with an antibiotic like rifaximin. 

Other Options: 

Option A: Bile irritation to the intestinal walls presents with secretory diarrhoea that occurs even at night. However, the presence of a positive lactulose hydrogen breath test makes SIBO more likely in this case.

Option C: Dumping syndrome occurs in patients post Roux en Y jejunal bypass due to direct bypass to the jejunum which leads to symptoms of bloating and abdominal pain. However a positive lactulose hydrogen breath test makes SIBO more likely in this case.

Option D: Increased colonic motility is protective and decreases the incidence of SIBO.

questions.text: You were posted for an autopsy of a 32-year-old man who was murdered by a serial killer. On examination, a fracture caused by a blow with a hammer was found in the skull as shown below. What is the type of fracture called?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image given above are suggestive of a depressed fracture.

A depressed fracture is caused by blows from a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. It is also called a signature fracture as the pattern of fracture resembles the weapon or object used. 

Closer examination of the injury will reveal that the outer table is driven into the diploe, and the inner table has irregular fractures or may be comminuted. 

The depth of the fracture varies according to the velocity with which the impact is delivered. When a hammer is used, the fracture is circular or in the shape of an arc of a circle. The diameter of the fracture is the same as the striking surface. There are generally no radiating linear fractures. 

Other options:

Option A - Comminuted fractures are caused by a greater intensity force striking over a broad area such as crushing head injuries, repeated blows by weapons with a large striking area, or falling from height. In a comminuted fracture, there will be two or more intersecting lines of fracture which divide the bone into three or more fragments. 

Option B - Pond fracture is also known as an indented fracture. This is a dent in the skull. They are caused by an obstetric forceps blade, a blow from a blunt object, etc. They occur only in the infant skulls.

Option C - Gutter fractures occur mainly in oblique bullet wounds as it removes a part of the thickness of the bone.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture/ sutural fracture - It involves the separation of sutures due to blow with a blunt weapon or from cerebral edema.

Fissured fracture/ linear fracture:

  • They are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture/ indented fracture - It occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. 

Depressed fracture/ signature fracture - It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced (signature fracture).

Comminuted fracture/ spider-web fracture - It has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of the fracture.

Ring fracture - It is usually caused due to a fall from height landing on feet. These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old boy presented with yellowish discoloration of the skin and sclerae for the last 3 days. He is otherwise asymptomatic. He had a viral fever one week ago which has now resolved. His investigations are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Serum bilirubin: 2.4 mg/dL
Unconjugated bilirubin: 2.1mg/dL
Conjugated bilirubin: 0.3mg/dL
Serum AST and ALT: Normal
questions.solution:
This patient has a short history of jaundice, which appeared only during a period of stress (viral fever). The lab reports show increased unconjugated bilirubin (normal 0.2-0.8 mg/dL) and normal AST and ALT levels. All this points toward a diagnosis of Gilbert syndrome.

Gilbert syndrome is a benign, familial disorder characterized by mild intermittent jaundice usually seen during stress, fatigue, or alcohol use. The condition is recognized to arise from a mutation in the promoter region of the UGT1A1 gene, which results in mildly decreased UDP-glucuronyltransferase production. This causes a reduction in the liver's ability to conjugate bilirubin, thus causing unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The total bilirubin value is usually < 3 mg/dL. 

Other options:

Option A: Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign disease that is characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and bilirubinuria. Patients are asymptomatic and other laboratory tests are normal. Liver biopsy shows characteristic deposition of black-colored pigment in the lysosomes of the centrilobular hepatocytes.

Option B: Rotor syndrome is similar to Dubin-Johnson syndrome but has a milder presentation. Conjugated bilirubin levels are elevated. The liver biopsy does not show pigment deposition.

Option D: Crigler-Najjar syndrome is another syndrome that has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is of two types, with type 1 having absent/trace UDP-glucoronyltransferase production and type 2 having <10% of the normal enzyme activity. Type 1 is far more severe and leads to kernicterus and neurological damage in infancy.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man with a history of drug usage that comes in a  colorful graphic blotting paper presents to the OPD with visual perception changes. He says the episodes last seconds to minutes and have recurred for the past 4 months. Which drugs did he most likely consume and what other drug can cause similar symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) abuse which is consumed on colorful graphic blotting paper and the patient experiences flashback phenomenon with recurrent visual perception changes lasting for seconds to minutes. Another drug that can cause similar findings is Psilocybin which is present in 'magic mushrooms'. 

LSD is the most powerful hallucinogen known to man. Increased sympathetic activity like tachycardia, hypertension, pupillary dilation, tremor, and fever can be seen within minutes of oral intake. Apart from this, the users may have psychiatric symptoms like visual illusions, extreme changes in mood, paranoid delusions, etc.

Patients may experience bad trips, where they have panic episodes. Prolonged experience without further exposure to drugs known as “flashbacks" can also result from LSD use. Flashbacks are defined as episodic recurrences of drug effects after the acute pharmacological effects have subsided and are very transient. This syndrome is diagnosed as a hallucinogen persisting perception disorder according to DSM-5.

Stopping the drug abruptly after continued use does not produce withdrawal symptoms. Management of bad trips due to LSD abuse involves supportive treatment with anxiolytics.

Other drugs that can cause flashback phenomenon include Dimethyltryptamine (DMT), magic mushrooms(Psilocybin), and mescaline.

Other options-

Option A: cannabis, Option B: alcohol and Option D: cocaine have no association with flash back phenomenon.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old man with known hypertension was brought to the casualty. He had headaches, nausea, vertigo, right-sided hemiparesis, and aphasia. His CT scan is shown below. On detailed evaluation, intraventricular hemorrhage was found to be present, with hematoma of volume 32 cc and no evidence of infratentorial origin. GCS score was calculated to be 8. Calculate the ICH score.

ICH: Intracerebral hemorrhage
questions.solution:
The Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) score for the above clinical scenario is 4. ( Age 80 years: 1; Hematoma volume >30 cc: 1; Intraventricular hemorrhage present: 1; Infratentorial origin absent: 0; Glassgow coma scale score 5 to 12: 1)

ICH Score (maximum score: 6)

Parameter Value Score
Age < 80 years 0
≥80 years 1
Hematoma Volume <30 ccs 0
≥30 ccs 1
Intraventricular hemorrhage present  No 0
Yes 1
Infratentorial origin of hemorrhage  No 0
Yes 1
Glasgow Coma Scale score  13 to 15 0
5 to 12 1
3 to 4 2

The given CT image shows a left-sided rapidly expanding hyperdense lesion that causes a midline shift and is indicative of acute ICH.

ICH (bleeding into the brain tissue) is the second most common cause of stroke (15–30% of strokes) and the most deadly.

Risk factors of ICH: 

  • Hypertension: Chronic high BP
  • Age: More common after the age of 55 years, with the buildup of protein in walls of arteries, called amyloid angiopathy
  • Gender: More common in men.
  • Race: Affects African Americans and Asians more than whites, possibly due to the higher prevalence of hypertension in these races
  • Previous history of stroke: Increases risk 23 times
  • Alcohol use and street drugs: Cocaine and amphetamines increase risk.
  • Liver disease: Increases risk due to issues with blood clotting
  • The primary brain causes: Tumors, vascular anomalies, infection, and venous sinus thrombosis

Treatment:

Non-surgical: 

  • Clotting factor administration, if the patient was on blood thinners;
  • Blood pressure control to reduce the risk of more bleeding; and
  • Measuring and controlling ICP (pressure on brain tissue due to clot) 

Surgical: 

  • Stereotactic clot aspiration
  • Craniotomy, followed by clot removal

Below is a CT image of acute ICH.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 30 year old male patient comes to the casualty after a hike in a reserved forest after he found an insect bite on his thigh. Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by this organism?
questions.solution:
The given image is of a human body louse, Pediculus humanus corporis. Rocky Mountain spotted fever is not spread by lice.

Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF) is caused by Rickettsia rickettsii transmitted through the bite of a dermacentor tick (hard tick). Patients present with fever, headache, myalgia, and centripetally distributed rashes over palms and soles. 

The most common serologic test for the diagnosis is the indirect immunofluorescence assay. Weil-Felix reaction is usually positive in RMSF because the antibodies against Rickettsia react with Proteus antigens. The drug of choice for the treatment of both children and adults with RMSF is doxycycline.
