questions.text:
A 50-year-old female presented with multiple joint pains and easy fatiguability. On examination, the following finding was seen. An X-ray was performed and is given below. Her lab findings are shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?

 

Lab Investigations

  • MCV - 80 fl (Normal: 87-96 fl)
  • ESR after 1 hour - 80mm
  • Serum Iron - 45 μg/dl (Normal - 50-150 μg/dl)
  • TIBC - 250 μg/dl (Normal -300-360 μg/dl)
  • Transferrin Saturation - 11 % (Normal:30-50%)
  • Serum Ferritin - 185 μg/L (Normal:50-200)
  • RA factor - strongly positive
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the image shows swan neck deformity with low MCV, low TIBC, and low transferrin saturation pointing towards the diagnosis of anemia of chronic disease secondary to Rheumatoid Arthritis. 

The chronic illnesses associated with  anemia of chronic disease can be grouped into three categories:

  1. Chronic microbial infections, such as osteomyelitis, bacterial endocarditis, and lung abscess
  2. Chronic immune disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis and regional enteritis
  3. Neoplasms, such as carcinomas of the lung and breast and Hodgkin lymphoma

Interleukin-6 (IL-6), stimulates an increase in the hepatic production of hepcidin. Hepcidin inhibits ferroportin function in macrophages and reduces the transfer of iron from the storage pool to developing erythroid precursors in the bone marrow.

Erythropoietin levels are inappropriately low for the degree of anemia.

Other options:

Option A - Serum ferritin and TIBC can be used to distinguish iron deficiency anemia from anemia of chronic disease. Iron deficiency anemia will have low serum ferritin. Additionally, high TIBC and low transferrin saturation may be seen in iron deficiency anemia.

Options C & D- Sideroblastic anemia and thalassemia will have a normal TIBC with a normal to high transferrin saturation.

questions.text: A patient with bronchogenic carcinoma presents to the OPD complaining of hoarseness of voice. On laryngoscopy, you notice that the left vocal cord is in the paramedian position and you start the patient on speech therapy. Which of the following muscles of the larynx is not affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given image-

  1. Lateral cricoarytenoid muscle
  2. Transverse arytenoid muscle
  3. Posterior cricoarytenoid muscle
  4. Cricothyroid muscle.

The given case scenario is of unilateral vocal cord palsy secondary to bronchogenic carcinoma which is an important cause of left recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis. Cricothyroid muscle is not affected in this condition.

All the intrinsic muscles of the larynx except for the cricothyroid are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve. Cricothyroid, a tensor of the vocal cord, present between the cricoid and thyroid cartilage, is supplied by the external laryngeal nerve which is a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.

In unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy, the affected vocal cord assumes a median or paramedian position and does not move laterally on deep inspiration.

One-third of the patients are asymptomatic while the others have some change in voice but no problems with airway obstruction. The voice in unilateral paralysis gradually improves due to compensation by the healthy cord which crosses the midline to meet the paralysed one.

Treatment includes speech therapy, injection laryngoplasty (materials used - autologous fat, carboxymethylcellulose) and thyroplasty type I (medialization thyroplasty).

The lateral cricoarytenoid and transverse arytenoid muscles are adductors of the vocal cord and posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is an abductor of the vocal cord.

questions.text: The dens of the axis vertebra is attached to which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
In the given image of the atlas vertebra (CI), the area marked 4 is the posterior surface of the anterior arch which gives attachment to the apex of dens from the axis vertebra (CII).

The major distinguishing feature of the atlas vertebra is that it lacks a vertebral body. During development, the vertebral body of CI fuses onto the body of CII during development to become the dens of CII.

Features of the atlas vertebra (CI):

  • No vertebral body
  • 2 lateral masses - with upper and lower articular facets
  • 2 arches- anterior and posterior arches 
  • 2 large transverse processes
  • The area marked 1 is the posterior tubercle which gives attachment to ligamentum nuchae.
  • The area marked 2 is the posterior arch. The superior surface bears a groove for the vertebral artery and its inferior border gives attachment to ligamentum flavum.
  • The area marked 3 is the superior articular facet.

questions.text: A 20-year-old primigravida in her third trimester is brought to the ER in an altered state of consciousness. Lab tests reveal elevated AST, ALT, and bilirubin, while a liver biopsy shows microvesicular fatty infiltration. Which enzyme deficiency is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The mother has acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP), which is associated with long-chain 3-hydroxyacyl CoA dehydrogenase (3-LCHAD) deficiency. This enzyme is involved in the beta-oxidation of fatty acids.

Women who develop AFLP have heterozygous mutations in the recessive gene for 3-LCHAD. The beta-oxidation capacity is reduced, but patients are asymptomatic outside pregnancy. AFLP develops when such women become pregnant with a fetus homozygous for the 3-LHCAD mutation. The fetus is unable to oxidize fatty acids, which then enter the maternal circulation. These fatty acids overwhelm the maternal oxidation capacity and cause acute fatty liver of pregnancy.

Liver function tests such as AST, ALT, and serum bilirubin levels are raised. Biopsy reveals a characteristic microvesicular fatty infiltration. Fulminant liver failure can lead to hepatic encephalopathy.

questions.text: A 10-month-old boy who is a known case of cerebral palsy, was brought to the OPD for a routine check-up. On examination you notice that the child does not use the normal 4-limbed crawling movement, instead, he uses his arms in a normal reciprocal fashion but tends to drag both legs while crawling. Brain MRI shows scarring and shrinkage in the periventricular white matter. Identify the subtype of the disease mentioned above.
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a child who uses his arms in a normal reciprocal fashion but tends to drag both legs while crawling (commando crawling) and brain MRI showing scarring and shrinkage in the periventricular white matter (periventricular leukomalacia) is highly suggestive of spastic diplegia type of cerebral palsy.

Cerebral palsy (CP) is a diagnostic term used to describe a group of permanent disorders of movement and posture causing activity limitation that is attributed to nonprogressive disturbances in the developing fetal or infant brain. It is the most common cause of motor disability in childhood. 

The subtypes of cerebral palsy and the pathology involved are given below:

Cerebral palsy subtype Pathology
Spastic diplegia Periventricular leukomalacia
Spastic quadriplegia Multi-cystic encephalomalacia
Spastic hemiplegia Middle cerebral artery territory infarction
Dyskinetic cerebral palsy Basal ganglia

 

Spastic diplegia is more commonly seen in premature infants with a history of birth asphyxia due to damage to immature white matter. It is 2nd most common type of cerebral palsy in India after spastic quadriplegia. Both the lower limbs are involved. During development, characteristic commando crawling is seen. Brain MRI shows scarring and shrinkage in the periventricular white matter with compensatory enlargement of the cerebral ventricles. IQ of these children is usually normal and has a good prognosis. 

In older children, a scissoring gait is characterized by the knees and thighs pressed together or crossing each other while walking, caused by high muscle tone (spasticity) in the hip adductors.

Spastic hemiplegia affects one-half of the body (upper and lower limbs on the same side). It is seen due to vascular insult leading to perinatal stroke event. Early hand preference is seen (before 1 year), where one side of the body is always preferred as the other side is weak. MRI shows focal changes and porencephalic cysts due to infarcts. 

Spastic quadriplegia is associated with ischemia of the brain and infections. MRI would reveal severe periventricular leukomalacia and multicystic cortical encephalomalacia.

Dyskinetic/ Extrapyramidal CP is more commonly seen in term infants. It is likely to be associated with birth asphyxia and kernicterus in the early neonatal period. The upper limb is affected more than the lower limb. Brain MRI reveals lesions in the basal ganglia and thalamus.

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravida who conceived after in-vitro fertilization therapy came for an antenatal checkup at 38 weeks of gestation. Her obstetric history revealed that she was pregnant with dichorionic diamniotic twins. On examination, the first twin was found to be in a vertex position and the second twin was found to be in a breech position. Maternal blood pressure was found to be greater than 140/90 mm Hg on two occasions with grade 2+ proteinuria. The fetal non-stress test was reassuring. What is the ideal next step in management?

choices.text: Monitor BP and terminate pregnancy if BP rises
Expectant management upto 40 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
In the given scenario of a patient with pre-eclampsia and twin gestation at 38 weeks of gestation, induction of labour is the ideal next step in management.

The ACOG recommends termination of pregnancy at 38 weeks of pregnancy in dichorionic gestations. Normal vaginal delivery is preferred as the first twin is in a vertex position. The second twin may be delivered through an assisted breech delivery. Additionally, pre-eclampsia necessitates termination of pregnancy beyond 37 weeks of gestation.

Diagnostic criteria of pre-eclampsia

It is defined as:

  • New-onset hypertension
    • mild: BP >140/90 mmHg on two occasions at least 4 h apart after 20 weeks of gestation in a previously normotensive patient.
    • severe: BP >160/110 mmHg on two occasions at least 4 h apart after 20 weeks of gestation in a previously normotensive patient.
  • And proteinuria
    • >300 mg/24 h or
    • Protein:creatinine ratio >0.3 or
    • Urine dipstick 2+
  • In the absence of proteinuria, it is defined as new-onset hypertension with any one of the following
    • Thrombocytopenia (PLT <1,00,000/mm3)
    • Renal insufficiency
    • Impaired liver function
    • Pulmonary edema
    • Headache or visual symptoms.

Management of hypertension in pregnancy

  • Begin anti-hypertensives when BP >160/110 mmHg
    • Labetalol
    • Nifedipine
    • Methyl-dopa
    • Hydralazine.
  • Definitive management is the termination of pregnancy
    • Mode - Vaginal delivery. C-section is indicated only for obstetric reasons.
    • Timing
      • Mild pre-eclampsia >37 weeks
      • Severe pre-eclampsia >34 weeks.

Other options

Option D - Cesarean section would be preferred if the first twin is in a breech position. An attempted vaginal delivery can cause locking of the fetuses, trapping of the fetal head above the cervix and umbilical cord prolapse.

questions.text:
Five months ago, a 55-year-old patient of yours presented to the OPD with complaints of dry mouth and difficulty in swallowing with positive serum anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies, following which you started her on treatment. Her recent blood investigations show elevated GGT and ALP levels and liver biopsy shows characteristic florid duct lesion. What is the most likely diagnosis?

GGT - Gamma-glutamyltransferase

ALP - Alkaline phosphatasee
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the initial presentation of dry mouth, difficulty in swallowing and positive serum anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies points to the diagnosis of Sjögren's syndrome. Based on the patient's current laboratory findings and liver biopsy showing characteristic florid duct lesion, the patient has developed Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), which is an extraglandular (systemic) manifestation of Sjögren's syndrome.

Sjögren’s syndrome is a prototype autoimmune disease, commonly seen in women aged 50-60 years, characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of the exocrine glands resulting in xerostomia, dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca), and profound B-cell hyperactivity.  

They present with a blurring of vision, burning, itching of the eyes, difficulty swallowing solid foods, dryness of the buccal mucosa, and parotid gland enlargement. 

Antibodies directed against two ribonucleoprotein antigens -SS-A (Ro) and SS-B (La) are detected in almost all patients with Sjogren's syndrome. The extra glandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome are:

  • Arthralgia or arthritis - It is usually non-erosive and leads to Jaccoud's arthropathy.
  • Raynaud's phenomenon
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Interstitial lung disease - most common type is non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
  • Renal tubular acidosis - Type 1 (distal) RTA

Primary biliary cirrhosis(PBC) is an autoimmune destructive condition of the small and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts, commonly seen in women aged 40-50 years. Clinical features of PBC include fatigue, debilitating pruritus and hyperpigmentation.

GGT and ALP are significantly elevated with only mild elevation of AST and ALT enzymes. About 90% of the patients will have anti-mitochondrial antibodies. 

Biopsy of the liver shows a florid duct lesion (as given in the image). This is due to the destruction of interlobular bile ducts with lymphoplasmacytic inflammation with or without granuloma formation. 

Option A: Primary sclerosing cholangitis presents with fatigue, pruritus, and steatorrhea similar to PBC. It is more common in men in the 3-5th decade. It is characterized by diffuse inflammation and fibrosis of intra and extrahepatic ducts. The perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (p-ANCA), is positive and anti-mitochondrial antibodies is negative. Liver biopsy shows concentric "onion-skin" fibrosis. 

Option B: Primary ascending cholangitis is a life-threatening condition caused by an ascending bacterial infection of the intra- and extrahepatic ducts with secondary blockage of the biliary tracts. It affects both men and women aged 50 to 60 years. Charcot triad describes cholangitis as clinical findings of fever, right upper abdominal pain, and jaundice.

Liver biopsy shows cholestasis within the hepatic parenchyma and neutrophils involving the bile duct lumen. 

Option D: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is defined as the presence of hepatic steatosis in individuals who do not consume alcohol or do so in small quantities. Histopathological diagnosis requires steatosis (≥5% of hepatocytes), lobular inflammation, and ballooned hepatocytes. The ratio (AST/ALT) is less than 1. GGT, when elevated, can be a marker of increased mortality.

Related Pearl: Extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome

The extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome are as follows:

  • Non-specific
    • Arthralgia or arthritis - It is the most common extraglandular manifestation. It is usually non-erosive and leads to Jacoud’s arthropathy
    • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Accumulation of peri-epithelial lymphocytes
    • Interstitial lung disease - Most common type is non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
    • Renal tubular acidosis - Distal (type 1) RTA
    • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Immune complex-mediated
    • Small vessel vasculitis - Presents as cutaneous palpable purpura
    • Glomerulonephritis with cryoglobulinemia
    • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Lymphoma
    • Extranodal marginal zone B cell lymphoma of mucosal-associated lymphoid tissue (MALToma).

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man is diagnosed with lower esophageal carcinoma. CECT shows an enlarged right paratracheal lymph node and he is taken up for surgery. On doing a PET-CT scan, symmetrical uptake of 18-FDG is seen in both supraclavicular areas with no uptake in the right paratracheal lymph node. What is the most likely explanation for this finding?

CECT (Contrast-enhanced CT)

PET-CT (Positron emission tomography-CT)

18-FDG (18F-fluorodeoxyglucose)
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, symmetrical uptake of 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (18-FDG) in both the supraclavicular areas is suggestive of brown adipose tissue.

FDG uptake in hyper-metabolic brown adipose tissue is well recognized as a potential source of false positives in PET-CT imaging. The typical distribution of brown fat in a bilaterally symmetric pattern in the supraclavicular and neck regions can be confused with malignancy.

PET-CT scan is a hybrid technique that combines PET and CT scan that is used as an excellent clinical tool in the diagnosis, staging and restaging of cancer. 18-FDG (a glucose analogue) is taken up by cells via glucose transporter proteins and undergoes phosphorylation by hexokinase to FDG-6 phosphate. Unlike glucose, FDG-phosphate does not undergo further metabolism and gets trapped in the cell.

18-FDG also accumulates in normal tissue and other non-malignant conditions, and some malignancies do not take up 18-FDG or have a low affinity for the tracer, leading to false-positive and false-negative interpretations.

Causes of false positive FDG PET scan:

  • In tissues with high metabolism like brown adipose tissue
  • Infectious and inflammatory lesions
  • Adrenal endothelial cyst

Causes of false negative FDG PET scan:

  • Size of tumour <1 cm
  • Bronchoalveolar carcinoma (adenocarcinoma in situ), carcinoid tumour (typical > atypical). The low metabolic rate of tumours makes the tumour negative (showing reduced uptake) on an FDG PET scan.

The main advantage of PET-CT is the identification of distant metastatic disease not seen on CT alone. The disadvantages of PET scans are radiation burden, poorer spatial resolution when used alone, and high cost.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient is being administered morphine for pain control. However, he develops constipation subsequently. Which of the following drugs can be used to manage his constipation?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient develops constipation following administration of opioids and the most suitable drug for the management of constipation is naloxegol as it is a peripherally acting opioid antagonist.

Naloxegol is an opioid receptor antagonist. It is similar structurally to naltrexone but does not cross the blood-brain barrier. As a result, naloxegol reverses the peripheral effects of opiates like constipation by increasing spontaneous bowel movement frequency. It does not interfere with the central nervous system effects of opiates, such as pain relief.

Its side effects include abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, flatulence, anxiety, restlessness, and sweating. Withdrawal symptoms can occur upon discontinuation of the drug. In patients not on opioid therapy, naloxegol has minimal effects on constipation. It. can also give rise to hypersensitivity reactions and gastrointestinal perforation.

Other peripherally acting opioid antagonists include:

  • Methylnaltrexone
  • Naldemedine
  • Alvimopan

Other options:

Options A and D: Naltrexone and naloxone are opioid receptor antagonists that are used in the management of morphine poisoning. They act centrally.

Option C: Loperamide is an opioid receptor agonist. It decreases bowel motility and intestinal secretions. Fecal continence is improved by enhancement of anal sphincter tone.

questions.text: An elderly male presents with an autosomal dominant syndrome, where the gene responsible for the illness is found on chromosome 3p and acts as an inhibitor of hypoxia-induced transcription factors. Which of the following features will this patient present with?

choices.text: Renal cell carcinoma, hemangioblastomas of the CNS and retina, pheochromocytoma
Neurofibromas, neurofibrosarcoma, acute myelogenous leukemia, brain tumors
Pancreatic islet cell tumors, parathyroid hyperplasia, pituitary adenomas
Gastrointestinal carcinomas, breast cancer, testicular cancer, benign pigmentation of the skin and mucosa

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Von Hippel Lindau's syndrome caused due to germline loss-of-function mutations of the VHL gene present on chromosome 3p that acts as an inhibitor of hypoxia-induced transcription factors. It is an autosomal dominant syndrome where the patient will present with renal cell carcinoma (clear cell type), hemangioblastomas of the CNS and retina and pheochromocytoma.

Mutations in the VHL gene, prevent the ubiquitination and degradation of hypoxia-inducible transcription factor 1α (HIF1α), even under normoxic conditions, and are accordingly associated with increased levels of angiogenic growth factors and alterations in cellular metabolism that favour tumour cell growth.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman undergoing treatment for pulmonary tuberculosis develops resistance to isoniazid. What is the most common mechanism by which this occurs?
questions.solution:
The most common mechanism of resistance to isoniazid (INH) in clinical isolates of Mycobacterium tuberculosis is by a mutation in the KatG gene.

Isoniazid (INH) is used as chemotherapy for drug-susceptible TB. It is given in combination with pyrazinamide, ethambutol, and rifampin. 

Isoniazid is not directly toxic to mycobacteria but gets activated to its toxic form by KatG, which is a catalase-peroxidase. A series of reactions occur which ultimately causes inhibition of mycolic acid synthesis, which leads to bacterial cell death.

Resistance to INH occurs by the following mechanisms:

  • Mutation of KatG - most common mechanism
  • Overexpression of inhA genes- confers a low level of resistance
  • Overexpression of ahpC
  • Induction of efflux pumps

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman presented with a 1-year history of worsening headaches and one episode of focal seizures recently. Imaging reveals a cortical calcified mass in the left cerebral hemisphere. The histopathological image is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?

IDH- Isocitrate dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario presence of cortical calcified mass in the left cerebral hemisphere with histopathology revealing a chicken-wire pattern and fried egg appearance is suggestive of oligodendroglioma.

In the given histopathological image there are regular sheets of tumor cells with spherical nuclei surrounded by a perinuclear halo termed fried egg appearance. The network of thin branched capillary-sized vessels shows a "chicken-wire" pattern in appearance. The cells that infiltrate the brain may collect around the neurons. This is called perineural satellitosis.

Oligodendroglioma is an infiltrating glioma composed of cells resembling oligodendrocytes. It is associated with mutations in IDH and deletion of chromosomes 1p and 19q.

Most commonly oligodendrogliomas are detected in the fourth and fifth decades of life. Patients may have had several years of antecedent neurologic complaints, often including seizures. The lesions are found mostly in the cerebral hemispheres, with a pre­dilection for white matter. The imaging may show the presence of cortical mass with calcifications.

Management includes a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy.

Related Pearl: Most commons of Brain tumours

Most common tumor of the brain - Metastasis secondary to lungs > breast

Most common primary CNS tumor - glioma > meningioma

Most common primary CNS tumor in children - pilocytic astrocytoma

Most common primary CNS tumor in adults - astrocytoma

Most common primary malignant tumor of the brain in children - medulloblastoma

Most common primary malignant tumor of the brain in adults - glioblastoma

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presented with dysphagia and postprandial chest pain. A barium swallow image is shown below. Which of the following statements is true regarding the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: It is associated with hiatus hernia
Most commonly seen in middle third of esophagus

questions.solution:
The given barium swallow showing a thin submucosal circumferential ring at the squamocolumnar junction is suggestive of Schatzki's ring. The true statement regarding the condition is, that it is associated with hiatus hernia.

Schatzki’s ring is a thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction. Schatzki's ring is a non-malignant condition and is often associated with a hiatal hernia. The patient experiences brief episodes of dysphagia during the hurried ingestion of solid foods.

The presence of a ring in the esophagus, with or without hiatal hernia, can be visualized on barium swallow.

For symptomatic patients who do not have reflux, the best form of treatment consists of esophageal dilation for relief of the obstructive symptoms. In patients who have proven reflux and a mechanically defective sphincter, an antireflux procedure is done to obtain relief and avoid repeated dilation.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient comes with complaints of increasing low back pain since 2 weeks. She has no history of falls. She has exquisite tenderness over the L5 vertebra but has no neurological deficit. What else would be indicated in this patient apart from pain control?
questions.solution:
This post-menopausal patient presenting with low back pain and point tenderness on palpation most likely has a low-energy vertebral compression fracture. A stable compression fracture without any neurological deficit is preferably treated with painkillers, rest, and supplementation of Calcium and vitamin D.

Women post-menopause have a higher risk of developing decreased bone mineral density due to the reduced permissive effect of estrogen on bone leading to reduced bone mineral density. This leads them to be at risk for low-impact compression fractures. Primary management in these patients is conservative management is as follows:

  • Painkillers and bed rest
  • A diet rich in calcium and vitamin D
  • IV bisphosphonates once a year
  • Oral bisphosphonates are usually given for 3-5 years after which the fracture risk is reassessed
  • Denosumab every 6 months
  • Parathyroid hormone is given in a pulsatile manner.

Fracture risk should be routinely calculated for women older than 50 years using DEXA scans and tools like FRAX and Qfracture. If the value in the DEXA is < -2.5, appropriate therapy should be started.

Other options:

Option A: ORIF with fusion, Option B: Anterior decompression, and Option D: IV dexamethasone are all indicated in vertebral fractures with severe features such as neurological deficits and evidence of acute spinal compression.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male patient, who is a known case of diabetes and hypertension, presents to the OPD with the skin lesion shown in the image below. On further evaluation, you diagnose this patient with metabolic syndrome. Which of the following findings in this patient helped you come to this diagnosis?
  1. Waist circumference- 110cm 
  2. HDL cholesterol- 30mg/dL 
  3. Body mass index (BMI)- 33 kg/m2
  4. Triglyceride level- 200 mg/dL
  5. LDL cholesterol- 170mg/dL
questions.solution:
The image showing velvety dark patches in the neck is suggestive of acanthosis nigricans. 

You can diagnose this patient, who is a known case of diabetes and hypertension, as metabolic syndrome with the following findings: waist circumference- 110cm, HDL cholesterol- 30mg/dL and triglyceride level- 200 mg/dL.

Metabolic syndrome is present if three or more of the following five criteria are met, as defined by National Cholesterol Education Program and Adult Treatment Panel III (NCEP-ATP III):

  • Central obesity: Waist circumference of >102 cm in males and >88 cm in females
  • Hypertriglyceridemia: Triglyceride level of ≥ 150 mg/dL
  • Low HDL cholesterol: <40 mg/dL and <50 mg/dL for men and women, respectively
  • Hypertension: Systolic BP of ≥130 mmHg or diastolic BP of ≥ 85 mmHg
  • Fasting plasma glucose level: ≥100 mg/dL or previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes

BMI and LDL cholesterol levels are not part of NCEP-ATP III.

Metabolic syndrome (syndrome X) is a group of conditions that increases the risk for cardiovascular disease. These include hypertension, hyperglycemia, hypertriglyceridemia, and central obesity. Increasing age, genetics, and sedentary lifestyle are considered risk factors. 

Insulin resistance is the most accepted hypothesis used to explain the pathophysiology of the condition. Elevated circulating fatty acids are considered a major factor in developing insulin resistance. It is associated with acanthosis nigricans which are velvety hyperpigmented lesions in skin flexures such as the axilla, groin, and back of the neck.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents with recurrent pyogenic infections. It is found that his B and T cell levels are normal but his IgG is decreased. A CD 40L mutation is found on genetic testing. What infection is this patient susceptible to?
questions.solution:
The history and laboratory analysis given here is suggestive of hyper-IgM syndrome, an inherited deficiency in the CD40 ligand or CD40L. This patient is at increased susceptibility to Pneumocystis jirovecci.

In hyper-IgM syndrome, the X-linked form affects helper T cells that do not express functional CD40 on their plasma membrane. The autosomal recessive form affects CD40 on B cells. Co-stimulatory engagement of CD40 with CD40 ligand is required for activation of B-cells. Normal B-cell responses to T-dependent antigens and the production of memory cells are also deficient.

The B-cell response to T-independent antigens is unaffected. In hyper-IgM syndrome, class switching of B-cells is affected, leading to high IgM and low levels of IgG.

CD40–CD40L interactions are also required for IL-12 secretion. So, defects in this pathway result in increased susceptibility to intracellular pathogens.

The image below defects in components of APC–T cell interactions that give rise to primary immunodeficiency.

questions.text: You see a farmer disposing of refuse and nightsoil by digging a 3-feet-deep trench. The waste is acted upon by the heat generated by bacterial action, and the entire process is completed in 4 to 6 months. What is the method of waste disposal used in this scenario?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the disposal of both refuse and nightsoil in a 3-foot-deep trench, which is acted upon by the heat generated by bacteria action, and completed in 4 - 6 months, is suggestive of the Bangalore method of composting.

Bangalore method, also called the hot fermentation process is an anaerobic method of composting that is used for disposing of both solid waste and nightsoil (excreta).

Trenches with a depth of not more than 3 feet (90cm) are used for this. This is done by spreading a layer of refuse (15 cm thick) at the bottom of the trench and nightsoil (5cm thick) is added next. Layers of refuse and nightsoil are added alternatively till the heap rises to 30cm above ground level. 

At the end of 4 – 6 months, decomposition is complete and the resulting manure is well decomposed, odourless material of high manurial value ready for application to the land.

Other options:

Option B: Manure pits are dug by individual householders in the rural part of India. Garbage, cattle dung, straw, and leaves are dumped into the manure pits and covered with earth after each day's dumping. In 5 to 6 months' time, the refuse is converted into manure.

Option C: Mechanical composting is an aerobic process, where compost is manufactured on a large scale by processing raw materials and turning out a finished product. It is then pulverised to reduce the size of particles to less than 2 inches. The pulverised refuse is then mixed with sewage, sludge or nightsoil in a rotating machine and incubated. 

Option D: Controlled tipping, also known as a sanitary landfill, where waste material is placed in a trench or other prepared area and adequately compacted and covered with earth at the end of the day.

Methods used in controlled tipping are:

  • Trench method: Done in places where level ground is available
  • Ramp method: Well suited where the terrain is moderately sloping
  • Area method: Used for filling land depressions, disused quarries, and clay pits

questions.text: Which of the following veins drain into the structure related to the area marked 'A' in the diagram below?
questions.solution:
The diagram shown is of the right lung identified by the presence of hyparterial and eparterial bronchus at the hilum and the area marked A is where the azygos vein arches over the hilum of the right lung.

The right superior intercostal vein drains the 2nd, 3rd and 4th posterior intercostal veins on the right side of the body into the azygous vein.

Other options:

Option A: Left superior intercostal vein drains into the left brachiocephalic vein.

Option B: The first posterior (supreme) intercostal vein drains into the ipsilateral brachiocephalic or vertebral vein.

Option C: Left marginal vein courses near the left border of the heart, draining much of the left ventricular myocardium and drains into the great cardiac vein.

Related Pearl: Structures related to the mediastinal surface and hilum of the lungs

Right lung:

  • Anterior to the hilum - superior vena cava and right brachiocephalic vein.
  • Posterior to this groove-  azygous vein.
  • Behind the hilum and pulmonary ligament- oesophagus.
  • The cardiac impression - right auricle, right atrium and right ventricle
  • Posteroinferiorly - inferior vena cava

Left lung:

  • The cardiac impression - left ventricle and auricle and right ventricle
  • Large groove that arches over the hilum and descends behind -  Arch of aorta and descending aorta.
  • Arrow groove that ascends to the apex- left subclavian artery
  • Superior to the aortic groove-  thoracic duct and esophagus.
  • Anterior to subclavian groove - left brachiocephalic vein.

questions.text: The histopathological finding given in the image below is most likely to be present in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The histopathological section has giant cells with a central ring of nuclei with a clear peripheral cytoplasm suggestive of the Touton giant cell. It is seen in xanthoma.

TOUTON GIANT CELL:

Touton giant cells are characterized by central eosinophilic cytoplasm and annulus of nuclei surrounded by a foamy, lipid-filled pale outer ring. These cells are seen in:

  • Fat necrosis
  • Xanthogranuloma
  • Dermatofibroma
  • Xanthoma

Other options

Options A and D: Langhans' giant cells are seen in tuberculosis and leprosy.  Langhans’ giant cells have a horseshoe-shaped nuclei arrangement at one pole of the cell. These are formed by the fusion of epithelioid cells. They are not phagocytic but secrete interleukins and help in inflammation.

Option C: Sarcoidosis: There are non-caseating granulomas composed of epithelioid macrophages with giant cells. There is no central necrosis. They are called naked granulomas as they are minimally surrounded by lymphocytes.

Laminated calcium and protein-containing bodies called Schaumann bodies (shown in the image below) and star-shaped inclusions called asteroid bodies are also found in the giant cells of most of these granulomas. These are not pathognomonic to sarcoidosis and can also be found in other granulomatous diseases like tuberculosis.

questions.text: A patient is complaining of severe headache following hernia surgery under spinal anesthesia. The headache is occipital in location which worsens on standing and is relieved by lying flat. All of the following needles can be used to perform spinal anesthesia to reduce the incidence of the above condition except
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient complained of headache in the occiput which worsens on standing and is relieved by lying flat following spinal anesthesia is suggestive of post-dural puncture headache. Quincke needle increases the risk of post-dural puncture headache.

The Quincke needle is a cutting needle with an end injection. Whitacre and Tuohy are Pencil-point needles (blunt needles) which reduce the incidence of post–dural puncture headaches.

Types of needles based on tip shapes:

  •  Dura cutting needles:
    • Quincke-babcock needle
    • Pitkin needle
  • Pencil point needles (blunt):
    • Whitacre
    • Sprotte - side-injection needle with a long opening
    • Tuohy - most commonly used needle for epidural anesthesia
    • Greene

PDPH can occur after spinal or epidural anesthesia due to loss of CSF through the dura which causes traction on the pain-sensitive intracranial structures. It may also occur due to compensatory, painful intracranial vasodilation to offset the reduction in intracranial pressure. Most cases occur within 72 hours of dural puncture. 

The headache worsens with the standing or seated position and is relieved by lying in the supine position. It is typically frontal or occipital in distribution and the associated symptoms include nausea, neck stiffness, low back pain, vertigo, vision changes, and auditory disturbances. 

Diagnosis is based on typical history and imaging is only rarely performed to exclude other diagnoses.

Management of PDPH: Most of the headaches resolve spontaneously within 7 days. Conservative management includes

  • Supine positioning
  • Hydration
  • Caffeine
  • Oral analgesics
  • Sumatriptan
  • An epidural blood patch is the definitive management.
    • It is ideally performed 24 hours after dural puncture and the development of classic symptoms.
    • 15-20 mL of autologous blood is injected into the epidural space at the same or one interspace below the level of the dural puncture.
    • It acts by stopping the CSF leak by either mass effect or coagulation.
    • Most patients will respond to a single blood patch, and 90% of initial nonresponders will obtain relief from a second injection (1 to 2 days after the first).
    • A prophylactic epidural patch is not recommended.

Related Pearl: PDPH- Post-Dural Puncture Headache

  • May follow lumbar puncture, spinal anesthesia, wet epidural tap (in which epidural needle pierced dura).
  • Onset 12-72hrs and last for 1-2 weeks.
  • Aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down.
  • Incidence increases with the larger needle, cutting point (in comparison to pencil point) needle, young age, females, pregnancy.
  • Prevention by thinner needle

Management:

  • Supine position
  • IV fluids
  • Caffeine and analgesia
  • Epidural blood patch

Related Pearl: Factors That Can Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Age: Younger, more frequent
  • Sex: Females > males
  • Needle size: Larger > smaller
  • Needle bevel: Less when the needle bevel is placed in the long axis of the neuraxis Orienting a needle bevel parallel with the axis of the spine, such that the longitudinal fibers of the dura would more likely be separated than cut, results in a lower incidence of postspinal puncture headache
  • Pregnancy: More when pregnant
  • Dural punctures: More with multiple punctures

Factors That Do Not Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Insertion and use of catheters for continuous spinal anesthesia
  • Timing of ambulation

questions.text: An elderly male with constrictive pericarditis develops portal hypertension. Which of the following etiological classifications of portal hypertension will it fall under?
questions.solution:
Constrictive pericarditis is a posthepatic cause of portal hypertension. 

Portal hypertension is defined as the elevation of the hepatic venous pressure gradient to >5 mmHg. It occurs due to resistance to blood flow in the liver due to fibrosis and nodules of regenerating parenchyma, and due to increased splanchnic blood flow.

Causes of Portal Hypertension:

1) Prehaptic: due to increased blood flow or obstruction within the portal vein or splenic vein before it enters the liver.

  • Portal vein thrombosis
  • Splenic vein thrombosis
  • Massive splenomegaly (Banti’s syndrome)

2) Intrahepatic:

  • Presinusoidal: Schistosomiasis, congenital hepatic fibrosis
  • Sinusoidal: Cirrhosis, alcoholic hepatitis
  • Postsinusoidal: Venoocclusive disease

3) Posthepatic: They affect the hepatic veins and venous drainage to the heart.

  • Budd-Chiari syndrome
  • Inferior vena caval webs
  • Cardiac causes – Restrictive cardiomyopathy, constrictive pericarditis, severe congestive heart failure

The complications of portal hypertension are esophageal varices with variceal bleeding, splenomegaly, ascites, and portal hypertensive gastropathy.

Related Pearl: Causes of Portal Hypertension

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presented with tingling and numbness of the upper and lower limb extremities. She also complains of blurring of vision with painful eye movements. Her brain MRI finding is given below. What is the best test to evaluate her eye pathology?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the symptoms of tingling and numbness of both limbs along with the brain MRI showing ovoid lesions with their long axis perpendicular to the ventricular surface called Dawson's fingers are characteristically seen in multiple sclerosis (MS). Optic neuritis is a common feature of MS, and is best evaluated by doing an MRI of the orbit.

Although the mainstay of imaging the orbit is CT, MRI is used as the first line in the evaluation of the optic nerve itself, for example in the setting of optic neuropathy/neuritis. It can be particularly useful in the characterisation of orbital masses and for delineating the spread of infection.

Multiple sclerosis(MS) is an autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system commonly associated with paresthesia (tingling sensations),  hypesthesia (numbness), optic neuritis, unilateral/ bilateral, limb weakness - spastic paralysis, Babinski's sign positive and bladder dysfunction. 

Optic neuritis (ON) presents as diminished visual acuity or decreased colour perception (desaturation) in the central field of vision. These symptoms can be mild or may progress to severe visual loss. Rarely, there is a complete loss of light perception. Periorbital pain (aggravated by eye movement) often precedes or accompanies the visual loss. 

Related Pearl: Investigation of choice in Neurology

Generally, MRI is considered the best imaging for the spinal cord and nerves.

Conditions in which MRI is used include:

  • Optic neuritis
  • Vestibular schwannoma
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Spinal cord tumor
  • Neurofibroma
  • Viral encephalitis
  • Hippocampal volumetry.

CT scan is preferred when the timing is critical. So, the investigation of choice for stroke is an NCCT. This helps to rule out hemorrhagic stroke.

The investigation of choice for ischemic stroke is a diffusion-weighted MRI.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency department with multiple fractures of the face and skull, following a road traffic accident. CT scan showed an intact eyeball with normal intraocular pressure. When light is shone into the right eye, both pupils constrict, but neither pupil constricts when light is shone into the left eye. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the presence of constriction in both pupils on shining light in the right eye, and the absence of constriction in both pupils on shining light in the left eye is highly suggestive of left optic nerve transection.

In the pupillary light reflex pathway, the afferent is the optic nerve (CN II) and the efferent is the oculomotor nerve (CN III). The afferent limb consists of the retina, the optic nerve, and the pretectal nucleus of the midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus. The pretectal nucleus projects crossed and non-crossed fibres to the ipsilateral and contralateral Edinger-Westphal nuclei. This connection forms the basis of the consensual light reflex.

Each Edinger-Westphal nucleus gives rise to preganglionic parasympathetic fibres that emerge with CN III to synapse with postganglionic parasympathetic neurons of the ciliary ganglion to innervate the ciliary sphincter.

In left optic nerve injury (e.g., left optic nerve CN II cut somewhere between the retina and the optic chiasm, thus damaging the left afferent limb, leaving the rest of the bilateral pupillary light reflex pathway intact) the following features are seen:

  • Left direct and right consensual reflexes are lost as afferent signals from the left eye cannot pass through the severed left optic nerve to reach the left and right intact efferent limbs respectively.
  • Right direct and left consensual reflexes are intact as right optic, right oculomotor and left oculomotor nerves are intact.

questions.text: A pregnant woman who presented with vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and several episodes of vomiting was diagnosed with complete molar pregnancy. On transvaginal ultrasonography, the following finding is seen in her left ovary.  What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Theca lutein cyst of the ovary is commonly associated with women diagnosed with complete mole.

Theca lutein cyst result from ovarian overstimulation by excessive hCG levels. Theca lutein cysts, usually regress spontaneously following the evacuation of a molar pregnancy. In some cases, a larger cyst may undergo torsion, infarction, and hemorrhage. Management includes detorsion. Oophorectomy is performed if there is an excessive infraction after detorsion.

Hydatidiform mole is an abnormal condition of the placenta, characterized by partly degenerative and partly proliferative changes in the chorionic villi. It may be either partial or complete.

The patient presents with a characteristic history of abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding or spotting, and vomiting during the first trimester. Also, there may be a history of passing grape-like vesicles vaginally. On examination, the size of the uterus is larger for gestational age and the fetal heart sounds are absent.

A USG scan shows a snowstorm appearance which is characteristic of a complete mole.

Suction and evacuation are the treatment of choice. Hysterectomy is done only if there is uncontrolled hemorrhage or perforation during surgical evacuation or if the age of the patient is above 35 years and has completed her family.

Serum hCG levels are checked within 48 hours of evacuation and are used as a baseline for future comparisons. It is then checked every week till it normalizes, which usually takes around 4 to 8 weeks. After the hCG values return to normal, a regular follow-up is done monthly for 6 months.

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

questions.text: A researcher was planning to go to a malaria-endemic place for a period of 8 weeks. Which of the following drugs can be taken as prophylaxis before visiting the malaria-endemic place?
questions.solution:
Mefloquine can be taken as prophylaxis by the researcher before going to malaria-endemic places for > 6 weeks.

Chemoprophylaxis against malaria for travelers:

  • If the duration of travel is less than 6 weeks then doxycycline 100mg once a day is to be started 2 days before travel and continued at least 4 weeks after travel.
  • If the duration of travel is more than 6 weeks then mefloquine 250mg once a week is to be started 2 weeks before travel and continued at least 4 weeks after travel.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female is undergoing a hysteroscopic myomectomy. The Gynaecologist is using monopolar electrocautery for this procedure and bleeding is expected. Which of the following distension media is most suitable for this case?
questions.solution:
Dextran solution is suitable as a distension media of choice for hysteroscopy when electrocautery is used.

In procedures like myomectomy, septum cutting, or endometrial ablation electrocautery is used. In these cases, the distension medium that is used should be nonionic (not normal saline(Option D)) to prevent the spread of electrical energy. The medium should not get mixed with blood as this would interfere with the visualization of the procedure. Hyskon (concentrated dextran solution) and glycine are commonly used. Hyskon is not miscible with blood and has good optical qualities.

Commonly used media is CO2, which is delivered through a hysteroflator to a maximum rate of 70mL/min and pressure less than 100 mmHg. Liquid media used are Normal saline, 5% dextrose, and Ringer lactate solutions. Intrauterine pressure of 40-50 mmHg is needed for adequate distension.

Hysteroscopy is an operative procedure that provides the endoscopic view of the endometrial cavity and tubal ostia via the cervix. It can be diagnostic or therapeutic. 

Therapeutic indications of hysteroscopy Diagnostic indications of hysteroscopy
  • Uterine septum
  • Asherman syndrome
  • Retained IUCD
  • Polypectomy
  • Submucous fibroid
  • Abnormal uterine bleeding
  • Tubal sterilization using sclerosing agents
  • To study the endocervical mucosal lining
  • Congenital malformations of the uterus
  • Endometrial tuberculosis
  • Asherman syndrome
  • Misplaced IUCD
  • Endometrial lesions
  • Endometrial polyp
  • Cornual tubal blockage

Complications of hysteroscopy include :

  • Early complications:
    1. Anesthesia complications- air embolism can occur
    2. Uterine perforation
    3. Thermal injury with cautery and laser
    4. Sepsis
    5. Allergic reaction to dextran and glycine
    6. Fluid overload occurs and can lead to pulmonary edema if the fluid deficit is more than 1000 mL. It can be managed by diuretics.
    7. Cerebral edema
    8. Cardiac failure
  • Late complications:
    1. Hematometra following cervical stenosis
    2. Pelvic inflammatory disease
    3. Uterine rupture during pregnancy
    4. Dysmenorrhea
    5. Amenorrhea

Other options:

Option B: CO2 cannot be used as it obscures the vision in the presence of blood and cannot be employed in the presence of bleeding.

Option A: There is a risk of combustion with N2O if electrocautery is used.

questions.text: Which is the correct sequence of manifestations that you would expect to see in a patient undergoing total body irradiation?
questions.solution:
Lymphocytopenia, granulocytopenia, and thrombocytopenia are the correct chronological sequence for radiation effects on peripheral blood components

Radiation affects hematopoietic stem cells. Most mature functional cells are relatively resistant, except lymphocytes which undergo apoptosis.

Cytopenias occur due to the death of functional cells and cannot be replaced due to loss of stem cells. The time-course of cytopenia is dependent on the lifespan of the mature cell.

  • Lymphocytes start to decline immediately.
  • Granulocytes start to decline within days.
  • Platelets decline after a few weeks.
  • Erythrocyte (RBC) lineage is relatively radioresistant, and anaemia usually does not occur from erythrocyte lineage suppression.

The Mean Lethal Dose (LD50) of radiation for humans is around 3–4 Gy without medical intervention and 4–8 Gy with standard medical care.

questions.text: Dark brown post mortem lividity is seen in:
questions.solution:
Dark brown post-mortem lividity is seen in phosphorous poisoning.

Post-mortem lividity is also known as Livor Mortis, postmortem hypostasis, postmortem staining, suggilations, and vibices. Usually, it is a reddish-purple discoloration due to the passive pooling of blood into the dependent areas of the body.

This color depends on the state of oxygenation at the time of death. Death due to hypoxia, results in darker colored skin due to reduced hemoglobin in the cutaneous vessels. However, if someone dies due to hypothermia (Option B), the color of the skin may be pink due to the presence of oxyhemoglobin. This happens because the tissues do not take up oxygen from the circulating blood due to reduced metabolism.

Other color changes include:

  • Cherry-pink color in carbon monoxide (Option D) or hydrocyanic acid (Option A) poisoning.
  • Chocolate/coffee-brown color in poisoning by potassium chlorate, potassium bichromate, nitrobenzene, or aniline.
  • Dark brown color in phosphorus poisoning.
  • A refrigerated dead body may show bright pink patches.

questions.text: While performing incision and drainage in which of the following conditions, is the site of drainage just lateral to the point of junction of the anterior pillar with a line drawn through the base of the uvula?
questions.solution:
While performing incision and drainage in quinsy/peritonsillar abscess, the site of drainage is just lateral to the point of junction of a vertical line through the anterior pillar and a horizontal line through the base of the uvula or to the point of maximum bulge above the upper pole.

Peritonsillar abscess is the collection of pus in the peritonsillar space between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx. Both aerobic and anaerobic organisms are seen.

Patient presents with fever, unilateral throat pain, odynophagia, hot potato voice, torticollis, foul breath, referred otalgia through glossopharyngeal nerve and trismus due to spasm of pterygoid muscles.

Oral cavity examination may show congested and edematous tonsils, pillars, and soft palate on the involved side. Edematous uvula pushed to the opposite side. Pus may be seen on the tonsillar region. Jugulodigastric lymph nodes may be enlarged.

The management of quinsy is by antibiotics and incision and drainage to drain the abscess followed by interval tonsillectomy 4 to 6 weeks later. 

Other options: 

Option A: Prevertebral abscess/ Chronic retropharyngeal abscess is tubercular in nature and presents as a fluctuant swelling in the posterior pharyngeal wall, centrally or on one side of midline.

Incision and drainage of the abscess can be done through a vertical incision along the anterior border of the sternomastoid (for low abscess) or along its posterior border (for high abscess).

Option B: Parotid abscess occurs due to the suppuration of parotid space. It presents with swelling, redness, firmness, and tenderness in the parotid area and at the angle of the mandible. 

Surgical drainage under local or general anaesthesia is carried out by a preauricular incision and the abscess is bluntly opened working parallel to the branches of the VIIth nerve.

Option C: Bezold abscess is a complication of acute otomastoiditis where the infection/pus breaks through the thin medial side of the tip of the mastoid and presents as a swelling in the upper part of the neck. Treatment includes cortical mastoidectomy and drainage of the neck abscess through a separate incision.

questions.text: The following instrument is used to measure the degree of a condition present in patient A. If the examiner wishes to rule out the pseudo cases of this condition, he should check for all of these except_____________?
questions.solution:
The image shows Hertel's exophthalmometer used to measure proptosis. Ipsilateral ptosis does not cause pseudoproptosis because there is only drooping of the upper eyelid in this condition.

An abnormal protrusion of the globe because of a space-occupying lesion in the orbit is called proptosis. Pseudoproptosis occurs when the eye has a proptotic anatomic appearance that is not caused by a mass effect from a lesion displacing the globe. 

Pseudoproptosis is seen in high myopia (due to increase in size of the eyeball), ipsilateral lid retraction (resultant sclera creates the impression of the globe protruding forward) and contralateral enophthalmos (the normal orbit, which is situated more anteriorly, may simulate proptosis when there is none).

Exophthalmometry: measures protrusion of the apex of the cornea from the outer orbital margin (with the eyes looking straight ahead). An absolute protrusion of >20 mm or a difference of >2 mm between the two eyes is labelled as proptosis.

Instruments used to measure proptosis:

  • Hertel’s exophthalmometer: the most common instrument used. Its advantage is that it measures both eyes simultaneously.
  • Luedde exophthalmometer

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with large fontanels, macroglossia and delayed developmental milestones. X-ray of the lower limb is given below. Which of the following features will be seen on a brain MRI in this child?

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of large fontanels, macroglossia and delayed developmental milestones along with the X-ray showing the absence of distal femoral epiphysis, is suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism. X-rays of the skull reveal enlarged sella and intersutural (wormian) bones. 

The image below shows enlarged sella turcica (small arrow) and wormian bones.

Congenital hypothyroidism is the most common preventable cause of intellectual disability. Congenital hypothyroidism is mostly asymptomatic at birth and is detected mainly by the neonatal screening of TSH levels in the first few weeks of life. Clinical features present after maternal thyroxine wanes. 

Thyroid dysgenesis is considered the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism in India accounting for about 75% of all cases.

The clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism include a puffy face, enlarged fontanelles, macroglossia, prolonged jaundice, lethargy, and a history of poor feeding. The absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphyses denotes the onset of congenital hypothyroidism. These epiphyses are normally present at birth.

Epiphyseal dysgenesis wherein there are multiple foci of ossification in the epiphyses, is common. X-rays of the skull reveal enlarged sella, large fontanelles, wide sutures, and intersutural (wormian) bones. 

Image below: The infant on the left with congenital hypothyroidism demonstrates the absence of the distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphyses, while in the normal infant on the right the distal femoral epiphysis is present:

The image below shows small upper femoral epiphyses:

Other options:

Option B: Craniopharyngiomas are suprasellar, partially calcified, solid, or mixed solid-cystic benign tumours that arise from remnants of Rathke’s pouch.

Option C: J-shaped sella is a skull radiographic finding in Hurler's syndrome. Hurler's syndrome is a severe type of mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS)-I, caused by a deficiency of α-L-iduronidase.

Option D: Rathke's cleft cysts appear completely cystic with a smooth, thin wall and no calcifications on MRI. They are mostly seen in the intrasellar region.

questions.text: As a PHC officer, you conduct a session on viral diseases that are more likely to affect the rice farmers in your area. You focus on a disease which follows a bird-arthropod-human transmission route where man is an incidental dead-end host. Identify the disease.
questions.solution:
The viral disease discussed in the above scenario is Japanese encephalitis, which follows bird-arthropod-human transmission, where man is an incidental dead-end host. 

Japanese encephalitis (JE) is a mosquito-borne encephalitis caused by a group B arbovirus (Flavivirus) and transmitted by the bite of Culex mosquitoes, specifically Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India), which typically breed in irrigated rice fields. Therefore, rice farmers are more likely to be affected.

The image below shows the life cycle of the Japanese B encephalitis virus.

Clinical features include high fever, headache, and vomiting. Signs of encephalitis, such as convulsions, neck rigidity, and altered sensorium, appear after 1-6 days. 

Inactivated vero cell culture-derived SA-14-14-2 vaccine is approved for use in India. JE vaccine is given in two doses- at 9-12 months of age and at 16-24 months of age in areas that are endemic to the disease, according to the National Immunization Schedule. 

Other options:

Option A: Ebola virus belongs to the family Filoviridae and is transmitted by bats. Human-to-human transmission through blood or body fluids can occur. It causes fever, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and haemorrhage. 

The image below shows the lifecycle of the ebola virus:

Option B: Nipah virus is a zoonotic virus, which is transmitted from pigs to humans. Fruit bats are the natural hosts. It causes severe encephalitis with high mortality. 

The image given below depicts the life cycle of the Nipah virus:

Option D: Zika virus is transmitted to human beings by the bite of an infected Aedes mosquito. It can also be transmitted trans-placentally, causing microcephaly and other severe fetal brain defects.

questions.text: During an anatomy lecture, your professor describes a lower limb nerve, related to the structure marked below. She also mentions that injury to this nerve causes loss of dorsiflexion and sensation over the lateral aspect of the leg and dorsum of the foot. Which of the following is not a branch of this nerve?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the structure marked in the given image is the neck of the fibula. The common fibular nerve (common peroneal nerve) passes around the lateral surface of the neck of the fibula and enters the lateral compartment of the leg.

The Lateral plantar nerve is not a branch of this nerve. It is a branch of the tibial nerve.

The common fibular is derived from the dorsal branches of the L4 - L5 and S1 - S2 ventral rami. It innervates the short head of the biceps femoris in the posterior compartment of the thigh and then continues into the lateral and anterior compartments of the leg and onto the foot.

It gives the following branches:

  • Sural communicating nerve (cutaneous branch)
  • Lateral sural cutaneous nerve (cutaneous branch)
  • Superficial fibular nerve 
  • Deep fibular nerve. 

Injury to the common peroneal nerve will lead to:

  • Weakness of dorsiflexion of foot or foot drop
  • Loss of dorsiflexion 
  • Loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the leg and dorsum of the foot.
  • Wasting of fibular and anterior tibial muscles.

The images given below show the common peroneal nerve course and the sensory area supplied.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with an untreated illness caused by a virus whose replication cycle is given below. Which of the following oral lesions is unlikely to develop in this patient?

choices.text: White, plaque-like lesions with cheesy exudate, on an erythematous mucosa
Discrete red lesions with central bluish-white spots seen on the buccal mucosa at the level of premolars
White, frond-like lesions with hair-like growths from folds in the patches
Well-circumscribed painful ulcers with a white necrotic base surrounded by a red halo.

questions.solution:
The replication cycle above shows an RNA virus using the reverse transcriptase enzyme to synthesize complementary DNA which is then integrated into the host DNA. The most probable virus, thus, is the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). 

Koplik spots (discrete red lesions with central bluish-white spots seen on the buccal mucosa at the level of premolars) are pathognomic lesions seen in measles are are not associated with HIV. 

Oral lesions commonly seen in patients with untreated HIV infection CD4+ T cell counts of <300/μL, include:

  • Oral Thrush/ Oral candidiasis associated with Candida albicans - presents as white plaque-like lesions with cheesy exudate on an erythematous mucosa. They are typically painful and can be easily brushed off. Diagnosis by KOH preparation demonstrates budding yeasts, hyphae, or pseudohyphae.
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia associated with Epstein-Barr virus presents as white, frond-like lesions with hair-like growths from folds in the patches, generally along the lateral borders of the tongue. they are typically painless and cannot be brushed. Despite its name, it is not considered premalignant. 
  • Aphthous ulcers- Well-circumscribed ulcerative lesions with a white necrotic base surrounded by a red halo. These lesions are of unknown etiology and can be quite painful and interfere with swallowing. Topical anaesthetics provide immediate symptomatic relief of short duration.

questions.text: A 31-year-old pregnant woman in labor was admitted to the hospital at 38 weeks of gestation. On examination, there is infraumbilical flattening of the abdomen and fetal heart sounds are heard over the flanks. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Wait and watch for the progress of labor

questions.solution:
Based on the examination and auscultation findings, the fetus is in occipitoposterior position. The most appropriate management is to wait and watch for the progress of labor. 

In a majority of cases, the occiput rotates through 3/8th of the circle, and the baby is born in the occipitoanterior position. Hence, when the diagnosis of occipitoposterior position is made, labor is allowed to proceed normally when there are good uterine contractions and a favorable pelvis.

The occipitoposterior (OP) position of the fetus is when the occiput is situated posteriorly over the sacroiliac joint or directly over the sacrum. It is the most common fetal malposition. It is an abnormal position seen in the vertex presentation, not an abnormal presentation. 

  • Occipitoposterior position is commonly seen in android pelvis/deflexed head.
  • The engaging diameter of this position is sub-occipitofrontal/occipitofrontal.
  • The most common type in occipitoposterior position is right OP.
  • A persistent occipitoposterior position results from a failure of internal rotation prior to birth.

Examination findings of OP position:

  • Inspection: The abdomen appears flattened below the umbilicus (infra-umbilical flattening).
  • Pelvic grips:
    • The head is not engaged.
    • The sinciput (cephalic prominence) is not prominently felt.
  • Auscultation: Fetal heart sounds are heard maximally over the flanks. However, in direct OP position, they are heard in the midline.

There are three variants of OP position:

  • Left OP position (fourth position of the vertex) - When the occiput points towards the left sacroiliac joint. 
  • Right OP position (third position of the vertex) - When the occiput points towards the right sacroiliac joint. It is more common than the left OP position.
  • Direct OP position: When the occiput points directly towards the sacrum.

All three positions may be primary (present before the onset of labor) or secondary (develops after the onset of labor). 

Indications of cesarean section in occipitoposterior position:

  • Arrest of labor
  • Inadequate uterine contraction
  • Fetal distress
  • Other obstetrical indications

Longest diameter of fetal skull: Mentovertical 14 cm > Submentovertical / occipitofrontal - 11.5cm

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient is being evaluated in the ward for abdominal pain 1 day after a laparoscopic abdominal surgery. Ultrasonography of the lower abdomen shows a hypoechoic mass. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: CT Scan of abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient presenting with abdominal pain 1 day after abdominal surgery with a  mass in the lower abdomen that appears hypoechoic on ultrasonography most likely has acute urinary retention. The next best step in the management of this patient would be to catheterize him with a Foley catheter to relieve the retention.

There can be multiple factors for urinary retention including anticholinergic medication, surgery, trauma, etc. It occurs due to an imbalance in the activity of the muscles of the bladder. In this case, the most likely cause of urinary retention is handling of the bladder intraoperatively which could have led to a transient hypoactivity of the bladder muscles. It could also be due to the effect of the anesthesia. The next step in management would be urgent Foley catheterization to relieve the obstruction.

If urethral catheter placement is not successful, suprapubic catheterization should be done. 

If there is a urethral stricture, a council tip catheter is used to dilate it using a cystoscope, guide wires, and urethral dilators. In acute urine retention, urethral strictures should be suspected when there is resistance at the urethral meatus as the strictures are more common in the distal urethra than the proximal urethra.

Significant hematuria can result in the formation of blood clots, which can further block the urethra and cause retention. 

Other Options:
Option B: A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is indicated if there is a suspicion of a bladder injury or if ultrasonography findings were equivocal. But the USG here shows a large hypoechoic region indicating Urinary retention.

Option C: Urgent surgery would have been needed if there was any evidence of bladder trauma. This patient should first be catheterized to relieve the obstruction in this case of acute urinary retention.

Option D: Oxybutynin is an anticholinergic medication that causes relaxation of the bladder muscles. It would worsen this patient's urinary retention.

questions.text: A 65-year-old trumpet player presents with hoarseness of voice and neck swelling that increases in size on coughing and on performing the Valsalva maneuver. Which of the following membranes does the swelling herniate through to appear as depicted in the figure below?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hoarseness of voice, and neck swelling that increases in size on coughing/Valsalva maneuver is suggestive of external laryngocele that herniates through the thyrohyoid membrane to appears as a swelling in the neck.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling in the neck due to abnormal distention of saccule present in the ventricle of the larynx (sinus of the larynx). It is more commonly seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to a raised transglottic air pressure in these people. It can be classified into internal, external, or combined types of laryngocele.

  • Internal laryngocele is limited within the larynx and appears as a distension of the false cord and aryepiglottic fold.
  • External laryngocele extends further superolaterally, pierces the thyrohyoid membrane, and may appear as a neck mass.
  • Combined or mixed laryngocele has both internal and external laryngoceles as its components
     

Given below is a diagrammatic representation of laryngocele.

Laryngocele presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and airway obstruction (if large). External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck that increases in size on coughing or performing the Valsalva maneuver. On pressing the neck swelling, a gurgling sound is heard, indicating a positive Bryce's sign. Adult laryngoceles can be associated with carcinoma.

Diagnosis is based on an indirect laryngoscopy and CT scan. Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialization and external laryngocele is managed by a surgical excision through an external neck incision.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of hair loss over the back of his head. There is no other significant past medical history. On examination, the following can be seen with exclamation mark hairs without scaling or inflammation. Which of the following is true about the condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of localized hair loss with exclamation mark hairs without scaling or inflammation on examination is suggestive of alopecia areata. Sparing of white hair is seen in alopecia areata.

Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease that leads to non-scarring hair loss. It is thought to be caused by T-cell-mediated autoimmunity(Option A). The activated T lymphocytes invade the hair bulb but the follicle is spared(Option C). It is associated with many autoimmune diseases systemic lupus erythematosus, thyroiditis, vitiligo, and psoriasis. 

It mainly affects the scalp, but can also affect the beard, eyebrows, and eyelashes (Option D). In some cases, this progresses to a total loss of scalp hair (alopecia totalis) or a loss of all hair on the body (alopecia universalis). The lesions of alopecia areata are characterized by a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia. Some broken hairs can be seen, which are called exclamation marks. They are easily extractable. It preferentially affects pigmented hair and spares non-pigmented or white hair.

Spontaneous remission occurs in a majority of patients with hair loss that is patchy and is of shorter duration. Topical steroids like clobetasol can be useful in patchy alopecia areata. Intralesional steroids are the most effective treatment for patchy alopecia areata. Severe and long-standing alopecia areata require oral corticosteroids.

The image below shows a clinical picture of alopecia areata with a patch of alopecia with a smooth surface of the scalp-

questions.text: As a medical intern, you attend a session conducted by your college, on the topic 'Recent Advances in Fetal Medicine'. The session featured 4 renowned paediatricians who sat on the dais and discussed this topic in front of an audience of 80 people. What form of communication is used in this session?
questions.solution:
The mode of communication used in the above scenario is panel discussion which comprises of 4-8 qualified persons who sit together and discuss a topic in front of an audience. 

It has a chairman, a moderator, and 4-8 speakers. There is no specific agenda or set speeches. The audience is also invited to take part after the main discussion.

Option C:  A workshop is a series of meetings with an emphasis on individual work within a group, with the use of external consultants or experts.
