questions.text: A 7-year-old intellectually disabled boy was brought with large warty crusts on the trunk, hands, and feet as shown below. Severe fissuring and scaling of the skin are present over the soles. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Norwegian scabies or human-crusted scabies.

Crusted scabies is characterized by hyperkeratotic skin crust and infestation of up to millions of mites. It occurs in people with an inadequate immune response to the mite, allowing them to multiply. Immunosuppression is a frequent association.

Clinical features include large warty crusts on the hands and feet. Palms and soles are irregularly fissured and thickened. Horny debris gets accumulated beneath the thickened and discolored nails. Erythema and scaling occur in the scalp face and seborrheic area. The itching will be absent often.

Diagnosis is confirmed by examining the scrappings which reveal mites and eggs. Management principles include hospitalization and isolation of patients due to the risk of transmission due to physical contact. Oral ivermectin, topical scabicide, and keratolytic agents are used for the crusting.

The images given below show hands in Norwegian scabies.

Other options:

Option A- Scabies incognito is a variant of scabies surrepticius that occurs due to inappropriate use of topical corticosteroids for scabies lesions. The steroids modify the clinical presentation of scabies and may mimic other dermatoses. The lesions might appear as vesicles, pustules, or nodules and could become diffuse.

Option B-  Animal scabies transmission to humans is rare. Hypersensitivity reactions for the mites and their products lead to intense pruritis and irritation. These lesions are usually self-limiting.

Option D-  Nodular scabies present as violaceous, pruritic localized nodules over the groin, axilla, and genitalia. They represent a hypersensitivity reaction to the mite antigens and can persist after treatment. 

The below image shows nodular scabies in the axilla.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presented with painless swelling on the side of his neck anterior to the muscle. On examination, swelling is soft, cystic, and transillumination positive. How would you manage the patient?

choices.text: Advise a CECT scan of the neck

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of a Branchial cyst. In a patient who is older than 35 years, there is a high index of suspicion of a malignant necrotic lymph node, and should be ruled out first before excising the mass.

Branchial cysts arise from the remnants of the second branchial cleft. Normally, 2nd, 3rd, and 4th clefts disappear to form a smooth neck. A persistent second cleft is called cervical sinus (of His) which eventually gets sequestered to form a branchial cyst.

Clinical Features:

  • Swelling in the neck beneath the anterior border of the upper third of the sternomastoid muscle. It is smooth, soft, fluctuant, and often transilluminate.
  • Even though congenital, it is seen in late adolescence and early 3rd decade.
  • Histologically, it is lined by squamous epithelium. The cyst wall shows plenty of lymphoid tissue.
  • It may get infected to form an abscess.
  • FNAC shows cholesterol crystals which are derived from the sebaceous glands in the lining mucous membrane.

Treatment:

  • Treatment is by complete excision, which is best undertaken when the lesion is quiescent.
  • Although the anterior aspect of the cyst is easy to dissect, it may pass backward and upwards through the bifurcation of the common carotid artery as far as the pharyngeal constrictors.
  • It passes superficial to the hypoglossal and glossopharyngeal nerves but deep to the posterior belly of the digastric. These structures and the spinal accessory nerve must be positively identified to avoid damage.
  • In a patient who is older than 35 years, there is a high index of suspicion of a malignant necrotic lymph node, and should be ruled out first before excising the mass.

Other options:

Excision would be the treatment of choice in a patient who is less than 35 years old
 
Reviewing after 6 months is not correct for a patient who is more than 35 years old as there is a high degree of suspicion of malignancy.
 
CT scan of the neck is not a recommended initial screening tool for a branchial cyst.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of ulcerative colitis comes with high fever and abdominal pain for the past 2 days. Her abdominal x-ray was as shown below. She is admitted to the ICU, is managed conservatively and has been kept NPO in the ICU for 48 hours with IV resuscitation. She hasn't passed flatus. BP is 90/68mm Hg. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Increase the dose of IV corticosteroids

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the radiograph are suggestive of toxic megacolon. In this patient with no improvement of symptoms after staying NPO for 48 hours, urgent surgery should be performed to prevent perforation.

Toxic megacolon may present with fever, abdominal pain, and abdominal distension. Bacterial infection with features of sepsis may also be seen. It can result in perforation. 

Abdominal radiography shows transverse or right colonic dilation of >6 cm and loss of haustrations.

It usually resolves with supportive treatment (correcting electrolyte imbalance, fluids, bowel rest) and medical therapy which includes glucocorticoids, anti-inflammatory drugs, and antibiotics. However, an urgent colectomy is indicated in patients who do not show signs of improvement.

Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease resulting in superficial erosions confined to the mucosa and submucosa of the colon. It starts from the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous manner.

The clinical features include abdominal pain, diarrhea, rectal bleeding, tenesmus, and passage of mucus. Other symptoms include anorexia, nausea, vomiting, fever, and weight loss.

Investigations show elevated C-reactive protein, platelet count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, fecal calprotectin, and fecal lactoferrin. A colonoscopy reveals loss of typical vascular pattern, erythema, friability, and ulcerations. 

Extraintestinal manifestations associated with IBD include ocular features (episcleritis, and uveitis), dermatological manifestations (erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosum), rheumatological (arthropathies, sacroiliitis, ankylosing spondylitis) and primary sclerosing cholangitis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with complaints of chest pain. The chest pain was exacerbated by exercise and emotional stress. He had a history of erectile dysfunction and was on sildenafil. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a history of chest pain which is exacerbated by exercise and emotional stress points towards the diagnosis of angina pectoris. The patient has a history of erectile dysfunction and was on sildenafil, Nitroglycerin should be avoided in this patient.

Nitrates should be avoided in a patient on sildenafil as nitrates increase cGMP levels by stimulating guanylyl cyclase. This leads to severe hypotension.

Sildenafil

Sildenafil acts by inhibiting phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) and is used in the treatment of erectile dysfunction. PDE-5 inhibitors cause the accumulation of cGMP in the corpus cavernosum, which leads to the relaxation of smooth muscles of penile arteries that fill the corpus cavernosum, thereby improving erectile function in patients with erectile dysfunction. In addition to erectile dysfunction, sildenafil can be used in the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension. Adverse effects include headache, flushing, nasal congestion, blue-green tinting of vision, and erections lasting more than 4 hours.

Nitrates

Nitrates act by releasing nitric oxide (NO). This NO activates the enzyme guanylyl cyclase which increases intracellular cyclic GMP (cGMP) levels. cGMP causes dephosphorylation of myosin light-chain (MLC) which causes smooth muscle relaxation. Nitrates are mixed dilators. They are used in the management of angina. Adverse effects include orthostatic hypotension, reflex tachycardia, and throbbing headache. 

Other options:

Options A, B, and D: Nifedipine, labetalol, and verapamil can be safely used in this patient as they do not interact with sildenafil.

questions.text: A  child presented to OPD with frequent vomiting, failure to thrive, lethargy, protein aversion, and intellectual disability. On evaluation, he is found to have raised blood ammonia levels and very high levels of plasma citrulline. Which is the enzyme likely to be deficient in this baby?
questions.solution:
The deficiency of the Argininosuccinate synthetase enzyme leads to citrullinemia type I, also called classic citrullinemia.  The severe or neonatal form (the most common form) appears in the 1st few days of life with signs and symptoms of hyperammonemia. In the subacute or mild form, clinical findings such as failure to thrive, frequent vomiting, developmental delay, and dry, brittle hair appear gradually after 1 year of age. Laboratory findings are similar to those found in patients with Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency (option D), except that the plasma citrulline concentration is greatly elevated.

Other options:

Option A: In the near-complete enzymatic deficiency of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase 1, symptoms appear during the 1st few days or even hours of life. the baby presents with the signs and symptoms of hyperammonemia (refusal to eat, vomiting, lethargy, convulsion, coma). Increased intracranial pressure is frequent. Orotic aciduria and increased production of pyrimidines like uracil in this case are not seen in Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase 1 deficiency.

Option C: Arginase deficiency is a rare distal urea cycle disorder that presents as acute neonatal form with intractable seizures, cerebral edema, and death. Laboratory findings include marked elevations of arginine in plasma and CSF.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: A cancer patient undergoing radiotherapy is given a dose of 1.8-2Gy once daily for 5 days a week for a duration of 6-8 weeks. This type of radiotherapy is called ____________.
questions.solution:
Conventional fractionated radiotherapy is the type of radiotherapy given in the above scenario. It is given once daily for 5 days/ week, with no more than 2 Gy/ fraction(fx).

Radiation therapy is usually divided or “fractionated” over a treatment course lasting multiple weeks. Fractionation is the process of dividing a dose of radiation into multiple “fractions”. This practice seeks to maximise the destruction of malignant cells while minimising damage to healthy tissues.

The different types of fractionated radiation therapy are:

  1. Conventional/Standard Fractionation: Once daily, 5 days/week, no more than 2 Gy/ fraction(fx).
  2. Accelerated Fractionation: Any fractionation schedule that gives >10 Gy/week. Subtypes include:
  3. Hypofractionation: Increased fraction size, with or without a decreased number of fractions/week.
  4. Hyperfractionation: Decreased fraction size with more than one fraction per day (BID or TID).

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding the graph shown below are true except?

choices.text: The first urge to void is felt at a volume of about 300 mL
The sense of fullness is felt at a volume of about 400 mL
The flatness of segment Ib is due to law of Laplace

questions.solution:
The above graph is a cystometrogram. The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL and not at 300 mL.

Cystometrogram is a  plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of fluid in the bladder. The curve shows three segments:

  • Ia where an initial slight rise in pressure when the first increments in the volume are produced
  • Ib where a long, nearly flat segment as further increments are produced
  • II where a sudden, sharp rise in pressure as the micturition reflex is triggered

The flatness of segment Ib is a demonstration of the law of Laplace. The law of Laplace states that the pressure (P) in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension (T) divided by the radius (R). This is expressed as P= 2T/R

In the blad­der, the tension increases as the bladder get filled. But as the radius too increases the increase in pressure is slight until the bladder is relatively full. The marked sense of fullness is felt at a bladder volume of about 400 mL.

questions.text: A patient presented to a primary care physician with complaints of depression. She takes a monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitor. The physician added another anti-depressant following which she developed restlessness, fever, extreme agitation with hyperreflexia, and autonomic instability. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be added?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient who is on a Monoamine Oxidase (MAO) develops diarrhea, restlessness, fever, extreme agitation with hyperreflexia, and autonomic instability which is suggestive of serotonin syndrome. The newly added drug must have been a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). Among the given options, fluoxetine is an SSRI.

When an SSRI is administered along with an MAO-I, tramadol, and pethidine, plasma levels of serotonin are raised resulting in serotonin syndrome. Clinical features of serotonin syndrome include diarrhea, agitation, restlessness, rigidity, hyperthermia, hyperreflexia, autonomic instability, twitchings followed by convulsions, delirium, coma, status epilepticus, cardio­ vascular collapse, and death.

Treatment involves removing the offending agent and supportive care. 

Other options:

Option B: Imipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant. Common side effects include anticholinergic symptoms, sedation, weight gain, and cardiac arrhythmias. TCAs given with MAO inhibitors can result in hypertensive crisis with excitement and hallucinations.

Option C: Mirtazapine acts by enhancing noradrenaline and 5-HT release. It helps patients with insomnia. Common side effects include increased appetite and weight gain. It doesn't cause sexual dysfunction.

Option D: Trazadone is also an atypical antidepressant. Common side effects include postural hypotension and priapism.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has frequent episodes of fever with a productive cough and frequent headaches. On examination, his second heart sound was prominently heard on the right side of the chest. The patient reported infertility for the past 7 years. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen in the lungs of this patient?

choices.text: Dilated airways in the lower lobes
Collapse of the right lower lobe

questions.solution:
The given scenario describes Kartegener syndrome. The findings of bronchiectasis will be seen in the lung, which is dilated airways in the lower lobes.

Kartagener syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive genetic ciliary disorder presenting with the classical triad of:

  • Situs inversus - leading to the right-sided heartbeat
  • Chronic sinusitis - leading to headaches
  • Bronchiectasis - leading to fever, excessive productive cough, and foul-smelling expectoration.

Bronchiectasis is defined as the permanent dilation of bronchi and bronchioles caused by the destruction of the smooth muscle and the supporting elastic tissue by chronic necrotizing infections.

It presents as a severe, persistent cough with foul-smelling expectoration, and on occasion bloody sputum and hemoptysis. In severe cases, it may present as orthopnea, dyspnea, cor pulmonale, brain abscess, and amyloidosis.

In bronchiectasis, normal clearing mechanisms are impaired, either due to congenital causes or due to bronchial obstruction which results in pooling of secretions, secondary infection, and inflammation, often with necrosis, fibrosis, and eventually dilation of airways as shown below:

Bronchiectasis usually affects the lower lobes bilaterally, with a predilection to vertical segments and distal bronchi and bronchioles. The airways are dilated up to four times the normal size and a probe can sometimes be passed all the way to the pleural surface. On the cut surface, the bronchi appear as cystic and are filled with mucopurulent secretions as shown below.

Other options:

Option A - Panacinar emphysema is seen in cases of α1-antitrypsin deficiency.

Option C - Collapse of the right lower lobe is not associated with bronchiectasis.

Option D - Interstitial fibrosis is seen in diseases like idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criterion for day care surgery?

choices.text: Ability to tolerate oral fluids and feeding
Able to mobilise with or without aid
Adequate pain control with oral analgesia

questions.solution:
Minimal post operative nausea and vomitting is not a criteria for consideration for day care surgery.

The criteria for a day care surgery is:

  • Patient should be able to mobilise with or without aid
  • There must be a low risk of significant immediate post op complications
  • Oral analgesia in conjunction with local anesthesia or nerve blocks should be able to provide adequate pain control
  • Patient should be able to tolerate oral fluids or feeds.

Daycare surgery is defined as the admission and discharge of a patient for a specific procedure within a 12-hour working day. Success in day surgery requires each component of the pathway to be safe and efficient and to be performed in sequence. Unplanned overnight admissions are minimized by ensuring that:

  • the patient is informed and fit for the procedure
  • the procedure itself is achievable as a day case
  • the procedure is scheduled early on the operating list to allow safe recovery and discharge
  • the home environment can support a postoperative ambulatory patient.

Physical fitness for the procedure, short duration, and a home environment that can support recovery and postoperative care are all important factors when choosing daycare surgery for a patient.

Some procedures that qualify for daycare surgery are listed below-

  • Arthroscopies
  • Biopsy (temporal, lymph node)
  • Reducing a strangulated hernia
  • Incision and drainage of an abscess 
  • K-wiring of a finger or wrist bone fracture
  • Laparoscopic appendicectomy

Patient's having daycare surgery can usually be discharged when they have stable vitals, have adequately controlled pain from oral analgesics, can perform basic activities on their own, have no evidence of incision site bleeding, have a designated caregiver, and have all the instructions required for further management at home and instructions in case of an emergency.

questions.text: A genital examination is being performed on a patient with perineal laceration post-vaginal delivery. The tear extends into the fascia and the musculature of the perineal body but the anal sphincter muscles remain intact.  Which of the following grades of perineal laceration does this correspond to?
questions.solution:
As the tear extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body and the anal sphincter muscles remain intact indicates this is a second-degree perineal tear.

The perineal tear is more common in primigravida and results from over-stretching or sudden stretching of the perineum during childbirth. Trauma to the perineum can also result in perineal tears.

Clinical features include the inability to hold the flatus and feces. Soreness over the peri-anal region can be seen due to constant irritation by stool. Palpation reveals the decreased/absence of a sphincteric grip depending on the degree of tear.

All recent tears should be repaired immediately. If there is a delay of 24 hours, the repair has to be withheld and the patient has to be started on antibiotics to prevent infection. Complete perineal tears that were not repaired in the first 24 hours should be operated on between 3-6 months after delivery. In 3 months of time, any local infection that might have been present would subside, and the general condition of the patient will also improve. However, if the perineal tear is untreated for more than 6 months, dense scar tissue forms making the surgery difficult.

questions.text: Which is the most common feeding regime-related complication following total parenteral nutrition (TPN)?
questions.solution:
Hyperglycaemia is found in up to 50% of parenteral nutrition patients. Important predictors are insulin resistance or diabetes mellitus, severity of the underlying illness, concomitant steroid therapy, and the amount of glucose provided.

Complications of parenteral nutrition

Related to nutrient deficiency

  • Hypoglycaemia, hypocalcaemia
  • Hypophosphataemia & hypomagnesaemia (refeeding syndrome)
  • Chronic deficiency syndromes (essential fatty acids, zinc, mineral and trace elements)

Related to overfeeding

  • Excess glucose: hyperglycaemia, hyperosmolar dehydration, hepatic steatosis, hypercapnia, increased sympathetic activity, fluid retention, electrolyte abnormalities
  • Excess fat: hypercholesterolaemia and formation of lipoprotein X, hypertriglyceridaemia, hypersensitivity reactions
  • Excess amino acids: hyperchloraemic metabolic acidosis, hypercalcaemia, aminoacidaemia, uraemia

Related to sepsis

  • Catheter-related sepsis
  • Possible increased predisposition to systemic sepsis

Related to line

  • On insertion: pneumothorax, damage to adjacent artery, air embolism, thoracic duct damage, cardiac perforation or tamponade, pleural effusion, hydromediastinum
  • Long-term use: occlusion, venous thrombosis

questions.text: You are examining a 6-month-old infant with delayed development and persistent hypocalcemia. He has a cleft lip and a cleft palate. An echo at birth had shown an atrial septal defect. Which test should be done additionally in this patient with regards to his clinical presentation?

choices.text: Flow cytometry to assess T cell levels

questions.solution:
This patient with hypocalcemia, cleft palate, atrial septal defect and delayed development most likely has DiGeorge Syndrome. A flow cytometry should be done in this patient to assess his T cell function to guide future therapy. 

DiGeorge syndrome is a clinical syndrome that occurs due to a deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22. It results from the failure of the development of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches. They give rise to the thymus, the parathyroids, some of the C cells of the thyroid, and the ultimobranchial body.

The absence of cell-mediated immunity causes poor defense against certain fungal and viral infections. The T-cell zones of lymphoid organs, i.e. paracortical areas of the lymph nodes and the periarteriolar sheaths of the spleen, are depleted. Ig levels may be normal or reduced, depending on the severity of the T-cell deficiency. T cell function is evaluated to guide further management like vaccination recommendations and requirement for any antibiotic prophylaxis. 

Other options:
Option 1: X Ray of the chest can be used to look for absence of thymus but it is a very non specific sign and is present in only 15% of cases.

Option 2: Serum phenylalanine levels can be measured to rule out Phenylketonuria(PKU). Phenylketonuria (PKU) results from a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. It manifests as a progressive intellectual disability. Patients with PKU have a musty or mousy odor due to phenylacetic acid accumulation and a positive dinitrophenylhydrazine test. The given symptoms are consistent with diGeorge syndrome. 

Option 3: MRI of the brain can be done to evaluate organic causes of delayed development. However this patient has the classic features of diGeorge syndrome and should be evaluated for T cell function. 

Related Pearl: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

  • C – Cardiac defects
  • A – Abnormal facies
  • T – Thymic aplasia
  • C – Cleft palate
  • H – Hypocalcemia

The image below shows the abnormal facies in DiGeorge syndrome.

questions.text: A patient underwent lung transplant due to idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis 2 years ago. Over the past 7 months, he has had a progressive decrease in pulmonary function on serial spirometry. A biopsy shows lymphocytic infiltrate and fibrosed airways. What is this pattern of rejection called?
questions.solution:
This patient's history of lung transplantation with progressively worsening pulmonary function suggests chronic graft rejection. The biopsy findings of a lymphocytic infiltrate with fibrosed airways are typical of bronchiolitis obliterans syndrome(BOS). 

BOS is the classic form of lung rejection and more than 50% of patients who receive a lung transplant will develop it to some extent in 5 years. It is characterised by breathlessness and cough that develops after months to years after a transplant. There should be persistence of symptoms for more than 3 weeks and other causes of graft dysfunction should be excluded.

Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy which shows the lymphocytic infiltrate and fibrosis of the terminal airways with alveolar sparing.  A CT scan shows fibrosis and thickening of the bronchial walls and a mosaic pattern persists due to air trapping. 

Treatment is by augmentation of immunosuppression as the disease course is thought to be a form of organ rejection. 

Other Options:

Acute cellular rejection occurs within days to weeks of a transplant. This patient has had the symptoms 2 years after the transplant. 

Vanishing airway syndrome also called vanishing bronchus syndrome presents post-transplant with necrotic changes in the walls of the bronchus. It is very rare and is unlikely to be the cause of this patient's symptoms. 

Graft versus host disease rarely involves the lungs and is unlikely to be the cause of this patient's symptoms. 

Related Pearl: Classification of Transplant Rejection Reactions

Hyperacute rejection (minutes to hours):

  • Mechanism: Antidonor antibodies present in the circulation of the recipient
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Grossly, cyanotic and mottled graft with pale white areas
    • Neutrophils accumulate
    • Acute fibrinoid necrosis of vessel walls or complete occlusion by thrombi

Acute rejection (days to weeks):

  1. Acute cellular rejection (acute T cell-mediated rejection):  
    • Mechanism: CD8+ CTLs directly destroy graft or CD4+ cells secrete cytokines that damage graft.
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Tubulointerstitial pattern (type I): extensive interstitial and tubular inflammation associated with focal tubular injury
      • Vascular pattern - Inflammation (type II) and necrosis (type III): Endotheliitis (swollen endothelial cells with lymphocytes between endothelium and vessel wall)
  2. Acute antibody-mediated (humoral) rejection: 
    • Mechanism: antibodies bind to endothelium and activate complement causing damage and graft failure
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Inflammation of glomeruli and peritubular capillaries.
      • Activation of the antibody-dependent classical complement pathway.
      • Focal thrombosis in small vessels. 

Chronic rejection (months to years):

  • Mechanism: T-cells react against alloantigens and secrete cytokines which stimulate fibroblasts and vascular smooth muscle cells (graft arteriosclerosis). Chronic rejection may also be antibody-mediated.
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Predominantly vascular changes (intimal thickening and vascular occlusion)
    • Glomerulopathy with duplication of basement membrane
    • Interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy with loss of renal parenchyma

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with fever, earache, and stiffness on opening the mouth. On examination, the parotid gland is enlarged, as shown below, and tender. Choose the correct strain used to prepare a vaccine for this disease.
questions.solution:
The clinical diagnosis in this case, based on clinical features and image, is most likely Mumps. The strain used to prepare the Mumps vaccine is Jeryl Lynn. It is a live attenuated vaccine.

Mumps is an infectious disease caused by an RNA virus from the paramyxoviridae family. Infection is caused by air droplets through the respiratory route and also through the conjunctiva.

The incubation period is 12-25 days. Then parotid swelling appears first. It is unilateral, to begin with, but may become bilateral. Some patients may have a prodrome of fever and malaise before the swelling appears.

Major complications of Mumps include epididymal orchitis and meningoencephalitis.

Mumps vaccine is given only after one year of age because, before that, maternal antibodies may interfere with its action. It can be given separately or as a part of Measles, Mumps, Rubella (MMR) vaccine.

Other options:

Option A: Edmonston-Zagreb strain is used for the Measles vaccine.

Option B: The 17D strain is used for the Yellow fever vaccine.

Option C: The Oka strain is used for the Varicella vaccine.

questions.text:
The MELD score of a husband and wife with end-stage liver disease is 25. They have been waiting for a liver transplant since 1 year. However with the recent update in the MELD 3.0 scoring system, what changes can be expected in both their scores?

MELD- Model for end-stage liver disease
questions.solution:
The female gender and serum albumin are the new components that have been added to the MELD 3.0 scoring system. Therefore in the above scenario, the wife’s score will increase and the husband’s score will remain the same.
The Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) is used as an indicator of short-term survival in patients with end-stage liver disease, and to determine organ allocation priorities for liver transplantation. Patients with high scores have poor prognoses without intervention and should therefore be prioritized for transplantation if eligible.
The components of the original MELD model were:

  • Serum creatinine
  • Serum bilirubin
  • INR (international normalized ratio)

In 2016, it was modified to incorporate serum sodium (the MELD-Na score).
The latest MELD 3.0 scoring system has added two additional components:

  • Serum albumin
  • Female gender

MELD 3.0 effectively predicts short-term mortality among patients with end-stage liver disease in the modern era and specifically addresses the existing sex disparity on the liver transplant wait. It is able to correctly reclassify almost 9% of patients to a higher MELD tier, giving them a much better chance of transplantation, particularly in women. It is estimated that almost 20 waitlist deaths can be reduced per year with the new MELD 3.0 scoring system.

Related Pearl: Revised Model for End-stage liver disease (MELD) scoring system: MELD 3.0

MELD 3.0 score has the following components (Mnemonic F BASIC)

  • Female sex
  • Bilirubin
  • Albumin
  • Serum sodium (mEq/L)
  • INR (International Normalized ratio)
  • Creatinine

Uses:

  • Predict short-term prognosis in patients undergoing transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) insertion
  • Assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation
  • Assess prognosis in cirrhosis

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the casualty after he was found unconscious by his mother. Intracranial pressure was found elevated. He has multiple casualty visits. His retina findings are shown below. What other coexisting lesion is he likely to have?
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of multiple retinal hemorrhages(cotton wool spots). In this patient with a history of multiple casualty visits and raised ICT, shaken baby syndrome should be suspected. In a child who has undergone abuse, another finding is Knob fractures which appear as a string of beads in the paravertebral region on x-ray. 

The battered baby syndrome refers to a constellation of clinical findings suggestive of repetitive physical abuse in a child via non-accidental violence by a parent or a guardian. Additionally, there may be associated deprivation of nutrition, care, and affection. It is usually seen in children less than 3 years of age with a history of emotional or financial problems in the family.

Clinical features:

  • Injuries of different ages and in different stages of healing
  • Bruises may be seen on either side of the chest, behind the axillae, and down the anterior chest wall indicative of the hand impressions of the perpetrator.
  • Violent shaking of a child leads to infantile whiplash syndrome. Repetitive and vigorous shaking of an infant gives rise to a triad of clinical findings—encephalopathy, retinal bleeds, and subdural hemorrhage. 
  • Multiple deformities of the long bones and ribs. Some characteristic fractures include the following:
    • Knob fractures are a result of callus formation in healing ribs that have been damaged due to squeezing. Chest x-ray shows a "string of beads" appearance in the paravertebral gutter.
    • Bucket-handle fractures are typical corner fractures near the metaphyseal regions of the long bones in the arms and legs.

Other options:

Option A: Multiple AV malformations can lead to raised ICT due to rupture leading to intracranial bleeds. However, in this patient with multiple casualty visits, child abuse should be ruled out first.

Option C: Petechial limb rashes are seen in conditions such as dengue, Henoch Schonlein purpura, and bleeding disorders. This patient's history does not suggest these etiologies.

Option D: Boot-shaped heart is seen in the tetralogy of Fallot. While cyanotic conditions can cause pulmonary hypertension and eventually systemic hypertension, they rarely cause raised ICT. Hence child abuse should be suspected first

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman presents with a throbbing unilateral headache, which is aggravated by movement and is associated with photophobia. What is the most appropriate drug for the management in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of throbbing unilateral headache which is aggravated by movement and is associated with photophobia is suggestive of migraine. The drug of choice for migraine in pregnancy is paracetamol.

Migraine is characterized by unilateral and throbbing headaches often associated with nausea, vomiting, sensitivity to light and sound, flashes of light, vertigo, and loose motions. Migraines can be divided into migraine with aura (classical migraine) in which the headache is preceded by visual or other neurological symptoms, and migraine without aura.

Drug therapy in migraine

Moderate

Severe

prophylaxis

  • Propranolol/other β blockers

  • Amitriptyline/other tricyclic antidepressants

  • Flunarizine/other Ca2+ channel blockers

  • Valproate/topiramate

However, in pregnancy, paracetamol is used for acute migraine attacks. The triptans (sumatriptan, zolmitriptan, naratriptan), dihydroergotamine and ergotamine are contraindicated in pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Simplified diagnostic criteria for migraine

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination with no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

At least 2 of the following features:

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at least 1 of the following features:

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child is brought with complaints of delayed developmental milestones and intellectual disability. On examination, the child had coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, and a clear cornea. Which of the following recombinant enzymes is useful in treating this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with intellectual disability, coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, and a clear cornea is suggestive of Hunter's disease. Idursulfase a.k.a Elaprase is used in the treatment of this condition.

Hunter's disease is also known as mucopolysaccharidosis II (MPS II) resulting from the deficiency of iduronate sulfatase. This causes the accumulation of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate.

All MPS are inherited in an AR manner, except Hunter’s disease which is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner. The clinical features include coarse facies, gingival hyperplasia, macroglossia, short stature, dysostosis multiplex, macrocephaly, intellectual disability, and hepatosplenomegaly. Unlike other mucopolysaccharidosis, these patients lack clouding of the cornea.  

Elaprase a.k.a Idursulfase (Recombinant iduronate-2-sulfatase) is the treatment of choice for Hunter's disease to ameliorate nonneural manifestations.

Other options:

Option A: Aldurazyme a.k.a Laronidase in the treatment of Hurler's disease, also known as mucopolysaccharidosis type I. It is characterized by facial dysmorphism, hepatosplenomegaly, corneal clouding, upper airway obstruction, skeletal deformity, and cardiomyopathy. 

Option C: Galsulfase a.k.a Naglazyme is used in the treatment of Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis type VI). It is characterized by macrocephaly, hydrocephalus, macroglossia, short stature, marked corneal clouding, and contractures. 

Option D: Myozyme a.k.a alglucosidase alfa, a recombinant form of alpha-1,4-glucosidase is used in the treatment of Pompe's disease. Clinical features include hypotonia (floppy baby syndrome), motor delay, cardiomegaly, macroglossia, hepatomegaly, failure to thrive, and poor feeding.

questions.text: Identify the bacteria based on the culture and microscopy findings shown below.
questions.solution:
The culture showing alpha hemolysis on blood agar, with optochin (Op) sensitivity, and microscopy showing gram-positive lancet-shaped diplococci, suggests Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus).

S. pneumoniae (pneumococci) is a member of the S. mitis group. The virulence of the organism is a function of its polysaccharide capsule, which prevents or delays ingestion by phagocytes.

They are normal inhabitants of the upper respiratory tract of 5–40% of humans but can cause pneumonia, sinusitis, otitis, bronchitis, bacteremia, meningitis, and peritonitis. Clinical features of pneumococcal pneumonia include sudden onset fever, chills, sharp pleural pain, and cough with bloody/ rusty sputum.

Diagnosis is by the presence of typical gram-positive diplococci in stained sputum samples. After some time, the organisms rapidly become gram-negative and tend to lyse spontaneously. This autolysis of pneumococci is greatly enhanced by surface-active agents, such as ox bile (10%) or sodium deoxycholate (2%).

Pneumococci are alpha-hemolytic on blood agar, and this is seen as greening of agar around the colonies. It is sensitive to optochin and shows a zone of inhibition, more than 14 mm around the optochin disk. This helps to differentiate pneumococcus from Streptococcus viridans.

They show characteristic Quellung reaction. When pneumococci of a certain type are mixed with specific antipolysaccharide serum of the same type (or with polyvalent antiserum) on a microscope slide, the capsule swells markedly and is seen as a halo around the organism. A positive reaction shows clumping because of cross-linking of the antibodies and pneumococci.

questions.text: The banding technique used for staining the telomeres of chromosomes is:
questions.solution:
The banding technique used for staining the telomeres of chromosomes is T banding.

Karyotyping is the process by which chromosomes are isolated, stained, and examined to find chromosomal anomalies. It is used in prenatal diagnosis, investigation of repeat pregnancy loss, investigation of children and adults suspected of having a chromosomal disorder, and subtyping of lymphomas and leukemias for the purpose of exact diagnosis, giving a prognosis, and treatment. Various techniques are used in karyotyping to study chromosomes. Staining with various compounds produces various results and helps us to understand the chromosomes better. Common techniques used are:

  • Q banding - Fluorescence staining with quinacrine mustard
  • G banding - Giemsa staining after partial denaturation of chromatin. It is the most common technique used in cytogenetics to produce a visible karyotype.
  • R banding - Reverse Giemsa staining. In this, the light and dark areas are reversed
  • C banding - Staining of heterochromatin with silver salts
  • T banding - Staining the telomeres of chromosomes

questions.text: The most predominant retinal glial cells are present in which of the following layers of the retina?
questions.solution:
The most predominant retinal glial cells are the radial (Müller) cells, whose nuclei lie within the inner nuclear layer (2).

From this region a single thick fibre ascends radially, giving off complex lateral lamellae which branch among the processes of the outer plexiform layer. 

The structures marked are as follows-

  1. Inner Plexiform Layer 
  2. Internal Nuclear Layer
  3. Outer Plexiform Layer 
  4. Outer Nuclear Layer

Radial glial cells span the entire thickness of the neural retina. They form the outer boundary of the retinal tissue at the level of the inner rod and cone segments, and the inner boundary at the internal limiting membrane.

Retinal astrocytes are largely confined to the ganglion cell and nerve fibre layers whereas microglial cells are scattered throughout the neural part of the retina in small numbers.

The retina consists of 10 layers, with retinal pigment epithelium(RPE) being the outermost layer below the Bruch's membrane of the choroid and the internal limiting membrane being the innermost layer separating the retina from the vitreous.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presented with behavioral changes and memory loss which which has progressively worsened over the past several years. The physician noticed abnormal writhing movements in both her hands. Genetic investigation revealed trinucleotide repeats. Which of the following cerebral blood flow patterns is likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Bilateral reduction in blood flow to caudate nucleus
Decreased blood flow to temporal lobes
Decreased blood flow in olivopontocerebellar area
Decreased blood flow to the midbrain

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, symptoms of behavioural changes, progressive memory loss, abnormal writhing movements and hyperactive reflexes are suggestive of Huntington's disease. The presence of trinucleotide repeats on genetic evaluation confirms the diagnosis.

In Huntington's disease, progressive atrophy of the head of the caudate nucleus can be visualized on MRI hence bilateral reduction in blood flow to the caudate nucleus will be seen.

Huntington's disease (HD) also known as Huntington chorea, is a progressive, fatal,  autosomal dominant disorder characterized by an abnormal expansion of the trinucleotide CAG in the Huntington gene on chromosome 4.

HD is characterized by rapid, nonpatterned, semi-purposeful, involuntary choreiform movements along with dysarthria, gait disturbance, behavioural disturbance, and cognitive impairment with dementia.

The disease predominantly affects the striatum but progresses to involve the cerebral cortex and other brain regions. More diffuse cortical atrophy can be seen in the middle and late stages of the disease. Reduced metabolic activity in the caudate nucleus and putamen and reduced brain metabolites on MR spectroscopy can be seen.

Other options: 

Option B: Decreased blood flow to temporal lobes is associated with Alzheimer's disease.

Option C: Decreased blood flow in the olivopontocerebellar area is seen in Multisystem atrophy (MSA), which is a type of Parkinson-plus syndrome. It is associated with cerebellar and brainstem atrophy and MRI shows a hot cross bun sign in the pons.

Option D: Decreased blood flow to the midbrain is associated with progressive supranuclear palsy(PSP) which is a Parkinson-plus syndrome. MRI shows the characteristic hummingbird sign, a name derived from predominant midbrain atrophy with preserved pons.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old child presents with muscle weakness, vomiting, and seizures accompanied by focal neurological deficits. Her developmental milestones were normal during the previous visits. Laboratory tests show lactic acidosis and microscopic findings of muscle biopsy are shown below. What is the likely underlying defect that is present in this patient?

ETC - Electron transport chain
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of vomiting, seizures, lactic acidosis, and muscle biopsy showing ragged red fibers (arrowhead) is suggestive of MELAS (mitochondrial encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke). It is due to defects in mitochondrial proteins like ETC complex I or complex IV. 

MELAS is a mitochondrial inherited condition due to deficiency of complex I (NADH-Q oxidoreductase) or complex IV(cytochrome oxidase). Children usually present with recurrent attacks of a migraine-like headache, anorexia, vomiting, seizures, proximal myopathy, encephalopathy, stroke, altered consciousness, and cardiomyopathy. Children with MELAS are also frequently found to have short stature. The microscopy of muscle biopsy with modified Gomori trichrome staining shows ragged red fibers with a background of blue myofibres. 

Mitochondrial DNA is transmitted by maternal non-mendelian inheritance. It has 37 genes that encode 13 protein subunits of the electron transport chain (ETC). It has 16,569 bp which makes up approximately 1% of total cellular DNA. It is circular, double-stranded, and has a high mutation rate.

Other options:

Option B: Pompe's disease results from a deficiency in the enzyme lysosomal alpha-glucosidase.

Option C: McArdle disease results due to a deficiency of the enzyme muscle glycogen phosphorylase.

Option D: A defect in the DNA helicase enzyme is associated with ataxia-telangiectasia, Bloom syndrome and Werner syndrome.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient presents with epigastric pain after a night of binge drinking. He is resuscitated with IV fluids and painkillers. As per Ranson's criteria, which of the following would be associated with a poor prognosis after 48 hours of admission?
questions.solution:
Increased Blood urea nitrogen of more than 5mg/dl in spite of IV fluid hydration is a part of the Ransons criteria after 48 hrs that indicates a poor prognosis for this patient.

This patient presenting after a night of binge drinking with epigastric abdominal pain should raise concerns for acute pancreatitis. Initial resuscitation is with IV fluids, maintaining an NPO status, and giving adequate pain control. The Ransons Criteria is used for calculating the likely prognosis of a patient with acute pancreatitis, of which elevated Blood urea nitrogen is a component. Ranson’s criteria is a clinical criterion used to calculate the prognosis of a patient who presents with acute pancreatitis. It has two scales, one used on admission and one used after 48 hours. An increase in Blood urea nitrogen is an indication of a worsening fluid status of the patient in terms of worsening third spacing of fluid or kidney injury.


Other Options: 

Option B: Increased glucose of >200mg/dl is a criterion in Ranson’s scale used for evaluation on admission but not after 48 hours. 

Option A: Decreased Vitamin B-12 is a common finding in alcoholics but has no correlation with acute pancreatitis.

Option D: Raised Hematocrit is not a component of Ranson’s criteria, rather, a decreased hematocrit by >10% is associated with a poor prognosis.

questions.text: Which of the following receptors is not matched correctly with the appropriate substances, agents, or microbes they recognize?

choices.text: NOD-like receptor - uric acid and released ATP

questions.solution:
RIG-like receptors (RLRs) are present in the cytosol of a majority of cells and detect nucleic acids of viruses that replicate in the cytoplasm of the infected cells. These receptors also stimulate the production of antiviral cytokines.

NOD-like receptors (NLRs) are present in the cytosol, which recognize products released from damaged/necrotic cells(uric acid and ATP), ion disturbances (like loss of K+), and a few microbial products. Most of the NLRs signal via a cytosolic multiprotein complex called the inflammasome. This activates the enzyme caspase-1 that generates the biologically active form of cytokine interleukin-1 (IL-1). IL-1 is a mediator of inflammation that acts by recruiting leukocytes and inducing fever. Gain-of-function mutations in NOD-like receptor results in periodic fever syndromes, also known as autoinflammatory syndromes. These syndromes respond very well to treatment with IL-1 antagonists. The NLR-inflammasome pathway also plays a role in the recognition of urate crystals (inflammation associated with gout) and the detection of lipids and cholesterol crystals.

C-type lectin receptors (CLRs) are present on the plasma membrane of macrophages and dendritic cells which detect fungal glycans and elicit an inflammatory response to different fungi.

Mannose receptors recognize microbial sugars that contain terminal mannose residues and induce phagocytosis of these microbes.

questions.text: While doing a study on various family cycles, you come across a nuclear family where the mother and father are currently the only ones remaining after their first daughter got married in 2020 and their second daughter got married in 2022. Which phase in the family cycle does this correspond to?
questions.solution:
The given scenario corresponds to the Completed contraction phase in the family cycle. It begins when the last child leaves the parental home and ends with the death of 1st spouse.

The family is the basic unit in all societies. It is the most powerful example of social cohesion. 

Families are not constant, they are ever-changing. A normal family cycle is generally conceived as having six phases- formation, extension, complete extension, contraction, complete contraction, and dissolution.

Related Pearl: The Family as a Social Organization

  • A family is a group of biologically related individuals living together under the same roof and eating from a common kitchen.
  • It is the most primary and basic unit of all societies.
  • The basic and arbitrary model of a family cycle has six phases:

  • Types of families:
    • A nuclear family or elementary family consists of only the married couple and their offspring while they are dependants.
    • The term new family is applied when nuclear families are younger than 10 years and consist of parents and children.
    • A joint family or extended family consists of a number of married couples and their children who live together in the same household with usually the men being related by blood. All property in joint families is held in common with the family income going into a common pocket. A senior male member is usually the head of the family who makes decisions.
    • A three generation family is one where there are representatives from three different generations in one house.
    • A communal family is one in which all the members play a part in its management.
  • Functions of the family:
    • Residence (patrilocal and matrilocal)
    • Division of labour
    • Reproduction and raising children
    • Socialization and social care
    • Economic functions
  • Problems families are those that lag behind the rest of the community in terms of standard and quality of life of its members.
  • Broken families are those in which the parental or family system has been disrupted by separation, divorce or death.

questions.text: Q. A alcoholic middle-aged man was brought to the ER after having a sudden episode of hematemesis. He has had 3 episodes of vomiting before presentation. Currently, he has ongoing vomiting with more blood in the vomitus. Apart from emergent IV cannulation and fluids, what else should be done for this patient?
questions.solution:
The above patient presenting with hematemesis with ongoing bleeding is likely at risk of aspiration and should be emergently intubated via Rapid sequence intubation. This should be done prior to any other invasive intervention like upper GI endoscopy to prevent aspiration complications.

The management of esophageal variceal bleeding involves:

  • Resuscitation with IV fluids, airway protection(intubation to protect airway and prevent aspiration), and oxygen
  • Blood transfusion to maintain Hb between 7-9g/dL
  • Antibiotic prophylaxis with ceftriaxone before endoscopy
  • An attempt at hemostasis with octreotide or terlipressin or vasopressin
  • Upper GI endoscopy within 12 hours after fluid resuscitation to confirm the source of the bleed
  • Endoscopic variceal band ligation or sclerotherapy
  • In case, of failure or rebleeding - TIPS

Liver transplantation is the definitive management to treat portal hypertension and variceal bleeding.

questions.text: A young butcher presents with headache, vomiting, dizziness, visual impairment, and altered mental status. On performing a CT scan, ring-enhancing lesions are found, along with some nodular calcifications. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a butcher with the given symptoms, along with the CT scan showing ring-enhancing lesions with some nodular calcifications, is suggestive of neurocysticercosis. This condition is caused by Taenia solium.

T. solium is also known as the pork tapeworm. Humans are the only definitive hosts for T. solium, whereas pigs are the usual intermediate host. When humans consume undercooked pork containing cysticerci, they acquire the infection leading to intestinal tapeworms.

Cysticerci can be found anywhere in the body but are most commonly detected in the brain, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), skeletal muscle, subcutaneous tissue, or the eye. Neurocysticercosis usually presents with neurological manifestations like seizures and hydrocephalus. Symptoms of increased intracranial pressure are often seen.

Diagnosis is made by the detection of eggs or proglottids in the stool. More sensitive methods like ELISA and PCR may also be used. Clinical diagnosis can only be made with the help of neuroimaging findings and exposure history.

Major neuroimaging findings include cystic lesions with or without enhancement, nodular calcifications, focal enhancing lesions, or multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space.

Brain parenchymal cysticerci are treated with a combination of praziquantel and albendazole. These drugs cause inflammatory responses around the deadly parasite, and therefore glucocorticoids should also be started along with antihelminthic.

The image given below shows an MRI of the brain that shows multiple cysts containing scolices in a patient with neurocysticercosis.

Other options:

Option B: Only the adult forms of T. saginata develop in humans and not the cysticerci. Therefore, it cannot cause cysticercosis in humans.

Option C: Bacteroides spp. is a causative organism for brain abscesses which are seen on a contrast-enhanced CT as ring-enhancing lesions. However, such a brain abscess is usually secondary to otitis media, mastoiditis, or paranasal sinusitis. This patient does not have any other disease, which makes brain abscess less likely.

The image given below shows a brain abscess.

Option D: Toxoplasma gondi causes toxoplasmosis. It is one of the most common causes of secondary CNS infection in AIDS patients. It usually occurs as a late complication when CD4+ T-cell counts <200/μL. It presents with fever, headache, and neurological deficits. MRI shows ring enhancement lesions in the brain due to inflammation and central necrosis in the lesions.

The image given below shows ring-enhancing lesions seen in cerebral toxoplasmosis.

Differential diagnoses for ring-enhancing lesions include:

  • Brain abscess
  • Toxoplasmosis
  • Central nervous system lymphoma
  • Tuberculoma

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient presented with polymorphous, erythematous patches with itching over his lower limbs, buttocks, and chest for the past 3 years. He has cervical lymphadenopathy. The peripheral blood smear shows lymphocytes with a cerebriform appearance. What will be the histopathological examination findings in this case?

choices.text: Band like Lymphocytic infiltrate in dermo epidermal junction

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly male with polymorphous, erythematous patches with pruritus and peripheral smear of lymphocytes with cerebriform appearance is suggestive of Mycosis fungoides. Lymphocyte-predominant micro abscesses known as Pautriers’s microabscesses are seen in this condition.

Mycosis fungoides is cutaneous T cell lymphoma (CD4+ Helper T cells) which usually stays confined to the skin. It usually involves limb/ girdle, breast, and especially the buttock area. It can disseminate into the blood which is known as Sezary syndrome. It presents as diffuse erythema of the skin (erythroderma).

Mycoses fungoides passes through 3 phases:

  • Inflammatory pre-mycotic phase- eczema-like lesions
  • Plaque phase- raised plaques are seen
  • Tumor phase- multiple tumor nodules indicating systemic spread

The image given below shows phases seen in mycosis fungoides.

Histological hallmark includes:

  • Sézary-Lutzner cells - cells with cerebriform nuclei (infolded/ hyper-convoluted nuclear membrane).
  • Pautrier's microabscesses - tumor cells invade the epidermis as single cells and small clusters.
  • Epidermotropism - the invasion of the tumor cells into the epidermis.

The image given below shows histological markers seen in mycosis fungoides.

Other options

Option A: Neutrophil predominant micro abscess (Munro microabscess) is seen in Psoriasis.

Histopathological Features of Psoriasis

  • Irregular epidermal thickening (Acanthosis)
  • Hyperkeratosis and Parakeratosis
  • Suprapapillary thinning
  • Clubbing of rete ridges at the base
  • Kogoj spongiform pustules (collection of neutrophils in Malpighian layer)
  • Munro microabscesses (collection of neutrophils in Stratum corneum)
  • Absence of stratum granulosum
  • Dilated, tortuous blood vessels in Dermis
  • Suprapapillary mononuclear leukocytic infiltrates

Remember:  M (munro microabscess) is seen in P (Psoriasis) and P (pautrier’s microabscess) is seen in M (mycosis fungoides).

Option C: Band like Lymphocytic infiltrate in dermo epidermal junction is seen in Lichen planus.

Histopathological features of Lichen planus:

  • Increase in epidermal Langerhans cells associated with a superficial perivascular infiltrate of lymphocytes and histiocytes, impinging on the dermal–epidermal junction (DEJ).
  • Hyperkeratosis and Hypergranulosis
  • Pigment incontinence: This occurs as the melanin gradually moves into the dermis as a result of degeneration of keratinocytes.
  • The melanin in the dermis is then engulfed by the macrophages forming melanophages (Melanin-containing macrophages).
  • The degeneration leads to the formation of spaces in the epidermis known as Max-Joseph Spaces.
  • The rete ridges are pointed at their lower end giving them Saw-toothed appearance.
  • Band like Lymphocytic infiltrate is present at the Dermoepidermal junction.
  • Degenerating/Apoptotic Basal epidermal cells are known as colloid bodies (also known as Cytoid bodies/Civatte bodies), which may appear singly or in clumps.

Image: Histopathology of Lichen Planus

Option D: Tubercles with peripheral lymphocytes is seen in Lupus vulgaris

Histology of Lupus vulgaris shows tubercles with scanty or absent central caseation, surrounded by epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleate giant cells, are present in the superficial dermis. Peripheral lymphocytes are often prominent. Usually, tubercle bacilli are scanty or absent.

Section below shows epidermis with marked acanthosis and neutrophilic abcess mixed with debris in keratin layers. The papillary dermis shows epitheliod cell granuloma with multinucleated gaint cell. The granuloma are surrounded by plasma cells and lymphocytes. Few eosinophils are seen amidst chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate.

questions.text: A research fellow in biochemistry is comparing the lac operon model with tryptophan operon. The tryptophan operon is _____

choices.text: Turned on only when tryptophan is present in the growth medium
Turned off only when glucose is present in the growth medium
Turned off whenever tryptophan is added to the growth medium

questions.solution:
The tryptophan operon is a repressible operon that is turned off whenever tryptophan is added to the growth medium.

This operon contains five structural genes: trp E, trp D, trp C, trp B, and trp A, which encodes tryptophan synthetase.

It also contains a promoter that binds to RNA polymerase, and an operator which blocks transcription, when it is bound to repressor protein synthesized by the repressor gene (trp R).

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, who is a known case of chronic kidney disease and diabetes mellitus, undergoes dialysis. During the session, he became drowsy and his BP was found to be 90/70 mmHg. Which of the following is not beneficial in preventing intradialytic hypotension?

choices.text: Rapid fluid removal (>13 mL/kg per h)

questions.solution:
Intradialytic hypotension (IDH) is the most common acute complication of hemodialysis, particularly among patients with diabetes mellitus. Excessively rapid fluid removal (>13 mL/kg per h) should be avoided, as rapid fluid removal has been associated with adverse outcomes, including cardiovascular deaths.

Numerous factors appear to increase the risk of hypotension, including excessive ultrafiltration with inadequate compensatory vascular filling, impaired autonomic responses and overzealous use of antihypertensive agents.

The management of hypotension during dialysis consists of discontinuing ultrafiltration, the administration of 100–250 mL of isotonic saline or the administration of salt-poor albumin.

Hypotension during dialysis can frequently be prevented by ultrafiltration modelling, such that more fluid is removed at the beginning rather than the end of the dialysis procedure. Increasing the dialysis frequency (short-daily dialysis), sequential ultrafiltration, cooling of the dialysate, avoiding heavy meals during dialysis and individualized dialysate sodium prescription can also help prevent intradialytic hypotension

Anaphylactoid reactions to the dialyzer and muscle cramps are other complications associated with hemodialysis.

questions.text: A 10-month-old child, who was born with the defect shown below, now presents with progressive hydrocephalus, stridor and vocal cord paralysis. Brain MRI shows a small posterior fossa with displacement of the medulla, fourth ventricle, and cerebellum through the foramen magnum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows protrusion of the spinal cord and meninges through the defect In the vertebral bone, seen in meningomyelocele/ spina bifida occulta. The presence of progressive hydrocephalus and stridor in a 10-month-old child, with brain MRI showing a small posterior fossa with displacement of the medulla, fourth ventricle, and cerebellum through the foramen magnum is highly suggestive of Arnold-Chiari II malformation.

Hydrocephalus in association with type II Chiari malformation develops in at least 80% of patients with myelomeningocele.

Arnold-Chiari II malformation is characterized by progressive hydrocephalus with a myelomeningocele. This lesion represents an anomaly of the hindbrain, probably owing to a failure of pontine flexure development during embryogenesis, and results in elongation of the fourth ventricle and kinking of the brainstem, with displacement of the inferior vermis, pons, and medulla into the cervical canal. They develop symptoms of hindbrain (brainstem) dysfunction, including difficulty feeding, choking, stridor, apnea, and vocal cord paralysis.

Brain MRI shows:

  • Small posterior fossa
  • Brainstem appears 'pulled' down with an elongated and low-lying fourth ventricle
  • Cerebellar tonsils and vermis are displaced inferiorly through the foramen magnum, which appears crowded.
In myelomeningocele with Chiari malformations, the scalloping of the frontal bones is observed in the ultrasound as the lemon sign while anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa forms the banana sign. 

Other options:

Option A: The vein of Galen malformation is the most common antenatally-diagnosed intracranial vascular malformation.  MR angiograph shows an enlarged midline venous structure, with multiple arteriovenous communications leading to aneurysmal dilatation.

Option B: The Dandy-Walker malformation consists of a cystic expansion of the fourth ventricle in the posterior fossa and midline cerebellar hypoplasia. It results from a developmental failure of the roof of the fourth ventricle during embryogenesis

Option D: Arachnoid cysts of the posterior fossa can be associated with hydrocephalus. Mega cisterna magna is characterized by an enlarged CSF space inferior and dorsal to the cerebellar vermis and when present in isolation may be considered a normal variant.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A 70-year-old lady presented with a progressive diminution of central vision in the right eye. On examination, her visual acuity was 6/60 and Amsler's grid test showed central scotoma. Fundus examination revealed the following findings. Which of the following features will be seen if a fundus fluorescein angiography(FFA) is done?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of an elderly female with progressive diminution of central vision, decreased visual acuity (6/60) and amsler's grid test showing central scotoma point towards the diagnosis of macular hole. The fundus showing a full-thickness macular hole with a surrounding cuff of subretinal fluid confirms the diagnosis.

Fundus fluorescein angiography(FFA), shows early foveal hyperfluorescene without a leak. 

Optical coherence tomography (OCT) examination confirms a large full-thickness hole with posterior vitreous detached from the disc and macula.

Macular hole (MH) is a vitreoretinal interface disease characterized by a partial or full-thickness neurosensory retinal defect in the centre of the macula. Females are more commonly involved (F: M=3:1) in their sixth or seventh decade of life. Vitreo-retinal interface abnormality along with its tractional forces plays a major role in the development of macular holes.

Clinical features include decreased vision (typically around 6/60 level for a full-thickness hole and better for a partial hole), metamorphopsia or distortion of vision and central scotoma seen on Amsler's grid.

Watzke-Allen test- A thin line of light is projected over the macula with a slit lamp and the patient is asked to report on its appearance. A line appearing broken may indicate a macular hole.

Early stages do not require any treatment as spontaneous hole closure can occur. Advanced stages can be treated with pars plana vitrectomy with posterior hyaloid removal and internal limiting membrane peeling.

Other options:

Option A: Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of the macular region neurosensory retina with/without retinal pigment epithelium detachment. FFA shows two patterns of leakage, ink-blot pattern and smoke-stack pattern.

Option B: Cystoid macular edema is defined as a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform (Henle's layer) and an inner nuclear layer of the retina. FFA shows a flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance).

Option D: Age-related Macular degeneration (ARMD) also known as senile macular degeneration is a chronic and progressive bilateral degenerative disorder of the macula that affects older individuals >50 yrs. The below given FFA image below shows stars in sky appearance of Drusen.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient being evaluated for recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis is suspected to have lipoprotein lipase deficiency. Which of the following is most likely to be elevated after a fatty meal in this patient?
questions.solution:
After a fatty meal, chylomicrons are elevated in a patient with lipoprotein lipase deficiency.

Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency causes hyperchylomicronemia (Type I hyperlipoproteinemia). Chylomicrons transport dietary lipids (Mainly triacylglycerol) from the intestine to the peripheral tissues. Lipoprotein lipase hydrolyzes the triacylglycerol in the chylomicron into fatty acids and glycerol which are either used for storage or energy. Therefore, patients who are deficient in lipoprotein lipase show increased levels of chylomicrons in the plasma after a fatty meal.

Clinically, patients can have hepatosplenomegaly, eruptive xanthomas, and an increased risk of acute pancreatitis. A milky appearance of plasma can be seen due to increased levels of triglycerides.

Investigations reveal elevated levels of Chylomicrons and VLDL. The levels of LDL and HDL are low. Whereas Cholesterol levels are normal. Hence there is no risk of coronary disease.

questions.text: A male patient presented with a knee dislocation. The nerve at the level of the fibular neck is injured. All of the following can be used for the treatment of this condition, except ______.

choices.text: Transfer of tibialis posterior tendon on the dorsum of the foot.

questions.solution:
The common peroneal nerve is generally injured at the level of the fibular neck. It leads to a foot drop. Bohler-Braun splint is used in the fracture of the femur. It is an immobilizer frame, which is not suitable for transportation and hence cannot be used for nerve injuries.

The common peroneal nerve supplies the extensors and evertors of the foot. Injury to the common peroneal nerve results in foot drop. So the patient attempts to lift the leg high enough during walking so that the foot does not drag on the floor. This is known as a high-stepping gait.

Causes of common peroneal nerve injury:

  • Fracture of the fibular neck
  • Pressure from a splint or a plaster cast over the neck of the fibula
  • Knee dislocations.

Toe-raising splint and ankle-foot orthosis (AFO) brace are used for conservative treatment. Reconstructive procedures like transfer of the tibialis posterior tendon on the dorsum of the foot can be done.

The AFO brace is shown in the image below.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man, who presented with complaints of epistaxis, generalized fatigue, and multiple bruises, was found to have pallor and hepatosplenomegaly. Investigations showed pancytopenia with increased PT, aPTT, and fibrin degradation products. Bone marrow aspirate reveals the following findings. Cytogenetic studies revealed the presence of t(15:17). Which of the following agents is the mainstay of treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with epistaxis along with increased PT, aPTT, and fibrin degradation products in the background of fatigue, easy bruising, and pancytopenia and bone marrow aspirate showing promyelocytes containing Auer rods (eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions) is suggestive of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML). All-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA) is the mainstay of treatment with t(15:17).

Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML/APL) is associated with a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 15 and 17 producing a PML-RARA fusion gene.  The chimeric protein produced by PML-RARA binds to retinoic acid-responsive elements in the cells causing inhibition of transcription and accumulation of myeloid progenitor cells. ATRA binds to the PML-RARA chimeric protein and leads to conformational change which makes the protein regain its normal function. This activates DNA transcription and induces myeloid differentiation.

Clinical features include generalized weakness and fatigue, gingival bleeding, petechiae or ecchymoses, visual changes secondary to retinal hemorrhages, epistaxis, or menorrhagia. Complications include deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, cerebrovascular accident, etc. Some patients present with overt disseminated intravascular coagulation and frank bleeding.

Pancytopenia can be seen in APML. Bone marrow aspirate will show promyelocytes with abnormally coarse and numerous azurophilic granules (Auer rods). PMR/RARA fusion seen in APML can be rapidly diagnosed with fluorescence in situ hybridization(FISH).

The image below shows Auer rod cells seen in APML:

 

Management includes all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) with arsenic trioxide (ATO).

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents with complaints of fatigue and severe itching throughout her body. Investigations reveal elevated GGT and ALP levels. She was suspected to have cirrhosis. Histopathological examination shows florid duct lesions and the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions in hepatocytes. What is the content of these inclusions?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of elevated ALT and GGT with florid duct lesions on histopathology is suggestive of primary biliary cirrhosis. The intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions on HPE are suggestive of Mallory Denk bodies. They are made up of cytokeratin 8 (Intermediate filaments)

As the liver undergoes inflammation and fibrosis, the hepatocytes are injured and swollen with cleared-out cytoplasm and cytoskeletal damage. These hepatocytes are called ballooned hepatocytes. When the cytoskeletal damage is extensive, there is the formation of Mallory Denk/ Mallory hyaline bodies. These are remnants of partially degraded intermediate filaments (cytokeratin 8 and 18).

questions.text: A 15-month-old baby is brought to your OPD for a routine check-up. On examination, you notice that the child's fine motor development is normal. Which of the following milestones helped you come to this conclusion?

choices.text: Transfer objects from one hand to another

Transferring objects from one hand to another is seen at 6 months.
