questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents to the OPD with amenorrhea for the last 8 months. She complains of a loss of libido and problems with intercourse with her partner. There is a previous history of chronic radiation exposure. Investigations are given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

FSH: 55 IU/L 
Prolactin: 20 ng/mL 
Pregnancy test: Negative
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a history of amenorrhea and loss of libido with chronic radiation exposure and elevated FSH levels (> 40 IU/L) in a 35-year-old female point toward the diagnosis of premature ovarian failure.

Premature ovarian failure is defined as ovarian failure occurring before the age of 40 years. Clinically, it presents as secondary amenorrhoea for at least 3 months with raised FSH, raised FSH/LH ratio, and low estrogen.

Causes of POF

  • Migration of germ cells from the yolk sac.
  • Germ cell apoptosis.
    • Chromosomal abnormalities
    • Autoimmune diseases - hypothyroidism, Addison's disease, etc
    • Genital TB
    • Smoking
    • Radiation and chemotherapy
    • Hysterectomy
    • Prolonged GnRH therapy
    • Induction of multiple ovulation.

Clinical features include amenorrhea, hot flashes, sweating, diminished libido, vaginal dryness, and urinary symptoms.

Management:

  • Treatment of cause
  • If not interested in pregnancy:
    • Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) - Libido improves with estrogen therapy
  • If interested in pregnancy:
    • Ovulation induction (if an ovarian reserve is present) or donor eggs for in vitro fertilization.

Other options:

Option B: Patients with androgen insensitivity syndrome would have presented with primary amenorrhea. Karyotyping would reveal a 46XY karyotype. LH is raised, but FSH is normal. 

Option C: A prolactinoma would present with elevated prolactin levels.

Option D: In polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), there are features like menstrual abnormalities, obesity, and hyperandrogenism. LH level is raised, FSH level remains normal, but FSH/LH ratio falls. Estrogen levels increase.

questions.text: You perform the Jones dye test on a patient who complains of watering from his left eye for the past 6 months. In Jones dye test 1, the dye is not seen in the cotton kept in the nose. However, on flushing with saline, both saline and dye are seen in the cotton. What could be the cause of watering in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the absence of dye in the cotton (negative Jones test 1) and the presence of dye in the cotton (positive Jones test 2) indicates a partial nasolacrimal duct (NLD) obstruction.

Watering of the eye is characterised by the overflow of tears from the conjunctival sac. The condition may occur either due to excessive secretion of tears (hyperlacrimation) or may result from inadequate drainage (outflow) of normally secreted tears (epiphora).

Jones dye tests are performed when a partial obstruction is suspected. Jones primary test (Jones test I) is used to distinguish between watering caused by partial obstruction of the lacrimal passages and primary hypersecretion of tears.

A dye-stained cotton bud indicates adequate drainage through the lacrimal passages and the cause of watering is primary hypersecretion. The unstained cotton(negative test) indicates either a partial obstruction or failure of the lacrimal pump mechanism. To differentiate between these conditions, Jones dye test-II is performed.

A positive Jones test II suggests that dye was present in the sac but could not reach the nose due to partial obstruction. A negative test indicates the presence of lacrimal pump failure which is the inability of the lid muscles to push tears towards the punctum for drainage. It is also called functional obstruction.

The flowchart below depicts the Jones dye test.

questions.text: A 21-year-old patient came with dizziness, headache, and weakness for 30 minutes while she was studying for her final exams. She has had similar complaints on 6 separate occasions in the last 3 months.  Family history is significant for Type 2 diabetes mellitus in her father. Fingerstick glucose is 40mg/dl. Her symptoms were relieved by IV glucose. Her C peptide levels are elevated, insulin to C peptide ratio is <1. Which of the following investigations will you do next?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen with contrast

questions.solution:
This patient presenting with dizziness and headache that relieved on taking glucose most likely has hypoglycemia secondary to hyperinsulinemia. She most likely has been taking sulfonylureas and has factitious disorder. 

Factitious disorder is also known as Munchausen syndrome:

  • The patient is referred to as a professional patient wherein the person always fakes the disease/symptoms in order to seek medical attention.
  • They keep going from doctor to doctor and hospital to hospital to seek attention.
  • They would have undergone multiple procedures and surgeries and have a characteristic Gridiron abdomen – multiple scars on the abdomen
  • They distort their history and findings and make it hard to come to a diagnosis when there isn’t any existing pathology.

This patient has the classic Whipple's triad of findings. The triad includes:

  • Symptoms of hypoglycemia after fasting or exercise
  • Plasma glucose levels <2.8 mmol/L or 50 mg/dL.
  • Relief of symptoms after intravenous administration of glucose

This triad can occur in insulinomas and in patients using insulin or insulin secretagogues surreptitiously.

This patient has had repeated doctor visits for similar symptoms. This coupled with the history of diabetes mellitus in her father allows access to sulfonylureas. This patient has likely been taking sulfonylureas to reproduce these symptoms to assume the sick role. Besides this, insulinomas are highly unlikely in a patient less than 40 years of age.

Treatment is with psychotherapy and consults with the same physician to prevent unnecessary testing.

Factitious disorder vs malingering: Factitious disorder is an intentional production of physical symptoms to obtain medical attention whereas malingering is an intentional production of symptoms and they hold a motive behind it.

Other Options:

Option A: Serum TSH can be used in cases of suspected abuse of thyroid hormone supplements. This patient's symptoms are more likely due to sulfonylurea use

Option B: CT of the abdomen can be used in cases of suspected insulinomas. This patient's presentation is more likely due to the abuse of sulfonylureas.

Option D: MRI of the brain is done in evaluation of headaches to look for space-occupying lesions. However this patient's episodic dizziness and weakness make this unlikely. 

Note: The reason why C peptide levels are higher than insulin is due to the different mechanism of metabolism. Insulin is metabolised by the liver at a faster pace while C peptide is excreted by the kidneys at a slower pace. Hence in surreptitious use of secretagogues, the ratio is reduced. 

Also, note that the most likely answer considering all the factors of the presentation needs to be chosen. Here, considering the age and other factors, serum sulfonylurea screening is the best suited next step.

questions.text: A 20 year old male is brought to the casualty after an accident and massive transfusion protocol is activated. An ABG done 4 hours later reveals hypocalcemia that is refractory to correction with IV Calcium salts. What other electrolyte abnormality is likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient had received a massive blood transfusion. This can lead to hypocalcemia due to the binding of calcium by the citrate present in the stored blood.

Massive blood transfusions can also lead to hypomagnesemia and when it is present, it can lead to treatment-resistant hypocalcemia and hypokalemia. In this patient with treatment-resistant hypocalcemia, he likely has a co-existing hypomagnesemia. Hypocalcemia refractory to correction with IV Calcium salts would be hypomagnesemia rather than hyperkalemia.

Massive transfusion is defined as the transfusion of 50% of the patient’s total blood volume over 3 hours or >5–10 units of RBCs.

Complications are:

  1. Citrate toxicity
  2. Hypothermia (Rapid transfusion of blood components at 4°C )
  3. Hypocalcemia that presents as circumoral paresthesia.
  4. Hyperkalemia(RBC leakage during longer storage, and irradiation increases the concentration of potassium in the unit)
  5. Dilutional coagulopathy. 
  6. Hypomagnesemia

Related Pearl: Complications of a Massive Transfusion

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

Complication Mechanism
Hypothermia As blood products are normally stored between 1°C and 6°C
Coagulopathy

MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy (vs consumptive coagulopathy caused by massive hemorrhage)

Can be prevented by starting early transfusion of FFP, platelets, pRBCs in a 1:1:1 ratio
Acidosis/ Alkalosis

Mild acidosis - increased CO2 levels in stored blood by 21-35 days

Metabolic alkalosis - citrate gets metabolized to bicarbonate

Metabolic acidosis - due to tissue hypoperfusion
Hyperkalemia/ Hypokalemia

Initially - Hyperkalemia, as stored blood has high K+ levels due to inactivated Na/K/ATPase pump

Later - Hypokalemia, due to intracellular potassium uptake and metabolic alkalosis
Hypocalcemia Stored blood is anticoagulated with citrate, which binds calcium.
Hypomagnesemia Infusion of large volumes of magnesium-poor fluids and binding of magnesium to citrate
Impaired O2-carrying capacity of hemoglobin Decreased 2, 3 DPG
Volume overload Due to massive transfusion

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents with a painful right calf. USG shows deep vein thrombosis. He has a history of Diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, and a subdural hematoma secondary to a fall. He is healthy currently except for the deep vein thrombosis. Which of the following is best suited to reduce his risk of a pulmonary embolism?

choices.text: IV heparin with careful PTT monitoring

questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). In this patient with a history of a previous intracranial haemorrhage(Subdural hematoma) anticoagulation and thrombolysis is contraindicated. Hence an IVC filter would be the preferred method to prevent pulmonary embolism. 

The principal indications for insertion of an IVC filter are:

  1. Active bleeding (prevents the use of anticoagulation)
  2. Deep vein thrombosis in a patient with a contraindication to anticoagulation.
  3. Recurrent thromboembolism despite adequate anticoagulation.
  4. Propagating iliofemoral venous thrombus in anticoagulation. 

Prevention of recurrent PE in patients with right heart failure who are not candidates for fibrinolysis and prophylaxis of extremely high-risk patients are some other indications for filter placement.

Patients impaired by dyspnea due to chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension should be considered for pulmonary thromboendarterectomy.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with persistent soreness of the nipple of the right breast. A crusted red, eczematous rash is present on the areola of the right breast. Histopathology shows malignant cells scattered individually throughout the squamous epithelium. These cells are periodic acid Schiff (PAS) positive and diastase resistant. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of a crusted red, eczematous rash on the areola with histopathology revealing malignant cells that are PAS positive and diastase resistant is suggestive of Paget's disease of the nipple.

Paget’s disease is a unique type of DCIS arising in the nipple. It presents as a unilateral erythematous eruption with crusting. Patient complaints of pruritus. It may become invasive with metastasis to the axillary lymph nodes.

Histology shows Paget cells, with abundant pale cytoplasm and pleomorphic nuclei, scattered individually throughout the squamous epithelium. Paget cells do not breach the basement membrane, they rather extend via the lactiferous sinuses into the nipple skin.

The underlying carcinomas are usually poorly differentiated, ER-negative, and overexpress HER2. A triple assessment is needed to exclude underlying malignancy. Paget’s disease without associated underlying malignancy is treated by central core excision followed by radiotherapy. Paget’s disease with underlying malignancy is treated by mastectomy and evaluation of the axillary nodal status.

Other options:

Option B: Mondor’s disease is thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall. The pathognomonic feature is a thrombosed subcutaneous cord which is usually attached to the skin.

Option C: Zuska’s disease, also called recurrent periductal mastitis, is a condition of recurrent retroareolar infections and abscesses. Smoking has been implicated as a risk factor for this condition.

Option D: Tietze syndrome is inflammation of the costochondral junction. Clinical features include pain in the lateral chest wall in the anterior axillary line and over the serratus anterior.

questions.text:
Which of the following is not considered an advantage of the revised recommendations of the IMNCI with respect to the classification and treatment of childhood pneumonia?

IMNCI- Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness.

choices.text: Oral cotrimoxazole can be used to treat both fast breathing pneumonia and chest indrawing pneumonia.
Decreased risk of nosocomial and injection borne infections.
Pneumonia classification and management are simplified to two categories.
Need for referrals to higher level facilities is decreased.

questions.solution:
According to the revised recommendations of the IMNCI, oral amoxicillin can be used to treat both fast-breathing pneumonia and chest indrawing pneumonia.

Cotrimoxazole is used in the treatment of suspected Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) as an additional treatment for HIV-infected infants aged from 2 months up to 1 year with chest indrawing or severe pneumonia.

Integrated Management of Childhood Illnesses (IMCI) is a strategy developed by the World Health Organization (WHO) and UNICEF. The IMNCI clinical guidelines target children less than 5 years old — the age group that bears the highest burden of deaths from common childhood diseases.

The advantages of the revised recommendations include:

  • Oral amoxicillin can be used to treat both fast-breathing pneumonia and chest indrawing pneumonia.
  • Pneumonia classification and management are simplified to two categories instead of three.
  • The need for referrals to higher-level facilities is decreased.
  • The probability of hospitalization and thus the risk of nosocomial and injection-borne diseases is reduced.
  • Probability of antimicrobial resistance is diminished, due to better adherence to the simplified treatment.
  • Access to antibiotic treatment closer to home is increased.
  • Training of health workers is simplified.

The following image distinguishes the previous and revised classification and treatment of childhood pneumonia.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes with the following lesions on his back and is concerned about malignancy. He says the lesions have persisted for years, and he had not previously sought medical attention as he had just ignored them. How would you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The above findings in an old man is a cherry hemangioma. It is benign and asymptomatic in most cases and patients should be reassured. 

Cherry angiomas are the most common vascular malformations seen. They're true capillary hemangiomas. They appear as small red dots on the skin in the third and fourth decades of life. The increase in numbers with age. They can appear anywhere on the body. 

Diagnosis is usually clinical but a biopsy can be done in doubtful cases. 

Management: Usually, cherry angiomas are asymptomatic and benign and patients should be reassured. 
For bleeding lesions or ones that are cosmetically troubling, the following measures can be taken:

  • Shave excision (Option D)
  • Hyfrecation
  • Cryotherapy (Option B)
  • Pulsed dye laser

Other Options:

Option A: Biopsy can be done in a lesion that appeared recently, however, this patient's lesions have persisted for years and are unlikely to be malignant.

questions.text: A primigravida underwent a quadruple screening test at 16 weeks of gestation. All the parameters were low except for serum inhibin A level which was normal. Identify the condition in which the findings given above are seen.
questions.solution:
All the parameters like maternal serum alfa-fetoprotein (MSAFP), beta HCG, and unconjugated estriol levels are reduced in trisomy 18/Edwards syndrome. Maternal serum inhibin A level may be normal or reduced.

Quadruple testing is usually done in the second trimester between 15-21 weeks of gestation. This test can additionally help in picking up Smith-Lemli-Optiz syndrome. However, one of the limitations of the test is that it fails to detect trisomy 13. 

In trisomy 21 and neural tube defects, the changes in the screening markers are as follows:

Parameter Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect 
MSAFP Low Low High
β hCG High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
Inhibin A High Normal/Low Normal

Various antenatal screening tests for aneuploidy are as follows:

Dual test (1st trimester) Triple test (2nd trimester) Quadruple test (2nd trimester)
Beta HCG  Beta HCG  Beta HCG 
PAPP-A  Unconjugated estriol  Unconjugated estriol 
This can be combined with nuchal translucency by USG MSAFP  MSAFP

questions.text:
A 35-year-old patient developed sudden onset fever, focal seizures and agitated behaviour for 2 days. Lumbar puncture was positive for HSV DNA, detected by PCR. Which of the following findings will be seen on EEG?

HSV- Herpes simplex virus 

PCR- Polymerase chain reaction

choices.text: Periodic biphasic or triphasic sharp-wave complexes.
Periodic focal temporal lobe spikes on a background of low-amplitude.
Generalised symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern.

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient's clinical features of sudden onset fever, focal seizures, agitated behaviour and positive HSV DNA on PCR are suggestive of Herpes simplex encephalitis which shows periodic focal temporal lobe spikes on a background of low amplitude on EEG.

The clinical hallmark of HSV encephalitis is the acute onset of fever and focal neurologic symptoms and signs, especially in the temporal lobe.

PCR amplification of viral DNA from the cerebrospinal fluid is the most sensitive means of detection and is recommended for the diagnosis of herpes meningitis or encephalitis. CSF shows lymphocytic pleocytosis, moderately elevated protein levels, and normal glucose concentration.

T2-weighted MRI,  FLAIR, or Diffusion-weighted MRI show high-intensity signals in the temporal regions.

Treatment of HSV encephalitis includes IV. Acyclovir. It is the drug of choice and administered in the dose of 10mg/kg body weight, once every eight hours for 14 to 21 days.

Other options:

Option A: EEG showing hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes) is suggestive of West syndrome. 

Option B:  EEG showing periodic biphasic or triphasic sharp-wave complexes seen as spikes is associated with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD). 

Option C: In Absent seizure, generalised symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern is seen on EEG.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with long-standing diabetes presented with a gangrenous diabetic foot ulcer. Laboratory investigations are suggestive of septicemia. An X-ray of the foot shows bony erosion of the first and second metatarsals. Identify the incorrect statement about this condition.

choices.text: After amputation, failure of take up of skin flap may occur
Intravenous antibiotics and wound debridement should be done
Amputation should be done distal to the gangrenous area
Revascularisation of the limb can be tried by angioplasty

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of diabetic gangrene of the right foot. The definitive management of patients presenting with gangrene and life-threatening systemic upset should be primary amputation. The level of amputation should be proximal to the area of gangrene.

A combination of three factors usually causes diabetic gangrene:

  • Ischaemia secondary to macrovascular disease and microvascular dysfunction
  • Peripheral sensorimotor neuropathy (PSN), which leads to trophic skin changes
  • Immunosuppression is caused by the excess of sugar in the tissues, which predisposes to infection

Macrovascular disease is atherosclerotic and typically affects the crural vessels with relative sparing of the pedal vessels, whereas increased microcirculatory shunting causes microvascular dysfunction.

The peripheral neuropathy is usually sensory in the early phase, classically in a stocking distribution, and renders the patients at high risk of soft tissue injury and its subsequent neglect. It may extend to the foot and ankle joints, resulting in loss of nociceptive and proprioceptive protective reflexes and a repeated cycle of joint injury and bony destruction.

Motor involvement causes an imbalance between flexors and extensor muscle groups of the foot, promoting altered foot biomechanics and abnormal pressure loading and resulting in thick callosities developing on the sole of the foot.

Ischaemia and Peripheral neuropathy act synergistically to increase the risk of diabetic foot ulceration and reduce its subsequent healing potential. Superadded infection due to poor wound care can spread rapidly and proximally in subfascial planes leading to fulminant foot sepsis, gangrene, and death.

In dry gangrene, the separation occurs by aseptic ulceration with minimum infection and the gangrene is dry and mummified.

In wet gangrene, separation takes place by septic ulceration. Often demarcation is vague with skip lesions more proximally and so landing with a higher level of amputations. Even after amputation skin flap may show die back process, leading to failure of taking up of flap of amputation and so requiring a still higher level of amputation.

Treatment depends on arterial involvement, which should be investigated and treated rapidly with angioplasty or surgery. The gangrene is treated by drainage of pus, liberal debridement of dead tissue, and antibiotics. Unfortunately, a number of patients present with life-threatening systemic upset and should undergo primary amputation.

questions.text: A lady with 7 weeks of amenorrhea presented to the OPD with complaints of slight vaginal spotting. On TVS, the MSD was 35 mm, and CRL was 7.8 mm with no cardiac activity. What is the next best step in the management in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with amenorrhea presenting with spotting with TVS revealing the MSD was 35 mm(Critical value->25mm), and CRL was 7.8 mm (Critical value ≥ 7mm) with no cardiac activity indicates missed abortion. The next best step in management is to perform MTP.

In a normal intrauterine pregnancy, a gestational sac will be visible on TVS by 4.5-5 weeks of LMP, and at 5.5 weeks the yolk sac appears. At 6 weeks, an embryo first appears adjacent to the yolk sac. The cardiac activity of the embryo can be first visualized on TVS around 6-6.5 weeks.

Mean sac (gestational sac) diameter ≥25mm and CRL ≥7mm are known as critical cut-off values which represent the upper limit beyond which if a structure is not visualized, it is abnormal.

Hence, Missed Abortion should be suspected if, on USG 

  • CRL ≥7 mm and no heartbeat is recorded (CRL-crown rump length)
  • MSD ≥25 mm and no embryo is seen (MSD-mean sac diameter)

Medical management can be performed with prostaglandin E1(misoprostol) or oxytocin. Surgical management in the form of dilatation and curettage can be performed.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old girl is brought with a history of impaired vision. On examination, she has light hair, light skin color, and pale blue iris. The child has a normal IQ. Which of the following are not derived from the precursor amino acid, whose metabolism is impaired in this child?

DOPA- dihydroxyphenylalanine, GABA- Gamma-aminobutyric acid
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a child with impaired vision, light hair, light skin color, and pale blue iris with a normal IQ is suggestive of albinism, which is a disorder of tyrosine metabolism where there is a defect in melanin synthesis. Glutamate is the precursor amino acid of GABA (γ-aminobutyric acid), not tyrosine.

Tyrosine is a precursor of melanin, thyroxin, epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA).

  • Formation of DOPA: Tyrosine is hydroxylated by tyrosinase to form dihydroxy phenylalanine or DOPA. Tyrosinase is a monooxygenase that contains copper.
  • Formation of melanin: Tyrosinase acts on DOPA to form dopaquinone, which is then converted to indolequinone. The indolequinone is polymerized to form melanin.
  • Formation of catecholamines: Epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine. They are produced by the adrenal medulla and sympathetic ganglia.
  • Formation of thyroid hormones: Tyrosine residues are iodinated to form 3-mono-iodo-tyrosine (MIT) and 3,5-di-iodo-tyrosine (DIT). These are coupled to give rise to triiodothyronine (T3) and tetraiodothyronine (thyroxine or T4).

The series of reactions involving the production of catecholamines is shown in the image below.

Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a group of inherited disorders characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes leading to hypopigmentation. It is either due to defective melanosomes or defective protein involved in the formation and transfer of melanin.
 
There are 7 types of nonsyndromic albinism (OCA1 to OCA7). OCA type 1 is characterized by reduced or absent tyrosinase activity. Clinical features include white hair, white skin, and iris appearing blue-grey in oblique light. Ocular manifestations include photophobia, nystagmus, and decreased visual acuity. The IQ of the child will be normal.

questions.text: A child, while playing in a field, stepped his right foot over a sharp-pointed stone. Immediately, as a reflex action, he lifted his right leg and extended the left leg. The action of the left leg is attributable to which of the following reflexes?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, when the right foot is placed on the sharp stone, the right leg is lifted off due to the flexor withdrawal reflex, while the left leg is extended due to the crossed-extensor reflex.

When a painful stimulus is applied to a limb, then the limb is immediately flexed to pull away from the danger. This reflex is called the flexion withdrawal reflex. Within 0.2 to 0.5 seconds, the extensor muscles of the opposite limb contract, to shift the weight of the body onto the other side, in the case of the lower limb, or to push the dangerous stimulus away from the body. This reflex is called the crossed-extensor reflex.

After the painful stimulus is removed, the crossed extensor reflex has a longer period of after-discharge when compared to the flexor reflex. This prolonged after-discharge results from reverberating circuits among the inter-neuronal cells.

The image below shows the flexor reflex

The image below shows the crossed extensor reflex

Other options:

Option A- The patellar tendon reflex, which is activated by tapping the patellar tendon, is a type of stretch reflex.

Option C- Positive supportive reaction is a primitive postural reflex, wherein the pressure applied on the footpad causes extension of the limb.

Option D- The Golgi tendon reflex provides a negative feedback mechanism that prevents the development of excessive tension in a muscle.

questions.text: You are posted in pediatrics OPD as an intern. A 7-year-old child presents to the clinic with a history of recurrent fractures and poorly-developed teeth. Examination reveals joint laxity and blue sclera. Both parents are phenotypically normal. Your senior asks you to interpret the mode of inheritance in this case from the pedigree chart given below.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of recurrent fractures, poorly developed teeth with blue sclera, and joint laxity is suggestive of osteogenesis imperfecta. Osteogenesis imperfecta is an example of gonadal mosaicism where phenotypically normal parents can have more than one affected child.

It is a type of autosomal dominant disorder where some patients do not have phenotypically affected parents. The disorder can result from a new mutation in the egg or the sperm from which the zygote was formed. The siblings may or may not be affected. In some cases, mosaicism can result from a mutation that occurs after the formation of the zygote, during early (embryonic) development.

A phenotypically normal parent who has gonadal mosaicism can transmit the disease-causing mutation to the offspring through their mutated ova/sperm. Therefore, there is a possibility that more than one child of such a parent can be affected.

Other options:

Option A- In X-linked recessive conditions, an affected male does not transmit the disorder to his sons but all daughters will be carriers of the disease. Sons of heterozygous women have a chance of inheriting the mutant gene.

Option B- In mitochondrial inheritance, if the mother is affected and the father is normal, then all their children (both male and female) will be affected. However, children born to an affected father and a normal mother will not be affected.

Option C- Genomic imprinting is the transcriptional silencing of either maternal or paternal allele. Prader-Willi syndrome is paternal imprinting (deletion of paternal chromosome15 in 65-75% of individuals), maternal uniparental disomy 15 (20-30%), or an imprinting defect; and Angelman syndrome is due to maternal imprinting (deletion of maternal chromosome 15).

questions.text: A 40-year-old HIV-infected male with a CD4 count of <200 cells/cu presents with shortness of breath, dry cough and moderate fever of two-week duration. Inspiratory crackles are heard on auscultation and chest CT shows bilateral ground-glass pattern. What is the most common causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, an HIV-infected male with a CD4 count <200 cells/cu presenting with shortness of breath, dry cough, fever, inspiratory crackles on auscultation and bilateral ground glass appearance on CT, points to the diagnosis Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia(PCP). 

Pneumocystis jirovecii is an opportunistic pathogen that causes pneumonia in immunocompromised hosts, particularly those with HIV infection with CD4 counts <200 cells/mm3. Pneumocystis proliferates in the lung, provoking a mononuclear cell response. The alveoli become filled with proteinaceous material and alveolar damage results in increased alveolar-capillary injury.

Chest X-ray reveals bilateral, symmetric, interstitial infiltration. Initially, infiltrates are perihilar, as the disease progresses, it becomes diffuse. High-resolution chest CT shows diffuse ground-glass opacities in virtually all patients with PCP.

The treatment of choice for PCP is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX). Intravenous pentamidine or the combination of clindamycin + primaquine is an option for patients who cannot tolerate TMP-SMX.

Other options:

Option A: Streptococcus pneumonia, is the most common organism known to cause pneumonia irrespective of the HIV status. Patients present with fever, dyspnea, and productive cough. On examination, involved lobes are dull to percussion, bronchial breath sounds, and crackles are heard on auscultation.

A chest radiograph reveals focal, segmental, or lobar consolidation of involved lobes.

 

Option C: 

Staphylococcus aureus causes bacterial pneumonia with features similar to pneumococcal pneumonia. The differentiating feature is that chest X-ray in Staph. aureus infection shows pneumatoceles (cavitation).

The X-ray shows pneumatoceles (air-filled cysts within lung parenchyma).

Option D: Mycoplasma causes atypical pneumonia. Patients present with dry cough, fever, chills, malaise, and upper respiratory tract symptoms. On auscultation, wheezes or rales are heard. Chest X-ray shows peribronchial pneumonia with prominent bronchial markings, interstitial infiltration, and atelectasis.

The chest X-ray below shows patchy consolidation at the hilum and fanning to the periphery.

    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)

    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)

    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-

    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-

    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient was diagnosed with Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia. A fixed-dose combination of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole was prescribed. The drugs act by inhibiting which of the following enzymes respectively?
questions.solution:
Trimethoprim inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase, while sulfamethoxazole inhibits the enzyme dihydropteroate synthase.

The fixed-drug combination of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is the drug of choice for Pneumocystis jiroveci (formerly P carinii) pneumonia.

Trimethoprim is a selective inhibitor of microbial dihydrofolate reductase. Dihydrofolate reductase is involved in the reduction of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate. The combination of sulfonamide with trimethoprim will result in a sequential blockade of bacterial folate synthesis that causes a synergistic action and acts as a bactericidal.

Cotrimoxazole is used in the management of urinary tract infections, bacterial diarrhea, dysentery, pneumocystis jiroveci infections, and chancroid.

Adverse effects include nausea, vomiting, stomatitis, headache, megaloblastic anemia, and rashes. Blood dyscrasias can occur rarely.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman who was recently diagnosed with placenta increta comes to the clinic to discuss management options. She has an obstetric score of G2P1 and a previous history of C-section. Which of the following is associated with a favourable pregnancy outcome?

choices.text: Use of methotrexate post delivery to enhance placental autolysis

questions.solution:
Cesarean hysterectomy is indicated in cases of morbidly adherent placenta/placenta accreta spectrum. 

The placenta accreta spectrum is characterized by abnormally implanted, invasive, or adhered placenta. This occurs due to partial or complete absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the Nitabuch layer. Risk factors include associated placenta previa and previous cesarean delivery as seen in this patient. 

There are three variants of this condition based on the depth of trophoblastic growth.

  • Placenta accreta, the villi are attached to the myometrium.
  • Placenta increta, the villi invade into the myometrium.
  • Placenta percreta, the villi penetrate the myometrium into the serosa.

It can be diagnosed in the antepartum period by ultrasound which will reveal loss of normal hypoechoic retroplacental zone between the placenta and uterus, placental vascular lacunae, bridging vessels, and placental bulging leading to distortion of the contour of the uterus. MRI can be performed when the ultrasound is inconclusive. However, ultrasound remains the modality of choice for diagnosis.

Management of this condition involves the following

  • Appropriate surgical, anesthesia, intensive care, and blood banking capabilities
  • Recommended scheduled delivery between 34 0/7 to 35 6/7 weeks (American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists)
  • Cesarean hysterectomy to reduce risk of maternal bleeding with placenta left in situ after delivery
  • Manual removal of the placenta should not be attempted due to the increased risk of blood loss.
  • Evidence regarding use of methotrexate in resorption of placenta is lacking.

questions.solution:
Shaffer’s sign or tobacco dusting refers to the presence of pigment cells in the anterior vitreous. It is seen in retinal detachment (RD), especially rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.

The image shows tobacco dust appearance (Shaffer's sign) in the anterior vitreous.

In rhegmatogenous retinal detachment, fluid accumulates after a break (tear) occurs in the retina. The most dangerous type of retinal break is a horseshoe tear. The most dangerous location of the retinal break is the superior temporal retina. 

Risk factors for the development of rhegmatogenous RD are:

  • High myopia
  • Blunt trauma
  • Previous cataract surgery (aphakia and pseudophakia)
  • Lattice degeneration of the retina

Clinical features of rhegmatogenous RD are:

  • Symptoms
    • Photopsia: Flashes of light due to vitreoretinal traction at the site of the break. Photopsia is symptom-specific for rhegmatogenous detachment. 
    • Floaters: Due to associated vitreous hemorrhage
    • Visual field defect: A black curtain/veil in front of the eye
  • Signs
    • Shaffer's sign: Pigments in the anterior vitreous (tobacco dusting) are a feature of fresh retinal detachment.
    • The detached retina is convex in its configuration.
    • The surface is corrugated with undulations.

Treatment of rhegmatogenous RD includes:

  • Prophylactic laser barrage
  • Scleral buckling
  • Pneumatic retinopexy
  • Pars plana vitrectomy

questions.text:
Under a scheme launched by the NRHM, in an urban area in Madya Pradesh, a community healthcare worker receives 400 rupees for encouraging a primigravida mother to deliver at a hospital rather than at home. Who is the healthcare worker being referred to in the above scenario?

NRHM- National Rural Health Mission
questions.solution:
According to the Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY), a program launched on 12th April 2005, under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM), an ASHA worker will receive 400 rupees for motivating the mother to undergo an institutional delivery rather than to deliver at home. In the same scenario, the mother is also given 1000 rupees.

Janani Suraksha Yojana aims to reduce maternal mortality by encouraging delivery in government health facilities. Under the scheme, a financial incentive is also provided for giving birth in a government health facility. 

The Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA) is the link between pregnant women and health institutions. She is responsible for making institutional antenatal and postnatal care available. 

States are divided into low-performing and high-performing on the basis of institutional delivery rate. The 10 low-performing states (LPS) with a low institutional delivery rate are Uttar Pradesh, Uttarakhand, Madhya Pradesh, Jharkhand, Bihar, Rajasthan, Chattisgarh, Odisha, Assam, and Jammu & Kashmir. All the other states are high-performing states (HPS).

The incentives under JSY are as follows:

Under this scheme, the cost of cesarean section and management of obstetric complications is also subsidized, up to Rs 1500 per delivery to the government institutions, where government specialists are not present.

Other options: 

Option B: An Auxiliary Nurse Midwife (ANM) is a trained health worker who provides basic healthcare services, including antenatal care, delivery, and postnatal care. She will utilize ASHA workers in motivating the pregnant women to come to the sub-centre for initial checkups and educate ASHA workers on the danger signs of pregnancy and labour. She does not receive any incentives like an ASHA worker under this scheme.

Option C: An Anganwadi Worker (AWW) is responsible for providing basic health care, nutrition, and preschool education to children under the age of six, pregnant women and lactating mothers. 

Option D: Trained birth attendants or dais provide medical services during delivery and in the post-partum period. 

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

Related Pearl: Maternal Mortality Ratio

Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

The main global causes of maternal deaths are severe bleeding, indirect causes (anemia, malaria, heart diseases), infections, unsafe abortions, eclampsia, obstructed labor, and other direct causes like ectopic pregnancy, anesthesia-related complications, etc.

In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

Related Pearl: Neonatal Mortality Rate

  • Neonatal deaths are those that occur during the neonatal period, commencing at birth and ending at 28 completed days after birth.
  • NMR = Number of deaths of children under 28 days of age in a year x 1000/Total live births in the same year
  • Main causes of neonatal death are prematurity (leading cause), birth asphyxia, intrapartum-related complications, sepsis, pneumonia, congenital anomalies, tetanus, diarrhea, etc.
  • India’s NMR  is 20 per 1000 live births (SRS 2020)

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency for the alleged consumption of an organophosphate compound. He is being treated with atropine and develops palpitations, blurring of vision, dryness of mouth, difficulty in speaking and swallowing, and difficulty in micturition. All of the following antihistamines can safely administered in this patient except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a patient being treated with atropine developing palpitations, blurring or vision and dryness of mouth,  difficulty in speaking and swallowing, and difficulty in micturition are indicative of atropine toxicity. Promethazine should be avoided in this case.

Promethazine is a first-generation antihistamine that has the strongest antimuscarinic activity amongst all antihistamines and therefore can potentiate atropine toxicity. Therefore, it has to be avoided in this patient.

A few important symptoms of atropine toxicity are shown in the diagram below.

The predominant initial signs are of muscarinic excess which includes: (DUMBBELSS)

  • Diarrhea
  • Urination
  • Miosis
  • Bronchospasm
  • Bradycardia
  • Emesis
  • Lacrimation
  • Salivation
  • Sweating

Nicotinic manifestations include twitching of eyelids, tongue, and facial muscles which then leads to paralysis. CNS stimulation results in headaches, tremors, ataxia, coma, and death. 

Other options:

Options A, B, and D: Fexofenadine, loratadine, and levocetrizine are second-generation antihistamines with no anticholinergic activity and therefore can safely be used in this patient.

questions.text: What is the pin index system for the cylinder given in the image below?
questions.solution:
The cylinder given in the above image is the oxygen cylinder. The pin index system for oxygen gas is 2,5.

A pin index safety system is adopted to prevent incorrect cylinder attachments. Each gas cylinder (sizes A–E) has two holes in its cylinder valve that mate with corresponding pins in the yoke of the anesthesia machine. The relative positioning of the pins and holes is unique for each gas.

Salient features of oxygen cylinder:

  • Black cylinders with white shoulders are used to store oxygen.
  • The pin index of the oxygen cylinder is 2,5.
  • The maximum pressure in the oxygen cylinder is around 2000 psi. 
  • The critical temperature of oxygen is -119 ºC; hence, it is present in the gaseous form at room temperature.

  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with less than 7% CO2: 2,6
